english_description: Deviation from the norm of height with respect to that which is expected according to age and gender norms.

Multicystic dysplasia of the kidney is characterized by multiple cysts of varying size in the kidney and the absence of a normal pelvicaliceal system. The condition is associated with ureteral or ureteropelvic atresia, and the affected kidney is nonfunctional.

A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on one of the autosomes (i.e., the human chromosomes 1-22) in which a trait manifests in heterozygotes. In the context of medical genetics, an autosomal dominant disorder is caused when a single copy of the mutant allele is present. Males and females are affected equally, and can both transmit the disorder with a risk of 50% for each child of inheriting the mutant allele.

A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on one of the autosomes (i.e., the human chromosomes 1-22) in which a trait manifests in individuals with two pathogenic alleles, either homozygotes (two copies of the same mutant allele) or compound heterozygotes (whereby each copy of a gene has a distinct mutant allele).

english_term: Abnormal morphology of female internal genitalia
chinese_term: 女性内生殖器形态异常
english_description: An abnormality of the female internal genitalia.
Dysfunction of the urinary bladder.
Repeated infections of the urinary tract.

chinese_term: 神经源性膀胱功能障碍
english_description: A type of bladder dysfunction caused by neurologic damage. Neurogenic bladder can be flaccid or spastic. Common manifestatios of neurogenic bladder are overflow incontinence, frequency, urgency, urge incontinence, and retention.
Urge incontinence is the strong, sudden need to urinate.
Underdevelopment of the uterus.
An abnormality of the urinary bladder.
Diverticulum (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urinary bladder.
Inability to completely empty the urinary bladder during the process of urination.
Abnormally increased production of urine during the night leading to an unusually frequent need to urinate.
Difficulty in beginning the process of urination.
Loss of the ability to control the urinary bladder leading to involuntary urination.
Dilatation of the bladder postnatally.
An abnormality of the male internal genitalia.
Protrusion of the contents of the abdominal cavity through the inguinal canal.
The presence of inflammation of the prostate.

english_term: Functional abnormality of male internal genitalia
chinese_term: 男性内生殖器功能异常

english_description: Decreased functionality of the male gonad, i.e., of the testis, with reduced spermatogenesis or testosterone synthesis.
Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen.
Testis in inguinal canal. That is, absence of one or both testes from the scrotum owing to failure of the testis or testes to descend through the inguinal canal to the scrotum.
Wasting (atrophy) of the testicle (the male gonad) manifested by a decrease in size and potentially by a loss of fertility.
The presence of a gonadoblastoma of the testis.
The presence of inflammation of the epididymis.
An abnormality of male external genitalia.
Ambiguous genitalia in an individual with XY genetic gender.
Accumulation of clear fluid in the between the layers of membrane (tunica vaginalis) surrounding the testis.
An anomaly of the testicle (the male gonad).
Abnormality of the male external sex organ.

Hermaphroditism refers to a discrepancy between the morphology of the gonads and that of the external genitalia. In male pseudohermaphroditism, the genotype is male (XY) and the external genitalia are imcompletely virilized, ambiguous, or complete female. If gonads are present, they are testes.
Displacement of the urethral opening on the dorsal (superior) surface of the penis.
Penile length more than 2 SD above the mean for age.
Ventral, lateral, or ventrolateral bowing of the shaft and glans penis of more than 30 degrees.
Lack of external genitalia in a male or female individual.

chinese_term: 低促性腺激素性性腺功能减退症
english_description: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is characterized by reduced function of the gonads (testes in males or ovaries in females) and results from the absence of the gonadal stimulating pituitary hormones: follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH).

Abnormal position of urethral meatus on the ventral penile shaft (underside) characterized by displacement of the urethral meatus from the tip of the glans penis to the ventral surface of the penis, scrotum, or perineum.
Midline indentation or cleft of the scrotum.
Superior margin of the scrotum superior to the base of the penis.

chinese_term: 男性外生殖器发育不良
english_description: Underdevelopment of part or all of the male external reproductive organs (which include the penis, the scrotum and the urethra).
Hypospadias with location of the urethral meatus in the perineal region.
The presence of abnormally large testes.
Abnormally small penis. At birth, the normal penis is about 3 cm (stretched length from pubic tubercle to tip of penis) with micropenis less than 2.0-2.5 cm.
An abnormality of the female external genitalia.
An abnormality of the clitoris.
An anomaly of the labia, the externally visible portions of the vulva.
Undergrowth of the outer labia.
Developmental hypoplasia of the clitoris.
Ambiguous genitalia in an individual with XX genetic gender.

A genital phenotype that is not clearly assignable to a single gender. Ambiguous genitalia can be evaluated using the Prader scale: Prader 0: Normal female external genitalia. Prader 1: Female external genitalia with clitoromegaly. Prader 2: Clitoromegaly with partial labial fusion forming a funnel-shaped urogenital sinus. Prader 3: Increased phallic enlargement. Complete labioscrotal fusion forming a urogenital sinus with a single opening. Prader 4: Complete scrotal fusion with urogenital opening at the base or on the shaft of the phallus. Prader 5: Normal male external genitalia. The diagnosis of ambiguous genitalia is made for Prader 1-4.
Fusion of the labia minora as a result of labial adhesions resulting in vaginal obstruction.
Congenital anomaly characterized by closure or failure to develop an opening in the urethra.
An abnormality of the ureter. The ureter is the duct by which urine passes from the kidney to the bladder.
A ureterocele is a congenital saccular dilatation of the distal segment of the ureter.
The presence of a stenotic, i.e., constricted ureter.
The distention of the ureter with urine.
A developmental anomaly characterized by the presence of two, instead of one, ureter connecting a kidney to the bladder.

chinese_term: 肾盂输尿管连接部梗阻
english_description: Blockage of urine flow from the renal pelvis to the proximal ureter.
A congenital anomaly of the urinary tract, in which the kidney is duplicated and is drained via two separate renal pelves and ureters.
Abnormal (retrograde) movement of urine from the bladder into ureters or kidneys related to inadequacy of the valvular mechanism at the ureterovesicular junction or other causes.
An abnormality of the kidney.
An abnormality of the genital system.
An abnormality of the urinary system.

chinese_term: 生殖系统生理机能异常
english_description: An abnormal functionality of the genital system.

A duplication of the collecting system of the kidney, defined as a kidney with two (instead of, normally, one) pyelocaliceal systems. The pyelocaliceal system is comprised of the renal pelvis and calices. The duplicated renal collecting system can be associated with a single ureter or with double ureters. In the latter case, the two ureters empty separately into the bladder or fuse to form a single ureteral orifice.

A reduction in the level of performance of the kidneys in areas of function comprising the concentration of urine, removal of wastes, the maintenance of electrolyte balance, homeostasis of blood pressure, and calcium metabolism.
A connection of the right and left kidney by an isthmus of functioning renal parenchyma or fibrous tissue that crosses the midline.
A developmental defect in which a kidney is located in an abnormal anatomic position.
Hypoplasia of the kidney.
Presence of cysts at the corticomedullary junction of the kidney in combination with tubulointerstitial fibrosis.
An abnormality of the renal tubules.
The presence of renal tubules with thick redundant basement membranes, or a reduction of greater than 50% in tubular diameter compared to surrounding non-atrophic tubules.
Increased levels of protein in the urine.
Accumulation of scar tissue within the glomerulus.

chinese_term: 局灶节段性肾小球硬化
english_description: Segmental accumulation of scar tissue in individual (but not all) glomeruli.
A height above that which is expected according to age and gender norms.
Inflammation of the renal glomeruli.

Nephrotic syndrome is a collection of findings resulting from glomerular dysfunction with an increase in glomerular capillary wall permeability associated with pronounced proteinuria. Nephrotic syndrome refers to the constellation of clinical findings that result from severe renal loss of protein, with Proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia.
An increased rate of urine production.
Agenesis, that is, failure of the kidney to develop during embryogenesis and development.
An abnormal increase in the size of the kidney.
A fluid filled sac in the kidney.
The presence of multiple cysts at the border between the renal cortex and medulla.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the kidney.

chinese_term: 肾小球球旁细胞肥大/增生
english_description: Increased number and size of the juxtaglomerular cells.
A nonspecific term referring to disease or damage of the kidneys.
The presence of multiple cysts in both kidneys.
Dysfunction of the proximal tubule, which is the portion of the duct system of the nephron of the kidney which leads from Bowman's capsule to the loop of Henle.
High urine phosphate in the presence of hypophosphatemia.
The presence of any abnormality of the genitourinary system.
Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium salts in renal parenchyma.
A unilateral form of agenesis of the kidney.
The presence of inflammation affecting the kidney.

Abnormal function of the renal tubule. The basic functional unit of the kidney, the nephron, consists of a renal corpuscle attached to a renal tubule, with roughly 0.8 to 1.5 nephrons per adult kidney. The functions of the renal tubule include reabsorption of water, electrolytes, glucose, and amino acids and secretion of substances such as uric acid.
A developmental defect in which a kidney is located in an abnormal anatomic position within the pelvis.
Severe distention of the kidney with dilation of the renal pelvis and calices.
A high concentration of one or more electrolytes in the urine in the presence of low serum concentrations of the electrolyte(s).
High urine potassium in the presence of hypokalemia.
An abnormality of the uterus.
The presence of a leiomyoma of the uterus.
Prolonged and excessive menses at regular intervals in excess of 80 mL or lasting longer than 7 days.
Decreased functionality of the female gonads, i.e., of the ovary.
A decreased functionality of the gonad.
The presence of a bifid uterus.
An abnormality of the ovary.
The presence of one or more cysts of the ovary.
The presence of prolapse of the uterus.
An abnormality of the ovulation cycle.
Absence of menses for an interval of time equivalent to a total of more than (or equal to) 3 previous cycles or 6 months.
Any structural abnormality of the vagina.
The presence of a fistula between the vagina and the rectum.
Congenital occlusion of the vagina or adhesion of the walls of the vagina causing occlusion.
The presence of a gonadoblastoma of the ovary.
The presence of a gonadoblastoma, a neoplasm of a gonad that consists of aggregates of germ cells and sex cord elements.
Aplasia of the uterus.
An abnormality of head and neck.
An abnormality of the mouth.
Distance between the oral commissures more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased width of the oral aperture (subjective).
Erosion of the mucous mebrane of the mouth with local excavation of the surface, resulting from the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue.
Any abnormality of the tongue.
Increased length and width of the tongue.
Distance between the commissures of the mouth more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased width of the oral aperture (subjective).
A type of cleft lip presenting as a midline (median) gap in the upper lip.
Posterior displacement of the tongue into the pharynx, i.e., a tongue that is mislocalised posteriorly.
Abnormality of the oral cavity, i.e., the opening or hollow part of the mouth.
Any abnormality of the teeth.
A severe form of periodontitis.
Any abnormality of the gingiva (also known as gums).
The presence of fibrosis of the gingiva.
Decreased length and width of the tongue.
Abnormality of the uvula, the conic projection from the posterior edge of the middle of the soft palate.
Any abnormality of the palate, i.e., of roof of the mouth.
Cleft palate is a developmental defect of the palate resulting from a failure of fusion of the palatine processes and manifesting as a separation of the roof of the mouth (soft and hard palate).

Hard-palate submucous clefts are characterized by bony defects in the midline of the bony palate that are covered by the mucous membrane of the roof of the mouth. It may be possible to detect a submucous cleft hard palate upon palpation as a notch in the bony palate.
An abnormality of the upper lip.
An abnormality of the lower lip.

Increased thickness of the lower lip, leading to a prominent appearance of the lower lip. The height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the midline is more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the frontal view (subjective).
Multiple indentations and/or elevations on the edge and/or surface of the tongue producing an irregular surface contour.

Cleft of the soft palate (also known as the velum, or muscular palate) as a result of a developmental defect occurring between the 7th and 12th week of pregnancy. Cleft soft palate can cause functional abnormalities of the Eustachian tube with resulting middle ear anomalies and hearing difficulties, as well as speech problems associated with hypernasal speech due to velopharyngeal insufficiency.
Decreased width of the upper lip.
Width of the palate more than 2 SD below the mean (objective) or apparently decreased palatal width (subjective).
An abnormality of the lingual frenulum, that is of the small fold of mucous membrane that attaches the tongue to the floor of the mouth, or the presence of accessory frenula in the oral cavity.
Extra fold of tissue extending from the alveolar ridge to the inner surface of the upper or lower lip.
Uvula separated into two parts most easily seen at the tip.
A facial appearance characterized by a permanently or nearly permanently opened mouth.
Depression located on the vermilion of the lower lip, usually paramedian.

Any abnormality of the parotid glands, which are the salivary glands that are located in the subcutaneous tissues of the face overlying the mandibular ramus and anterior and inferior to the external ear.
The presence of an abnormally short lingual frenulum.

chinese_term: 皮埃尔 - 罗宾序列征
english_description: Pierre Robin malformation is a sequence of developmental malformations characterized by micrognathia (mandibular hypoplasia), glossoptosis and cleft palate.

The presence of a cleft in the oral cavity, the two main types of which are cleft lip and cleft palate. In cleft lip, there is the congenital failure of the maxillary and median nasal processes to fuse, forming a groove or fissure in the lip. In cleft palate, there is a congenital failure of the palate to fuse properly, forming a grooved depression or fissure in the roof of the mouth. Clefts of the lip and palate can occur individually or together. It is preferable to code each defect separately.
A gap in the upper lip. This is a congenital defect resulting from nonfusion of tissues of the lip during embryonal development.
An abnormality of the appearance of the face caused by constant contraction of the lips leading to a puckered or pursed appearance.
Inflammation of the tongue.
The presence of a triangular form of the mouth.
Limitation in the ability to open the mouth.

Hyperplasia of the gingiva (that is, a thickening of the soft tissue overlying the alveolar ridge. The degree of thickening ranges from involvement of the interdental papillae alone to gingival overgrowth covering the entire tooth crown.
Telangiectasia (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the lips.

Height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the midline more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the frontal view (subjective).
Dryness of the mouth due to salivary gland dysfunction.
Height of the palate more than 2 SD above the mean (objective) or palatal height at the level of the first permanent molar more than twice the height of the teeth (subjective).
Height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the midline more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the frontal view (subjective).
Inability of velopharyngeal sphincter to sufficiently separate the nasal cavity from the oral cavity during speech.
Accentuation of the grooves on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
Hyperkeratosis of the gingiva.
A decreased ability to perceive flavor.
Hemorrhage affecting the gingiva.
Telangiectasia (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the tongue.
Inflammation of the gingiva.

An abnormal configuration of the lower lip such that it is turned outward i.e., everted, with the Inner aspect of the lower lip vermilion (normally opposing the teeth) being visible in a frontal view.

Height of the vermilion of the medial part of the lip more than 2 SD below the mean, or apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the lip in the frontal view. The vermilion is the red part of the lips (and confusingly, the vermilion itself is also often referred to as being equivalent the lips).
An abnormality of the head.

english_term: Abnormality of the fontanelles or cranial sutures
english_description: Any abnormality of the fontanelles (the regions covered by a thick membrane that normally ossify in the first two years of life) or the cranial sutures (the fibrous joints in which the articulating bones or cartilages of the skull are connected by sutural ligaments).
Abnormally decreased size of the anterior fontanelle with respect to age-dependent norms.

Hydrocephalus is an active distension of the ventricular system of the brain resulting from inadequate passage of CSF from its point of production within the cerebral ventricles to its point of absorption into the systemic circulation.

In newborns, the two frontal bones, two parietal bones, and one occipital bone are joined by fibrous sutures, which form a small posterior fontanelle, and a larger, diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle. These regions allow for the skull to pass the birth canal and for later growth. The fontanelles gradually ossify, whereby the posterior fontanelle usually closes by eight weeks and the anterior fontanelle by the 9th to 16th month of age. Large fontanelles are diagnosed if the fontanelles are larger than age-dependent norms.
Parietal bossing is a marked prominence in the parietal region.
Wedge-shaped, or triangular head, with the apex of the triangle at the midline of the forehead and the base of the triangle at the occiput.
Abnormal vertical height of the skull and a shortening of its anterior-posterior length, frequently combined with malformations of the occipital region.
Inflammation of the paranasal sinuses owing to a viral, bacterial, or fungal infection, allergy, or an autoimmune reaction.

An abnormality of skull shape characterized by a decreased anterior-posterior diameter. That is, a cephalic index greater than 81%. Alternatively, an apparently shortened anteroposterior dimension (length) of the head compared to width.
An abnormal increase of density of the bones making up the calvaria.
Head circumference below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender.
Progressive microcephaly is diagnosed when the head circumference falls progressively behind age- and gender-dependent norms.
Occipitofrontal (head) circumference greater than 97th centile compared to appropriate, age matched, sex-matched normal standards. Alternatively, a apparently increased size of the cranium.
Enlargement of the anterior fontanelle with respect to age-dependent norms.
Tall head relative to width and length.
Oxycephaly (from Greek oxus, sharp, and kephalos, head) refers to a conical or pointed shape of the skull.
An abnormality of the mastoid process, which is the conical prominence projecting from the undersurface of the mastoid portion of the temporal bone.
Asymmetry of the bones of the skull.

An abnormality of skull shape characterized by a increased anterior-posterior diameter, i.e., an increased antero-posterior dimension of the skull. Cephalic index less than 76%. Alternatively, an apparently increased antero-posterior length of the head compared to width. Often due to premature closure of the sagittal suture.
Increased convexity of the occiput (posterior part of the skull).

Infants normally have two fontanels at birth, the diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle at the junction of the coronal and sagittal sutures, and the posterior fontanelle at the intersection of the occipital and parietal bones. The posterior fontanelle usually closes by the 8th week of life, and the anterior fontanel closes by the 18th month of life on average. This term applies if there is delay of closure of the fontanelles beyond the normal age.
An abnormality of the face.
Underdevelopment of the malar prominence of the jugal bone (zygomatic bone in mammals), appreciated in profile, frontal view, and/or by palpation.
A face that is short (HP:0011219) and narrow (HP:0000275).

Bizygomatic (upper face) and bigonial (lower face) width are both more than 2 standard deviations below the mean (objective); or, an apparent reduction in the width of the upper and lower face (subjective).
Facial height (length) is more than 2 standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, an apparent increase in the height (length) of the face (subjective).
Any abnormality of the mandible, the bone of the lower jaw.
An abnormality in which the mandible is mislocalised posteriorly.

Absence of fine and sharp appearance of brows, nose, lips, mouth, and chin, usually because of rounded and heavy features or thickened skin with or without thickening of subcutaneous and bony tissues.
Bizygomatic (upper face) and bigonial (lower face) width greater than 2 standard deviations above the mean (objective); or an apparent increase in the width of the face (subjective).
A fold of skin starting above the medial aspect of the upper eyelid and arching downward to cover, pass in front of and lateral to the medial canthus.
An increased amount of subcutaneous fat tissue in the face.
An abnormality of the philtrum.

Distance between the philtral ridges, measured just above the vermilion border, more than 2 standard deviations above the mean, or alternatively, an apparently increased distance between the ridges of the philtrum.
An anomaly of the forehead.
Loss of normal subcutaneous fat tissue in the face.
Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible.

Distance between the hairline (trichion) and the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose), in the midline, more than two SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between the hairline and the glabella.
A characteristic facial appearance with a round facial form, full cheeks, a short nose, and a relatively small chin.
Reduced muscle tone of a muscle that is innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
A lack of facial expression often with staring eyes and a slightly open mouth.
A face with a rounded and slightly elongated outline.
Abnormal prominence of the chin related to increased length of the mandible.
An abnormality of the chin, i.e., of the inferior portion of the face lying inferior to the lower lip and including the central prominence of the lower jaw.
A marked tapering of the lower face to the chin.
A form of developmental hypoplasia of the mandible in which the mandible is mislocalised posteriorly.

An anomaly of the midface, which is a region and not an anatomical term. It extends, superiorly, from the inferior orbital margin to, inferiorly, the level of nasal base. It is formed by the maxilla (upper jaw) and zygoma and cheeks and malar region. Traditionally, the nose and premaxilla are not included in the midface.
The facial appearance is more circular than usual as viewed from the front.
Interpupillary distance more than 2 SD above the mean (alternatively, the appearance of an increased interpupillary distance or widely spaced eyes).
Facial myokymia is a fine fibrillary activity of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
Flat skin surface, with no ridge formation in the central region of the upper lip between the nasal base and upper vermilion border.
Facial contours, as viewed from the front, show a broad upper face/cranium and lower face/mandible, creating a square appearance.

Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border.
An abnormal difference between the left and right sides of the face.
Facial contour, as viewed from the front, triangular in shape, with breadth at the temples and tapering to a narrow chin.
An abnormality of the Maxilla (upper jaw bone).

Abnormally small dimension of the Maxilla. Usually creating a malocclusion or malalignment between the upper and lower teeth or resulting in a deficient amount of projection of the base of the nose and lower midface region.
Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, occurring in the face.
Decreased vertical distance from the vermilion border of the lower lip to the inferior-most point of the chin.
Greater than average forward and/or lateral protrusion of the supraorbital portion of the frontal bones.
Width of the forehead or distance between the frontotemporales is more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or apparently increased distance between the two sides of the forehead.
A reduced degree of motion of the muscles beneath the skin of the face, often associated with reduced facial crease formation.
Coarse facial features reminiscent of those of a boxer.

Inclination of the anterior surface of the forehead from the vertical more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or apparently excessive posterior sloping of the forehead in a lateral view.
Width of the forehead or distance between the frontotemporales is more than two standard deviations below the mean (objective); or apparently narrow intertemporal region (subjective).

Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border.
An abnormality of facial morphology characterized by a small mouth opening and constant contraction of the lips as if the patient were whistling.
Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible.
An abnormally increased height of the forehead.
Frontal hairline with bilateral arcs to a low point in the midline of the forehead.
The presence of a forehead that is abnormally small.
An abnormality of the external ear.

A type of abnormal location of the ears in which the position of the ears is characterized by posterior rotation (the superior part of the ears is rotated towards the back of the head, and the inferior part of the ears towards the front).
An abnormality of the inner ear.
Tinnitus is an auditory perception that can be described as the experience of sound, in the ear or in the head, in the absence of external acoustic stimulation.
In otosclerosis, a callus of bone accumulates on the stapes creating a partial fixation. This limits the movement of the stapes bone, which results in hearing loss.
An abnormality of the lobule of pinna.
An abnormality of the sensory perception of sound.
A decreased magnitude of the sensory perception of sound.
An abnormality of the nose.
Ears that are low-set (HP:0000369) and posteriorly rotated (HP:0000358).
Upper insertion of the ear to the scalp below an imaginary horizontal line drawn between the inner canthi of the eye and extending posteriorly to the ear.
An abnormality of the middle ear.
Acute otitis media is a short and generally painful infection of the middle ear.
An abnormality of the External acoustic tube (also known as the auditory canal).
An abnormality of the cochlea.

english_term: Incomplete partition of the cochlea type II
english_description: IWith incomplete partition II, the cochlea consists of 1.5 turns; the apical and middle cochlea turns are undifferentiated and form a cystic apex. The vestibule is normal while the vestibular aqueduct is always enlarged. Developmental arrest occurs at the seventh week of gestation.
An abnormality of the pinna, which is also referred to as the auricle or external ear.
Laterally protruding ear that lacks antihelical folding (including absence of inferior and superior crura).

Stapes ankylosis refers to congenital or acquired fixation of the stapes (the stirrup-shaped small bone or ossicle in the middle ear), which is associated with conductive hearing resulting from impairment of the sound-conduction mechanism (the external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, and/or middle-ear ossicles).
A rudimentary tag of skin often containing ear tissue including a core of cartilage and located just anterior to the auricle (outer part of the ear).
Reduced volume of the earlobe.
Absence of fleshy non-cartilaginous tissue inferior to the tragus and incisura.
Inflammation or infection of the middle ear.
Chronic otitis media refers to fluid, swelling, or infection of the middle ear that does not heal and may cause permanent damage to the ear.
Increased thickness of the helix of the ear.
Anterior and inferior folding of the upper portion of the ear that obliterates triangular fossa and scapha.
The presence of an abnormally prominent antihelix.
A condition in which the helix is folded over to a greater degree than normal. That is, excessive curling of the helix edge, whereby the free edge is parallel to the plane of the ear.

chinese_term: 学语前感音神经性听力损失
english_description: A form of sensorineural deafness with either congenital onset or infantile onset, i.e., before the acquisition of speech.

Median longitudinal ear length greater than two standard deviations above the mean and median ear width greater than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparent increase in length and width of the pinna (subjective).

english_term: Stenosis of the external auditory canal
english_description: An abnormal narrowing of the external auditory canal.
Increased susceptibility to otitis media, as manifested by recurrent episodes of otitis media.
An abnormality of vibrational conductance of sound to the inner ear leading to impairment of sensory perception of sound.
A type of hearing impairment in one or both ears related to an abnormal functionality of the cochlear nerve.

chinese_term: 渐进性感音神经性听力损失
english_description: A progressive form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
A type of hearing loss resulting from a combination of conductive hearing impairment and sensorineural hearing impairment.

Angle formed by the plane of the ear and the mastoid bone greater than the 97th centile for age (objective); or, outer edge of the helix more than 2 cm from the mastoid at the point of maximum distance (objective).

english_term: Atresia of the external auditory canal
english_description: Absence or failure to form of the external auditory canal.
Increased volume and globular shape of the anteroinferior aspect of the nose.
Decreased width of the nasal ridge.
An abnormality of the nasal septum.
Reduced superior to inferior length of the nasal septum.
Epistaxis, or nosebleed, refers to a hemorrhage localized in the nose.

Abnormality of the nasal bridge, which is the saddle-shaped area that includes the nasal root and the lateral aspects of the nose. It lies between the glabella and the inferior boundary of the nasal bone, and extends laterally to the inner canthi.
Anterior positioning of the nasal root in comparison to the usual positioning for age.
An abnormality of the Ala of nose.
Thinned, deficient, or excessively arched ala nasi.
Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root).
Telangiectasia of the nasal mucosa.
Decreased distance from the nasal tip to the nasal base.
Nasal ridge curving anteriorly to an imaginary line that connects the nasal root and tip. The nose appears often also prominent, and the columella low.
Interalar distance more than two standard deviations above the mean for age, i.e., an apparently increased width of the nasal base and alae.
Decreased width of the bony bridge of the nose.
Distance between subnasale and pronasale more than two standard deviations above the mean, or alternatively, an apparently increased anterior protrusion of the nasal tip.
Abnormal narrowing of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture).
Absence or abnormal closure of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture).
Increase in width of the nasal tip.
A splitting of the nasal tip. Visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal tip.
Lack of prominence of the nose resulting from a posteriorly-placed nasal ridge.

An inability to perceive odors. This is a general term describing inability to smell arising in any part of the process of smelling from absorption of odorants into the nasal mucous overlying the olfactory epithelium, diffusion to the cilia, binding to olfactory receptor sites, generation of action potentials in olfactory neurons, and perception of a smell.
Interalar distance more than 2 SD below the mean for age, or alternatively, an apparently decreased width of the nasal base and alae.

Anteriorly-facing nostrils viewed with the head in the Frankfurt horizontal and the eyes of the observer level with the eyes of the subject. This gives the appearance of an upturned nose (upturned nasal tip).
An abnormality of the neck.

Pterygium colli is a congenital skin fold that runs along the sides of the neck down to the shoulders. It involves an ectopic fibrotic facial band superficial to the trapezius muscle. Excess hair-bearing skin is also present and extends down the cervical region well beyond the normal hairline.
Decreased strength of the neck musculature.

english_term: Increased adipose tissue around the neck
english_description: An increased amount of subcutaneous fat tissue around the neck.
Diminished length of the neck.
Dysplasia affecting the vasculature of the gastrointestinal tract.
Increased inferior-superior length of the neck.
Involuntary contractions of the neck musculature resulting in an abnormal posture of or abnormal movements of the head.

A thickening of the skin thickness in the posterior aspect of the fetal neck. A nuchal fold measurement is obtained in a transverse section of the fetal head at the level of the cavum septum pellucidum and thalami, angled posteriorly to include the cerebellum. The measurement is taken from the outer edge of the occiput bone to the outer skin limit directly in the midline. A measurement 6 mm or more is considered significant between 18 and 24 weeks and a measurement of 5 mm or more is considered significant at 16 to 18 weeks (PMID:16100637).
Increased side-to-side width of the neck.
A cystic lymphatic lesion of the neck.
Any abnormality of the eye, including location, spacing, and intraocular abnormalities.
A structural abnormality of the retina.
A notch or cleft of the retina.
Any abnormality of the cornea, which is the transparent tissue at the front of the eye that covers the iris, pupil, and anterior chamber.
A congenital abnormality of the cornea in which the cornea and the anterior segment of the eye are smaller than normal. The horizontal diameter of the cornea does not reach 10 mm even in adulthood.
A type of astigmatism associated with abnormal curvatures on the anterior and/or posterior surface of the cornea.
A form of astigmatism in which one meridian is hyperopic while the one at a right angle to it has no refractive error.
An enlargement of the cornea with normal clarity and function. Megalocornea is diagnosed with a horizontal corneal diameter of 12 mm or more at birth or 13 mm or more after two years of age.

A misalignment of the eyes so that the visual axes deviate from bifoveal fixation. The classification of strabismus may be based on a number of features including the relative position of the eyes, whether the deviation is latent or manifest, intermittent or constant, concomitant or otherwise and according to the age of onset and the relevance of any associated refractive error.

Any noninflammatory disease of the retina. This nonspecific term is retained here because of its wide use in the literature, but if possible new annotations should indicate the precise type of retinal abnormality.
An eye that is more deeply recessed into the plane of the face than is typical.
Inflammation of the cornea.
An abnormality of the eyelids.
An abnormality of the fovea centralis, the central area of the macula that mediates central, high resolution vision and contains the largest concentration of cone cells in the retina.
The palpebral fissure inclination is more than two standard deviations below the mean.
The presence of recurrent corneal epithelial erosions. Although most corneal epithelial defects heal quickly, some may show recurrent ulcerations.
An abnormality in voluntary or involuntary eye movements or their control.
Inflammation of the eyelids.
An abnormality of the eyelashes.
Glaucoma refers loss of retinal ganglion cells in a characteristic pattern of optic neuropathy usually associated with increased intraocular pressure.
An abnormality of the conjunctiva.
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the conjunctival blood vessels.
Abnormality of eyesight (visual perception).

Visual impairment (or vision impairment) is vision loss (of a person) to such a degree as to qualify as an additional support need through a significant limitation of visual capability resulting from either disease, trauma, or congenital or degenerative conditions that cannot be corrected by conventional means, such as refractive correction, medication, or surgery.
Distance between the inner canthi more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparently increased distance between the inner canthi.
The upper eyelid margin is positioned 3 mm or more lower than usual and covers the superior portion of the iris (objective); or, the upper lid margin obscures at least part of the pupil (subjective).
Inflammation of the conjunctiva.

An inherited retinal disease subtype in which the rod photoreceptors appear to be more severely affected than the cone photoreceptors. Typical presentation is with nyctalopia (due to rod dysfunction) followed by loss of mid-peripheral field of vision, which gradually extends and leaves many patients with a small central island of vision due to the preservation of macular cones.

chinese_term: 垂直性核上性凝视麻痹
english_description: A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a vertical direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal.
Any abnormality of the electrical responses of various cell types in the retina as measured by electroretinography.
An abnormally slow velocity of the saccadic eye movements.
An abnormality of the lens.
A cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the crystalline lens of the eye or in its capsule.
A cataract that occurs congenitally as the result of a developmental defect, in contrast to the majority of cataracts that occur in adulthood as the result of degenerative changes of the lens.
An eye that is protruding anterior to the plane of the face to a greater extent than is typical.
Absence of tear secretion.
A cataract that affects the region of the lens directly beneath the capsule of the lens.
The presence of small (ca. 0.5-1.0 mm) dilated blood vessels near the surface of the mucous membranes of the conjunctiva.
An abnormality of the iris, which is the pigmented muscular tissue between the cornea and the lens, that is perforated by an opening called the pupil.

Abnormality of the iris characterized by, typically bilateral, complete or partial iris hypoplasia. The phenotype ranges from mild defects of anterior iris stroma only to almost complete absence of the iris.
Mid upper eyelash length >10 mm or increased length of the eyelashes (subjective).
Absence of the globe or eyeball.
A reduction of previously attained ability to see.

chinese_term: 脉络膜视网膜形态异常
english_description: An abnormality of the choroid and retina.
Atrophy of the choroid and retinal layers of the fundus.
An abnormality of the eyebrow.
A fold of skin starting at or just below the medial aspect of the lower lid and arching upward to cover, extend in front of and lateral to the medial canthus.
Apparent optic disc swelling in the absence of increased intracranial pressure.
An abnormality in the process of focusing of light by the eye in order to produce a sharp image on the retina.
An abnormality of refraction characterized by the ability to see objects in the distance clearly, while objects nearby appear blurry.
Separation of the inner layers of the retina (neural retina) from the pigment epithelium.
Reduced ability to move the eye in the direction of the nose.
A pale yellow discoloration of the optic disk (the area of the optic nerve head in the retina). The optic disc normally has a pinkish hue with a central yellowish depression.
Paralysis of the external ocular muscles.
An abnormality of refraction characterized by the ability to see objects nearby clearly, while objects in the distance appear blurry.
A nonspecific term denoting degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium and/or retinal photoreceptor cells.
Any deviation from the normal motor coordination of the eyes that allows for bilateral fixation on a single object.
Lack of any response to stimulation upon electroretinography.
An anomaly in the ability to discriminate between or recognize colors.
Difficulty distinguishing between yellow and blue, possible related to dysfunction of the S photopigment.
An abnormality of the uvea, the vascular layer of the eyeball.
Inflammation of one or all portions of the uveal tract.
An abnormal white reflection from the pupil rather than the usual black reflection.

Retinal dystrophy is an abnormality of the retina associated with a hereditary process. Retinal dystrophies are defined by their predominantly monogenic inheritance and they are frequently associated with loss or dysfunction of photoreceptor cells as a primary or secondary event.
Diffusely large eye (with megalocornea) associated with glaucoma.
A congenital malformation of the anterior segment characterized by iridicorneal malformation, glaucoma, iris stroma hypoplasia, posterior embryotoxon, and corneal opacities.
Lack of eyelashes.
A cone-shaped deformity of the cornea characterized by the presence of corneal distortion secondary to thinning of the apex.

A developmental disorder of the lacrimal drainage system that most often affects the lacrimal ostium and resulting in non-opening of the nasolacrimal duct. It usually results from a non-canalization of the nasolacrimal duct.
A form of strabismus with one or both eyes turned inward ('crossed') to a relatively severe degree, usually defined as 10 diopters or more.
Absence of a region of the retina, retinal pigment epithelium, and choroid.
A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of one or both eyes.
An abnormality of eye movement characterized by impairment of fast (saccadic) eye movements.
Saccadic undershoot, i.e., a saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object.
Loss of visual acuity (implying that vision was better at a certain time point in life). Otherwise the term reduced visual acuity should be used (or a subclass of that).
Hemorrhage occurring within the retina.
Increased density/number and/or increased diameter of eyebrow hairs.
A regional and pathological increase of the light detection threshold in any region of the visual field surrounded by a field of normal or relatively well-preserved vision.
A scotoma (area of diminished vision within the visual field) located between the central point of fixation and the blind spot with a roughly horizontal oval shape.
A form of strabismus with one or both eyes deviated outward.
Blockage of the lacrimal duct.

An abnormality of the retina characterized by pigment deposition. It is typically associated with migration and proliferation of macrophages or retinal pigment epithelial cells into the retina; melanin from these cells causes the pigmentary changes. Pigmentary retinopathy is a common final pathway of many retinal conditions and is often associated with visual loss.
A fixed reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids with short palpebral fissures.
The palpebral fissure inclination is more than two standard deviations above the mean for age (objective); or, the inclination of the palpebral fissure is greater than typical for age.
An abnormality of the cornea characterized by the deposition of calcium in a band across the central cornea, leading to decreased vision, foreign body sensation, and ocular irritation.
Reduced depth of the orbits associated with prominent-appearing ocular globes.
Abnormality of the optic nerve.
A cleft of the optic nerve that extends inferiorly.
A developmental defect characterized by a cleft of some portion of the eye or ocular adnexa.
Initial bilateral ptosis followed by limitation of eye movements in all directions and slowing of saccades.
An abnormality of the sclera.
An abnormal bluish coloration of the sclera.
Abnormality of the anterior chamber, which is the space in the eye that is behind the cornea and in front of the iris.
Reduced depth of the anterior chamber, i.e., the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is decreased.
Ophthalmoplegia is a paralysis or weakness of one or more of the muscles that control eye movement.
An abnormality of the ear.
An anomaly in the placement or shape of the hairline (trichion) on the forehead, that is, the border between skin on the forehead that has head hair and that does not.
An anomaly of the pharynx, i.e., of the tubular structure extending from the base of the skull superiorly to the esophageal inlet inferiorly.
Interpupillary distance less than 2 SD below the mean (alternatively, the appearance of an decreased interpupillary distance or closely spaced eyes).
Paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles that are responsible for eye movements.
An area of depressed vision located at the point of fixation and that interferes with central vision.

A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a particular direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal.
A nonspecific term denoting degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium and/or retinal photoreceptor cells of the macula lutea.
Underdevelopment of the optic nerve.
Any structural abnormality of the choroid.
A coloboma of the iris.
Excessive sensitivity to light with the sensation of discomfort or pain in the eyes due to exposure to bright light.
An abnormality of the nasolacrimal drainage system, which serves as a conduit for tear flow from the external eye to the nasal cavity.
An abnormality of the pupil.
Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil.
An abnormality of eye movement characterized by impaired smooth-pursuit eye movements.
Blindness is the condition of lacking visual perception defined as visual perception below 3/60 and/or a visual field of no greater than 10 degrees in radius around central fixation.
Reduced ability to turn the eyes inward in order to focus on a nearby object.
Inflammation of the nasolacrimal sac.

An abnormal inversion (turning inward) of the eyelid (usually the lower) towards the globe. Entropion is usually acquired as a result of involutional or cicatricial processes but may occasionally be congenital.
Lack of sharpness of vision resulting in the inability to see fine detail.
A vertical gaze palsy with inability to direct the gaze of the eyes downwards.
A short discontinuity of the margin of the lower or upper eyelid.
A posterior embryotoxon is the presence of a prominent and anteriorly displaced line of Schwalbe.
Increase in periorbital soft tissue.
Abnormality of tear production.
Abnormally decreased lacrimation, that is, reduced ability to produce tears.
An impaired ability of the eye to move in the outward direction (towards the side of the head).
A markedly blue coloration of the iris.
A short discontinuity of the margin of the upper eyelid.
Distance between medial and lateral canthi is more than two standard deviations above the mean for age (objective); or, apparently increased length of the palpebral fissures.
Rhythmic, involuntary oscillations of one or both eyes related to abnormality in fixation, conjugate gaze, or vestibular mechanisms.
Nystagmus made apparent by looking to the right or to the left.

The controller signal for saccadic eye movements has two components: the pulse that moves the eye rapidly from one point to the next, and the step that holds the eye in the new position. When both the pulse and the step are not the correct size, a dysmetric refixation eye movement results.
Difficulty with discriminating red and green hues.
A focal dystonia that affects the muscles of the eyelids and brow, associated with involuntary recurrent spasm of both eyelids.
Reduced visual acuity that is uncorrectable by lenses in the absence of detectable anatomic defects in the eye or visual pathways.
A congenital anomaly in which a part or the whole of the cornea acquires the characteristics of sclera, resulting in clouding of the cornea.
Atrophy of the optic nerve. Optic atrophy results from the death of the retinal ganglion cell axons that comprise the optic nerve and manifesting as a pale optic nerve on fundoscopy.
An anomaly of visually evoked potentials (VEP), which are electrical potentials, initiated by brief visual stimuli, which are recorded from the scalp overlying the visual cortex.

english_term: Abnormal amplitude of pattern reversal visual evoked potentials
chinese_term: 图形视觉诱发电位振幅异常

english_description: Diplopia is a condition in which a single object is perceived as two images, it is also known as double vision.
A short discontinuity of the margin of the lower eyelid.
Decreased density/number of eyelashes.

english_term: Decreased light- and dark-adapted electroretinogram amplitude
chinese_term: 光和暗适应视网膜电图振幅降低
english_description: Descreased amplitude of eletrical response upon electroretinography.
An outward turning (eversion) or rotation of the eyelid margin.

Ocular motor apraxia is a deficiency in voluntary, horizontal, lateral, fast eye movements (saccades) with retention of slow pursuit movements. The inability to follow objects visually is often compensated by head movements. There may be decreased smooth pursuit, and cancellation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex.
A form of anterior segment dysgenesis in which abnormal cleavage of the anterior chamber occurs. Peters anomaly is characterized by central, paracentral, or complete corneal opacity.

A creamy appearance of the retinal blood vessels that occurs when the concentration of lipids in the blood are extremely increased, with pale pink to milky white retinal vessels and altered pale reflexes from choroidal vasculature.
Inability to see well at night or in poor light.
Meeting of the medial eyebrows in the midline.
Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements.
Atrophy of the eyeball with blindness and decreased intraocular pressure due to end-stage intraocular disease.
The absence of five or less teeth from the normal series by a failure to develop.
Caries is a multifactorial bacterial infection affecting the structure of the tooth. This term has been used to describe the presence of more than expected dental caries.
The absence of all teeth from the normal series by a failure to develop.

english_term: Macrodontia of permanent maxillary central incisor
english_description: Increased size of the maxillary central secondary incisor tooth.
The absence of six or more teeth from the normal series by a failureto develop.
Changes in alignment of teeth in the dental arch

Increased volume of dental pulp of permanent molar characterized by a crown body-root ratio equal or larger than 1:1 or an elongated pulp chambers and apical displacement of the bifurcation or trifurcation of the roots.
Delayed tooth eruption affecting the primary dentition.
An abnormality of the dental enamel.
A grey discoloration of the dental enamel.
Delayed tooth eruption, which can be defined as tooth eruption more than 2 SD beyond the mean eruption age.
Developmental hypoplasia of teeth.
Increased spaces (diastemata) between most of the teeth in the same dental arch.

Dental malocclusion refers to an abnormality of the occlusion, or alignment, of the teeth and the way the upper and lower teeth fit together, resulting in overcrowding of teeth or in abnormal bite patterns.
Agenesis of one or more maxillary lateral incisor, comprising the maxillary lateral primary incisor and maxillary lateral secondary incisor.
Decreased size of the teeth, which can be defined as a mesiodistal tooth diameter (width) more than 2 SD below mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased maximum width of tooth.
Abnormal alignment, positioning, or spacing of the teeth, i.e., misaligned teeth.

The diagnosis odontodysplasia requires clinical and radiological exams, in which unusually large pulp chambers and large pulp room chambers with thin enamel and dentin are visible. It may affect either a single tooth or several teeth. The term regional odontodysplasia is used if several teeth are affected. It affects the deciduous and permanent dentitions in the maxilla, the mandible or both, although the maxilla is more frequently involved. A type of dental dysplasia occurring in dentinogenesis imperfecta in which the pulp chambers are enlarged and there is a reduced amount of coronal dentin.
A tooth present at birth or erupting within the first month of life.
Delayed tooth eruption affecting the secondary dentition.
An abnormal conical form of the teeth, that is, a tooth whose sides converge or taper together incisally.
Increased space between two adjacent teeth in the same dental arch.
Radiolucency (reflecting a reduction in the bony substance) around the apex (the tip of the dental root).
Developmental dysplasia of dentin.
Inflammation of the periodontium.
A developmental dysplasia of the dental enamel.
A tooth which does not erupt within the teeth eruption timeline and after the loss of eruption potential.
An abnormality of the nervous system.
An abnormality of mental functioning including various affective, behavioural, cognitive and perceptual abnormalities.
A condition characterized by changes of personality and thought patterns often accompanied by hallucinations and delusional beliefs.
A tendency or compulsion to examine objects by mouth.
A state of unease characterized by diffuse motor activity or motion subject to limited control, nonproductive or disorganized behavior, and subjective distress.
Unstable emotional experiences and frequent mood changes; emotions that are easily aroused, intense, and/or out of proportion to events and circumstances.
A state of exceeding restlessness and excessive motor activity associated with mental distress or a feeling of inner tension.

Frequent feelings of being down, miserable, and/or hopeless; difficulty recovering from such moods; pessimism about the future; pervasive shame; feeling of inferior self-worth; thoughts of suicide and suicidal behavior.

Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction and communication, and by restricted and repetitive behavior. Autism begins in childhood. It is marked by the presence of markedly abnormal or impaired development in social interaction and communication and a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest. Manifestations of the disorder vary greatly depending on the developmental level and chronological age of the individual (DSM-IV).
Aggressive behavior can denote verbal aggression, physical aggression against objects, physical aggression against people, and may also include aggression towards oneself.
An exaggeration of emotional affects such as laughing crying, or yawning beyond what the person feels.
Recurrent obsessions or compulsions that are severe enough to be time consuming (i.e., they take more than 1 hour a day) or cause marked distress or significant impairment (DSM-IV).
Behavior characterized by an abnormal limitation to few interests and activities.

A loss of global cognitive ability of sufficient amount to interfere with normal social or occupational function. Dementia represents a loss of previously present cognitive abilities, generally in adults, and can affect memory, thinking, language, judgment, and behavior.

english_term: Impaired ability to form peer relationships
chinese_term: 同伴关系建立能力障碍

english_description: Persistent deficits in social interaction and communication and interaction as well as a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest as well as repetitive patterns of behavior.

english_term: Inflexible adherence to routines or rituals

english_description: A stereotypy is a repetitive, simple movement that can be voluntarily suppressed. Stereotypies are typically simple back-and-forth movements such as waving of flapping the hands or arms, and they do not involve complex sequences or movement fragments. Movement is often but not always rhythmic and may involve fingers, wrists, or more proximal portions of the upper extremity. The lower extremity is not typically involved. Stereotypies are more commonly bilateral than unilateral.
A lack of restraint manifested in several ways, including disregard for social conventions, impulsivity, and poor risk assessment.

Difficulty in social interactions related to an impairment of characteristics such as eye contact, smiling, appropriate facial expressions, and body postures and characterized by difficulty in forming peer relationships and forming friendships.
Reduced attention span characterized by distractibility and impulsivity but not necessarily satisfying the diagnostic criteria for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
A proneness to anger, i.e., a condition of being easily bothered or annoyed.
Perceptions in a conscious and awake state in the absence of external stimuli which have qualities of real perception, in that they are vivid, substantial, and located in external objective space.

Intense feelings of nervousness, tenseness, or panic, often in reaction to interpersonal stresses; worry about the negative effects of past unpleasant experiences and future negative possibilities; feeling fearful, apprehensive, or threatened by uncertainty; fears of falling apart or losing control.
Recurrent attacks of severe anxiety, whose occurence is not restricted to any particular situation or set of circumstances and is therefore unpredictable.
Primitive reflexes traditionally held to be a sign of disorders that affect the frontal lobes.

The feeling of frustration can be defined as an emotional reaction that occurs if a desired goal is not achieved. Frustration intolerance is defined as an age-inappropriate response to frustration characterized by crying or temper tantrums (in children) or aggressive or other undesirable behaviors.
A false belief that is held despite evidence to the contrary.
A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age.
An abnormal shift in patterns of thinking, acting, or feeling.
Hyperactivity is a state of constantly being unusually or abnormally active, including in situations in which it is not appropriate.
A type of anxiety disorder characterized by avoidance of public places, especially where crowds gather.
Reduced ability to use nonverbal behavior for communication, such as eye-to-eye gaze, facial expression, body posture, and gestures.

chinese_term: 周围神经系统形态异常
english_description: A structural abnormality of the peripheral nervous system, which is composed of the nerves that lead to or branch off from the central nervous system. This includes the cranial nerves (olfactory and optic nerves are technically part of the central nervous system).
A reduction in the speed at which electrical signals propagate along the axon of a neuron.
Peripheral neuropathy affecting the sensory nerves.
Progressive deterioration of peripheral axons.
Any abnormality of the thorax (the region of the body formed by the sternum, the thoracic vertebrae and the ribs).
An anomaly of the sternum, also known as the breastbone.
A defect of the chest wall characterized by a depression of the sternum, giving the chest ("pectus") a caved-in ("excavatum") appearance.
A deformity of the chest caused by overgrowth of the ribs and characterized by protrusion of the sternum.
Abnormal development of large mammary glands in males resulting in breast enlargement.
An anomaly of the rib.
Reduced rib length.
Reduced width of the chest from side to side, associated with a reduced distance from the sternal notch to the tip of the shoulder.
Any abnormality of the diaphragm, the sheet of skeletal muscle that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominal cavity.
The presence of a hernia of the diaphragm present at birth.
Abnormality of the thymus, an organ located in the upper anterior portion of the chest cavity just behind the sternum and whose main function is to provide an environment for T lymphocyte maturation.
Underdevelopment of the thymus.
Any abnormality of the scapula, also known as the shoulder blade.
The presence of calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
The presence of blood in the urine. Hematuria may be gross hematuria (visible to the naked eye) or microscopic hematuria (detected by dipstick or microscopic examination of the urine).
The presence of uric acid-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.

A type of glomerulonephritis characterized by diffuse mesangial cell proliferation and the thickening of capillary walls due to subendothelial extension of the mesangium. The term membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is often employed to denote a general pattern of glomerular injury seen in a variety of disease processes that share a common pathogenetic mechanism, rather than to describe a single disease entity
The presence of immunoglobulin A deposits in the glomerulus.
An abnormality of the urethra, i.e., of the tube which connects the urinary bladder to the outside of the body.
Obstruction of the flow of urine through the urethra.
Reduced count of spermatozoa in the semen, defined as a sperm count below 20 million per milliliter semen.
Abnormal fat accumulation in the kidneys.
Inability to develop or maintain an erection of the penis.
Cysts of the cortex of the kidney.
The presence of xanthine-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
Lack of the ability to control the urinary bladder leading to involuntary urination at an age where control of the bladder should already be possible.
A severe form of hypospadias in which the urethral opening is located at the junction of the penis and scrotum.
An anomaly of the adnexa, uterus, and vagina (in female) or seminal tract and prostate (in male).
The presence of a bicornuate uterus.

chinese_term: 高促性腺激素性性腺功能减退症
english_description: Reduced function of the gonads (testes in males or ovaries in females) associated with excess pituitary gonadotropin secretion and resulting in delayed sexual development and growth delay.
An abnormality of the tricarboxylic acid cycle.
Difficulty in looking at another person in the eye.
An abnormality of the endocrine system.
A group of abnormalities characterized by hyperglycemia and glucose intolerance.
An abnormality of the thyroid gland.
Deficiency of thyroid hormone.
The presence of chronic increased pressure in the systemic arterial system.
Passing the age when puberty normally occurs with no physical or hormonal signs of the onset of puberty.

english_term: Decreased response to growth hormone stimuation test
chinese_term: 对生长激素刺激试验的反应降低
english_description: Insufficient responses to growth hormone (GH) provocation tests. GH deficiency is defined as a serum peak GH concentration less than 10 ng/mL on provocation with a combination of at least two separate stimulation tests.
An increased concentration of insulin combined with a decreased concentration of glucose in the blood.

The onset of secondary sexual characteristics before a normal age. Although it is difficult to define normal age ranges because of the marked variation with which puberty begins in normal children, precocious puberty can be defined as the onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls or 9 years in boys.
An abnormality of the parathyroid gland.
A condition caused by a deficiency of parathyroid hormone characterized by hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.

A condition of reduced function of the anterior pituitary gland characterized by decreased secretion of one or more of the pituitary hormones growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, adrenocorticotropic hormone, prolactin, luteinizing hormone, and follicle-stimulating hormone.

A type of diabetes mellitus related not to lack of insulin but rather to lack of response to insulin on the part of the target tissues of insulin such as muscle, fat, and liver cells. This type of diabetes is typically associated with increases both in blood glucose concentrations as will as in fasting and postprandial serum insulin levels.

chinese_term: 原发性甲状腺功能减退症
english_description: A type of hypothyroidism that results from a defect in the thyroid gland.
Abnormality of the adrenal glands, i.e., of the endocrine glands located at the top of the kindneys.
Developmental hypoplasia of the adrenal glands.
An abnormality of thyroid physiology characterized by excessive secretion of the thyroid hormones thyroxine (i.e., T4) and/or 3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine zwitterion (i.e., triiodothyronine or T3).
Overproduction of gonadotropins (FSH, LH) by the anterior pituitary gland.

A type of reduced stature with normal proportions related to dysfunction of the pituitary gland related to either an isolated defect in the secretion of growth hormone or to panhypopituitarism, i.e., a deficit of all the anterior pituitary hormones.

chinese_term: 肾上腺性征异常综合征
english_description: Adrenogenital syndrome is also known as congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which results from disorders of steroid hormone production in the adrenal glands leading to a deficiency of cortisol. The pituitary gland reacts by increased secretion of corticotropin, which in turn causes the adrenal glands to overproduce certain intermediary hormones which have testosterone-like effects.

chinese_term: 肾素-血管紧张素系统亢进
english_description: An abnormally increased activity of the renin-angiotensin system, causing hypertension by a combination of volume excess and vasoconstrictor mechanisms.
An increased concentration of insulin in the blood.
Excessive production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands.

Acromegaly is a condition resulting from overproduction of growth hormone by the pituitary gland in persons with closed epiphyses, and consists chiefly in the enlargement of the distal parts of the body. The circumference of the skull increases, the nose becomes broad, the tongue becomes enlarged, the facial features become coarsened, the mandible grows excessively, and the teeth become separated. The fingers and toes grow chiefly in thickness.
Insufficient production of steroid hormones (primarily cortisol) by the adrenal glands.
An increased level of renin in the blood.

chinese_term: 先天性甲状腺功能减退症
english_description: A type of hypothyroidism with congenital onset.

chinese_term: 假性甲状旁腺功能减退症
english_description: A condition characterized by resistance to the action of parathyroid hormone, in which there is hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and (appropriately) high levels of parathyroid hormone.
An enlargement of the thyroid gland.
The presence of a adenoma of the thyroid gland.
Increased resistance towards insulin, that is, diminished effectiveness of insulin in reducing blood glucose levels.

chinese_term: 新生儿胰岛素依赖性糖尿病

english_description: Abnormally high variation in the amount of time between periods.
Overproduction of the mineralocorticoid aldosterone by the adrenal cortex.
Developmental hypoplasia of the parathyroid gland.
A form of diabetes insipidus related to a failure of vasopressin (AVP) release from the hypothalamus.

Abnormality of the pituitary gland (also known as hypophysis), which is an endocrine gland that protrudes from the bottom of the hypothalamus at the base of the brain. The pituitary gland secretes the hormones ACTH, TSH, PRL, GH, endorphins, FSH, LH, oxytocin, and antidiuretic hormone. The secretion of hormones from the anterior pituitary is under the strict control of hypothalamic hormones, and the posterior pituitary is essentially an extension of the hypothalamus, so that hypothalamus and pituitary gland may be regarded as a functional unit.

chinese_term: 甲状腺功能正常结节性甲状腺肿
继发性甲状旁腺功能亢进症
english_description: Secondary hyperparathyroidism refers to the production of higher than normal levels of parathyroid hormone in the presence of hypocalcemia.

The presence of abnormally increased levels of prolactin in the blood. Prolactin is a peptide hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland that plays a role in breast development and lactation during pregnancy.

A pituitary functional deficit affecting all the anterior pituitary hormones (growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, adrenocorticotropic hormone, and prolactin).
A chronic, autoimmune type of thyroiditis associated with hypothyroidism.

A state of excessive water intake and hypotonic (dilute) polyuria. Diabetes insipidus may be due to failure of vasopressin (AVP) release (central or neurogenic diabetes insipidus) or to a failure of the kidney to respond to AVP (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus).
Infrequent menses (less than 6 per year or more than 35 days between cycles).

chinese_term: 青春期胰岛素抵抗性糖尿病

english_description: Presence of only 11 pairs of ribs.
Decreased inferosuperior length of the sternum.
Underdeveloped scapula.
Ribs with a reduced diameter.
Increased width of ribs
Malformation of the rib cage.
Wide, concave rib end.
A horizontal (flat) conformation of the ribs, the long curved bones that form the rib cage and normally progressively oblique (slanted) from ribs 1 through 9, then less slanted through rib 12.
Any abnormality of the clavicles (collar bones).
Increased length of the clavicles.
A bifid rib refers to cleavage of the sternal end of a rib, usually unilateral. Bifid ribs are usually asymptomatic, and are often discovered incidentally by chest x-ray.
Abnormal outward curving (protuberance) of the junction of ribs and costal cartilage.
Reduced length of the clavicles.
An excessive upward convexity of the lateral clavicle.
Multiple circumscribed bony excrescences located in the ribs.
A row of beadlike prominences at the junction of a rib and its cartilage (i.e., enlarged costochondral joints), resembling a rosary.
Increased thickness (diameter) of ribs.
Complete or partial merging of adjacent ribs.
The presence of wide, concave anterior rib ends.

chinese_term: 锁骨远端进行性骨吸收
english_description: Progressive bone resorption in the distal part of the clavicle.
Wide, concave anterior rib end.

chinese_term: 宽杯状的肋软骨交界处

english_description: Abnormally flat configuration of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.

chinese_term: 先天性肩胛骨向上移位（Sprengel畸形）
english_description: A congenital skeletal deformity characterized by the elevation of one scapula (thus, one scapula is located superior to the other).
Complete or partial merging of the posterior part of adjacent ribs.
A broad chest.
Pectus excavatum (defect of the chest wall characterized by depression of the sternum) affecting primarily the inferior region of the sternum.
Increased width (cross-sectional diameter) of the clavicles.
Pectus carinatum affecting primarily the superior part of the sternum.
The presence of multiple exostoses on the scapula. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage.

Any anomaly of the costochondral junction. The costochondral junctions are located between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum.

Abnormally increased size of the costochondral junctions, which are located between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum.
A developmental anomaly with absence of one or more ribs.
Wide, concave posterior rib end.
The presence of a row of multiple rounded expansions (beadlike prominences) at the junction of a rib and its cartilage.
An abnormality of the skeletal system.
Any abnormality of the vertebral column.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance between the vertebral endplates.

The bones of the skeleton undergo a series of characteristic changes in size, shape, and calcification from fetal life until puberty. An abnormality of this process can include delayed or accelerated skeletal maturation, or deviation of some, but not all bones from the expected patterns of maturation.
An abnormality of the skull, the bony framework of the head which is comprised of eight cranial and fourteen facial bones.
An abnormality of the fossa cranii posterior (the posterior fossa), which is made up primarily of the occipital bone and which surrounds to the foramen magnum.

Radiographic evidence of articular calcification that represent calcium pyrophosphate depositions in soft tissue surrounding joints and at the insertions of tendons near joints (Entheses/Sharpey fibers) .
Abnormal thickening of the cortex of long bones.

Osteopenia is a term to define bone density that is not normal but also not as low as osteoporosis. By definition from the World Health Organization osteopenia is defined by bone densitometry as a T score -1 to -2.5.

Osteoporosis is a systemic skeletal disease characterized by low bone density and microarchitectural deterioration of bone tissue with a consequent increase in bone fragility. According to the WHO criteria, osteoporosis is defined as a BMD that lies 2.5 standard deviations or more below the average value for young healthy adults (a T-score below -2.5 SD).
An abnormality of the structure or form of the diaphysis, i.e., of the main or mid-section (shaft) of a long bone.
An abnormality of one or more metaphysis, i.e., of the somewhat wider portion of a long bone that is adjacent to the epiphyseal growth plate and grows during childhood.
Underdevelopment of the ilium.
An abnormal appearance of the long bones with resemblance to a dumbbell, a short bar with a weight at each end. That is, the long bone is shortened and displays flaring (widening) of the metaphyses.
An abnormality of the skin.
Yellow pigmentation of the skin due to bilirubin, which in turn is the result of increased bilirubin concentration in the bloodstream.
A darkening of the skin related to an increase in melanin production and deposition.
The distal and proximal transverse palmar creases are merged into a single transverse palmar crease.
A dermatosis characterized by thickened, hyperpigmented plaques, typically on the intertriginous surfaces and neck.
Cafe-au-lait spots are hyperpigmented lesions that can vary in color from light brown to dark brown with smooth borders and having a size of 1.5 cm or more in adults and 0.5 cm or more in children.
Skin characterized by the lack of natural or normal moisture.
A cutaneous indentation resulting from tethering of the skin to underlying structures (bone) of the intergluteal cleft.
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucosa due to poor circulation or inadequate oxygenation of arterial or capillary blood.

Hyperkeratosis is thickening of the outer layer of the skin, the stratum corneum, which is composed of large, polyhedral, plate-like envelopes filled with keratin which are the dead cells that have migrated up from the stratum granulosum.
Reduction in thickness of the skin, generally associated with a loss of suppleness and elasticity of the skin.

Eczema is a form of dermatitis. The term eczema is broadly applied to a range of persistent skin conditions and can be related to a number of underlying conditions. Manifestations of eczema can include dryness and recurring skin rashes with redness, skin edema, itching and dryness, crusting, flaking, blistering, cracking, oozing, or bleeding.

A reticular discoloration of the skin with cyanotic (reddish-blue appearing) areas surrounding pale central areas due to dilation of capillary blood vessels and stagnation of blood within the vessels. Cutis marmorata generally occurs on the legs, arms and trunk and is often more severe in cold weather.
Abnormally diminished capacity to sweat.

Petechiae are pinpoint-sized reddish/purple spots, resembling a rash, that appear just under the skin or a mucous membrane when capillaries have ruptured and some superficial bleeding into the skin has happened. This term refers to an abnormally increased susceptibility to developing petechiae.
Ectodermal dysplasia is a group of conditions in which there is abnormal development of the skin, hair, nails, teeth, or sweat glands.
An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body.
Inability to sweat.
Abnormal thickening of the skin localized to the palm of the hand and the sole of the foot.
Wrinkled, redundant, inelastic and sagging skin.
A condition in which the skin can be stretched beyond normal, and then returns to its initial position.
Abnormal excessive perspiration (sweating) despite the lack of appropriate stimuli like hot and humid weather.
Subjective impression of increased softness upon palpitation of the skin.

An ecchymosis (bruise) refers to the skin discoloration caused by the escape of blood into the tissues from ruptured blood vessels. This term refers to an abnormally increased susceptibility to bruising.
