english_description: A type of megaloblastic anemia that does not improve upon administration of folate. Since vitamin B12 acts by promoting recycling of folate, administration of vitamin B12 also does not improve this type of anemia.

chinese_term: 难治性贫血伴环状铁粒幼红细胞
english_description: A type of myelodysplastic syndrome characterized by less than 5% myeloblasts in the bone marrow, but with 15% or greater red cell precursors in the marrow being abnormal iron-stuffed cells called ringed sideroblasts.
Repeated episodes of obstruction of blood flow due to an embolus, i.e., blood clot that has traveled from its point of origin within the blood stream.
The presence of erythrocytes that are sphere-shaped and reduced in size.

chinese_term: 急性早幼粒细胞白血病
english_description: A type of acute myeloid leukemia in which abnormal promyelocytes predominate.
A form of severe hemolytic anemia characterized by erythrocyte morphology reminiscent of that seen in patients after a thermal burn.

chinese_term: 低色素性小红细胞性贫血
english_description: A type of anemia characterized by an abnormally low concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes and lower than normal size of the erythrocytes.

Decreased activity of coagulation factor XII. Factor XII (fXII) is part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway and binds to exposed collagen at site of vessel wall injury, activated by high-MW kininogen and kallikrein, thereby initiating the coagulation cascade.
A type of hemolytic anemia in which the Coombs test is positive.
The accumulation of transformed primitive hematopoietic blast cells, which lose their ability of normal differentiation and proliferation.
Bleeding that persists longer than the normal time following a surgical procedure.

chinese_term: Ph染色体阳性急性淋巴细胞白血病
english_description: A subset of acute lymphoblastic leukemia that results from a reciprocal translocation between the ABL-1 oncogene and a breakpoint cluster region (BCR), resulting in a fusion gene, BCR-ABL, that encodes an oncogenic protein with constitutively active tyrosine kinase activity.

chinese_term: 复发性深静脉血栓形成
english_description: Repeated episodes of the formation of a blot clot in a deep vein.

chinese_term: 叶酸反应型巨幼细胞性贫血
english_description: A type of megaloblastic anemia (i.e., anemia characterized by the presence of erythroblasts that are larger than normal) that improves upon the administration of folate.

chinese_term: 白细胞碱性磷酸酶减少
english_description: Decreased alkaline phosphatase measured within leukocytes.
Reduced platelet count that occurs sporadically, i.e., it comes and goes.
An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein S. Protein S is a cofactor of protein C.
A type of anemia characterized by an normal concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes and lower than normal size of the erythrocytes.

chinese_term: 巨核细胞缺乏性血小板减少症
english_description: Thrombocytopenia related to lack of or severe reduction in the count of megakaryocytes.

chinese_term: 硫胺素反应性巨幼细胞性贫血
english_description: A type of megaloblastic anemia (i.e., anemia characterized by the presence of erythroblasts that are larger than normal) that improves upon the administration of thiamine.

chinese_term: ADP诱导的血小板聚集障碍
english_description: Abnormal platelet response to ADP as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of ADP.
An chronic form of hemolytic anemia.
The presence of a fistula between the bowel and the perineum.
An abdominal hernia that occurs at a site of weakness in the abdominal wall resulting from an incompletely-healed surgical wound.
Pneumothorax occurring neonatally without traumatic injury to the chest or lung.
Lack of strength of the intercostal muscles, i.e., of the muscle groups running along the ribs that create and move the chest wall.
Episodic hyperventilation.

chinese_term: 呼吸衰竭，需要辅助通气
english_description: A state of respiratory distress that requires a life saving intervention in the form of gaining airway access and instituting positive pressure ventilation.

english_term: Intermittent episodes of respiratory insufficiency due to muscle weakness
chinese_term: 肌无力所致的间歇性呼吸功能不全发作

english_description: An abnormally elevated blood pressure in the circulation of the pulmonary artery.
Increased susceptibility to infections due to aspiration, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infections due to aspiration.

chinese_term: 应激/感染诱发的乳酸酸中毒
english_description: A form of lactic acidemia that occurs in relation to stress or infection.
A severe form of lactic acidemia.
A form of lactic acidemia that occurs following exercise or exertion.
A form of lactic acidemia with congenital onset.

chinese_term: 青少年发病的成人型糖尿病
english_description: The term Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) was initially used for patients diagnosed with fasting hyperglycemia that could be treated without insulin for more than two years, where the initial diagnosis was made at a young age (under 25 years). Thus, MODY combines characteristics of type 1 diabetes (young age at diagnosis) and type 2 diabetes (less insulin dependence than type 1 diabetes). The term MODY is now most often used to refer to a group of monogenic diseases with these characteristics. Here, the term is used to describe hyperglycemia diagnosed at a young age with no or minor insulin dependency, no evidence of insulin resistence, and lack of evidence of autoimmune destruction of the beta cells.
A reduced concentration of vitamin A.

chinese_term: 低钾低氯性代谢性碱中毒
碳酸氢盐流失性肾小管酸中毒

english_description: Repeated transient episodes of metabolic acidosis, that is, of the buildup of acid or depletion of base due to accumulation of metabolic acids.
An intermittent (discontinuous) form of lactic acidemia.

chinese_term: 婴儿反复发作性低血糖
english_description: Recurrent episodes of decreased concentration of glucose in the blood occurring during the infantile period.
An impairment of galactose metabolism.
A form of metabolic acidosis with increased serum chloride levels.
An increased concentration of L-phenylalanine in the blood.
An abnormal resistance to glucose, i.e., a reduction in the ability to maintain glucose levels in the blood stream within normal limits following oral administration of glucose.
A chronic form of lactic acidemia.

english_term: Orthostatic hypotension due to autonomic dysfunction
chinese_term: 自主神经功能障碍性体位性低血压

english_description: An abnormal widening of the diameter of the pulmonary artery.
Arteriosclerosis (increased thickness, increased stiffness, loss of elasticity) of the small arteries of the brain.

A separation of the layers within the wall of the ascending aorta. Tears in the intimal layer result in the propagation of dissection (proximally or distally) secondary to blood entering the intima-media space.
Abnormal calcification of the vasculature.
A congenital anomaly with a narrowing or complete absence of the opening between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery.
Formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a vein, causing the obstruction of blood flow.
An aneurysm (severe localized balloon-like outward bulging) in the pulmonary artery.
Excessive bending, twisting, and winding of a cerebral artery.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts, affecting arteries distributed throughout the body.

Aortic dilatation refers to a dimension that is greater than the 95th percentile for the normal person age, sex and body size. In contrast, an aneurysm is defined as a localized dilation of the aorta that is more than 150 percent of predicted (ratio of observed to expected diameter 1.5 or more). Aneurysm should be distinguished from ectasia, which represents a diffuse dilation of the aorta less than 50 percent of normal aorta diameter.

Atherosclerosis which occurs in a person with certain risk factors (e.g., SLE, diabetes, smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, family history of early heart disease) at an earlier age than would occur in another person without those risk factors.
The presence of a localized dilatation or ballooning of a cerebral artery.
An abnormal connection between an artery and vein.
Abnormal twisting of arteries or veins.

Narrowing of peripheral arteries with reduction of blood flow to the limbs. This feature may be quantified as an ankle-brachial index of less than 0.9, and may be manifested clinically as claudication.
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of arteries affecting most or all arteries.
An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the descending thoracic aorta.
A congenital defect with aplasia (absence) of one of the right or left pulmonary artery.
An anomalous origin of the left pulmonary artery, such that it arises from the posterior aspect of the right pulmonary artery and passes between the trachea and esophagus to reach the left hilum.
An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in the thoracic aorta.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the aorta.
Increase in mass of the tunica media of the arteries in the pulmonary circulation.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the tunica media of large (conduit) arteries.
Recurrent bleeding into the parenchyma of the brain.
Stenosis of a peripheral branch of the pulmonary artery.
An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the tubular part of the ascending aorta.
Underdevelopment of the pulmonary artery.
An abnormal increase in the average blood pressure in an individual during a single cardiac cycle.

english_term: Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the femurs
english_description: Flaring of distal femur.
Missing radius bone on both sides associated with congenital failure of development.
Abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.
Reduction in density of metaphyseal bony tissue.
Shortening of the middle parts of the leg in relation to the upper and terminal segments.
Disproportionate shortening of the proximal segment of the arm (i.e. the humerus).

english_term: Slender long bones with narrow diaphyses
english_description: Reduced diameter of a long bone with a more pronounced reduction of the diameter of the diaphysis of the long bones.

english_term: Multicentric ossification of proximal humeral epiphyses
chinese_term: 肱骨近端骨骺多中心骨化

english_description: Patellar dislocation occurring repeated times.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the capital femoral epiphysis
chinese_term: 股骨头骨骺发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the proximal epiphysis of the femur.

english_term: Femoral bowing present at birth, straightening with time
chinese_term: 出生时股骨有弯曲，随年龄增长而变直
english_description: Congenital onset bending or abnormal curvature of the femur that normalizes with age.

english_term: Osteomyelitis leading to amputation due to slow healing fractures
chinese_term: 因骨折愈合缓慢导致截肢的骨髓炎

english_description: Shortening of the middle parts of the arm in relation to the upper and terminal segments.

chinese_term: 多关节软骨钙质沉着病

english_description: Underdevelopment of the distal portion of the humerus.
Underdevelopment of the distal portion of the ulna.

english_term: Shortening of all phalanges of the toes
english_description: Developmental hypoplasia (shortening) of all phalanges of the foot.
An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the proximal portions of the radius and the ulna.
Multiple exostoses originating in long bones.
Irregular surface of the normally relatively smooth capital femoral epiphysis.

chinese_term: 不规则佝偻病样干骺端

english_description: An elevation in bone density of the cortex of one or more diaphyses. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an anterolateral direction.
Bony outgrowths that extend laterally from the margin of the metaphysis.

english_term: Cone-shaped epiphyses fused within their metaphyses
chinese_term: 干骺端融合的锥形骨骺

english_description: Overgrowth of the proximal part of the fibula.
The ability of the wrist joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an anterior direction.
A limited ability of the knee joint to perform extension and flexion.
An abnormality of the pattern of trabecula (small interconnecting rods of bone) in a metaphyseal region of bone.
A lateral bending or abnormal curvature of the femur.
The presence of streaks (bands) of abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.
A bending or abnormal curvature of the distal portion of the femur.

english_term: Premature birth following premature rupture of fetal membranes
chinese_term: 胎膜早破引起的胎儿早产

english_description: A type of hearing impairment affecting primarily the higher frequencies of sound (3,000 to 6,000 Hz).
Deterioration or loss of the tissues of the cochlea.
Ossification affecting the external ear cartilage.
Underdevelopment of the nasal septum.
Any abnormality of the vertebral end plates, which are the top and bottom portions of the vertebral bodies that interface with the vertebral discs.
An abnormality of the sacral bone.
An abnormality of the intervertebral disk.
An abnormality of the Achilles tendon.

An atrial arrhythmia characterized by disorganized atrial activity without discrete P waves on the surface EKG, but instead by an undulating baseline or more sharply circumscribed atrial deflections of varying amplitude an frequency ranging from 350 to 600 per minute.
An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the abdominal aorta.
An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the aortic arch.
A type of arrhythmia that originates above the ventricles, whereby the electrical impulse propagates down the normal His Purkinje system similar to normal sinus rhythm.
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of arteries.
Abnormal increase in diastolic blood pressure.
An excessive concavity of the posterior surface of one or more vertebral bodies.
Compression of the heart caused by rigid, thickened, or fused pericardial membranes.
Enlargement of the chamber of the right ventricle.
Refers to the specific combination of defects with a severely dysplastic pulmonary valve and massively dilated branch pulmonary arteries.
An abnormality of the T wave on the electrocardiogram, which mainly represents the repolarization of the ventricles.
Mitral annular calcification (MAC) results from progressive calcium deposition along and beneath the mitral valve annulus.
The dividing wall between left and right sides of the heart, thickens and bulges into the left ventricle.
Abnormal narrowing of the coronary artery.
Any defect in the valve connecting the heart and the pulmonary artery.
An impairment of the electrical continuity between the atria and ventricles.
Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized proximal to the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the preductal region of aortic arch.
A type of cardiomyopathy characterized pathologically by hamartomatous lesions of cardiac Purkinje cells.

A ventircular escape rhythm occurs whenever higher-lever pacemakers in AV junction or sinus node fail to control ventricular activation. Escape rate is usually 20-40 bpm, often associated with broad QRS complexes (at least 120 ms).
Underdeveloped, small left heart atrium
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with an symmetrical and concentric pattern of hypertrophy.

chinese_term: 完全性肺静脉回流异常
english_description: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return refers to a congenital malformation in which all four pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium, but instead drain abnormally to the right atrium.

Inability of the left ventricle to perform its normal physiologic function. Failure is either due to an inability to contract the left ventricle or the inability to relax completely and fill with blood during diastole.
A congenital malformation of the pulmonary valve characterized by leaflet deformation.
Reduced time for the PR interval (beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex). In adults, normal values are 120 to 200 ms long.
An abnormal increase in magnitude of the pressure in the right atrium.

english_term: Complete heart block with broad QRS complexes
chinese_term: 完全性心脏传导阻滞伴宽QRS波群
english_description: A type of third degree heart block in which the escape rhythm arises at a relatively low part of the conduction system (below the atrioventricular node), which produces a wide QRS complex.
Conduction block in the posterior division of the left bundle branch of the bundle of His.
A congenital malformation of the aortic valve characterized by leaflet deformation.
Arteriosclerosis occurring at an age that is younger than usual.
Failure of the tricuspid valve to close sufficiently upon contraction of the right ventricle, causing blood to regurgitate (flow backward) into the right atrium.
Reduction of the diameter of the coronary arteries as the result of an accumulation of atheromatous plaques within the walls of the coronary arteries before age of 45.
The presence of a bicuspid pulmonary valve.
An abnormal dilatation of lymph vessels in the pericardium.

A longer than normal interval (corrected for heart rate) between the Q and T waves in the heart's cycle. Prolonged QTc can cause premature action potentials during late phase depolarizations thereby leading to ventricular arrhythmias and ventricular fibrillations.
Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metatarsal bones.
A sensation of stiffness in the joints that occurs following waking up in the morning.
Interphalangeal joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in the interphalangeal joints when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity.

english_term: Aplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
english_description: Absence of the abdominal musculature.
A recurrent infection of the GI tract with helicobacter pylori, a gram-negative, microaerophilic bacterium usually found in the stomach.
The occurrence of the full-thickness tear (perforation) of the wall of the esophagus.
Cyst-like space not lined by epithelium and contained within the pancreas. Pancreatic pseudocysts are often associated with pancreatitis.
Watery voluminous diarrhea resulting from an imbalance between ion and water secretion and absorption.
The presence of cyst of the intrahepatic bile duct.

Leukoplakia is a precancerous dermatosis of mucous membranes analogous Leukoplakia is basically a chronic inflammatory hypertrophy in which anaplasia and malignant dyskeratosis may develop and subsequently advance to an invasive squamous cell cancer. The clinical diagnosis of primary anal leukoplakia is indicated by single or multiple slightly raised,irregular, marginated, grayish-white keratinized' patches in the anal canal. Tissue biopsy is necessary for confirmation.
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition lesions in the pancreas.
Blockage or impairment of the normal flow of the contents of the intestine towards the anal canal.

chinese_term: 频繁蓝氏贾第鞭毛虫感染
english_description: Increased susceptibility to Giardia lamblia infection of the intestine, as manifested by a medical history of multiple episodes of Giardia lamblia intestinal infection.
An abnormal reduction in the ability to masticate (chew), i.e., in the ability to crush and ground food in preparation for swallowing.
The presence of a fistula (abnormal tunnel) between the anal canal and the perineum.
Absence of gastric intrinsic factor, which is normally produced by the parietal cells of the stomach, and is required for the absorption of vitamin B12.
The presence of multiple diverticula of the intestine.
A collection of pus in the area of the rectum.
Accumulation of cell free, noninflammatony fluid within the wall of the intestinal tract producing uniform thickening of the mucosal folds.
Presence of multiple adenomatous polyps in the colon.
Obstruction affecting the biliary tree.
A chronic form of gastritis.
A developmental defect resulting in abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the jejunum.
A form of chronic pancreatitis that is characterized by calcification.
Atresia in the extrahepatic bile duct.
Failure to form of portions of the abdominal musculature.
Developmental hypoplasia of the intestine.

english_term: Hypoplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
english_description: Underdevelopment of the abdominal musculature.
Atresia in the intrahepatic bile duct.
Aplasia (congenital absence) of the pectoralis minor.

chinese_term: 胸肌发育不全/发育不良

english_term: Abnormal facility in opposing the shoulders

english_description: Hemorrhage occurring within a joint.
The presence of inflammation of the gastric mucous membrane.
An abnormality of the gallbladder.
A discrete abnormal tissue mass that protrudes into the lumen of the intestine and is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or a broad base.

english_term: Premature delivery because of cervical insufficiency or membrane fragility
chinese_term: 宫颈机能不全或胎膜脆性原因导致的早产

english_description: A pregnancy that ends at a stage in which the fetus is incapable of surviving on its own, defined as the spontaneous loss of a fetus before the 20th week of pregnancy.

Exaggerated bulkiness of the crease or fold of skin running from the lateral margin of the nose, where nasal base meets the skin of the face, to a point just lateral to the corner of the mouth (cheilion, or commissure).
Lack of the cartilage of the nasal septum.
Posterior positioning of the nasal root in relation to the overall facial profile for age.
Abnormality of the nostril.

english_term: Intimal thickening in the coronary arteries

english_description: A separation (dissection) of the layers of an artery.
Peripheral arterial stenosis with onset before the age of 50 years.
A rare congenital vascular anomaly that results when the left superior cardinal vein caudal to the innominate vein fails to regress.
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the carotid arteries.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the arch of aorta.
Formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a cerebral vein, causing the obstruction of blood flow.
The presence of a capillary hemangioma, which are hemangiomas with small endothelial spaces.

chinese_term: 体位性低血压伴代偿性心动过速

english_description: A type of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessel walls) affecting large arteries such as the aorta and branches of the aorta.
A developmental defect characterized by the lack of formation of the pulmonary blood vessels.
Formation of excess fibrous connective tissue in the tunica intima (innermost layer) of arteries in the pulmonary circulation.

chinese_term: 纤维肌性动脉发育不良
english_description: An arterial lesion that is characterized by either intimal fibroplasia, with neointimal lesions of cells and matrix deposition, or medial fibroplasia, in which there is loss of smooth muscle cells and increased deposition of collagen and proteoglycans in the medial layer.
Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) more than 3 wood units, as defined by the current definition of pulmonary hypertension. 95% of individuals have a PVR of less than 2.4 wood units.
Inflammation of the blood vessels within the brain.

A type of craniofacial dysostosis associated with abnormalities of the external ears, mirognathia, macrostomia, coloboma of the lower eyelid, and cleft palate. This is a bundled term that is left in the HPO now for convenience with legacy annotations but should not be used for new annotations.
An abnormality of the gestures or movements executed with the facial muscles with which emotions such as fear, joy, sadness, surprise, and disgust can be expressed.

english_term: Extension of hair growth on temples to lateral eyebrow
english_description: A pattern of hair growth in which there is hair extending from the temples to the lateral eyebrows.
Underdevelopment of the philtrum.
A degree of wrinkling of the facial skin that is more than expected for the age of the individual, leading to a prematurely aged appearance.
Recurrent partial dislocations of the mandible.
Decreased density/number and/or decreased diameter of lateral eyebrow hairs.
An abnormality of the complement system.
Abnormal bladder function (increased urge or frequency of urination or urge incontinence) resulting from abnormal functioning of the autonomic nervous system.
Underdevelopment of the urinary bladder.
Any structural abnormality of the carotid arteries, including the common carotid artery and its' arterial branches.
An abnormality of the structure of the veins that return deoxygenated blood from the body into the heart, i.e., the superior vena cava and the inferior vena cava.
Inspiratory stridor is a high pitched sound upon inspiration that is generally related to laryngeal abnormalities.
Hypoplasia of the epiglottis.
A primary immune deficiency that is characterized by defects or deficiencies of T-lymphocytes that causes specific susceptibility to intracellular micro-organisms.
Increased susceptibility to herpesvirus, as manifested by recurrent episodes of herpesvirus.
Complete inability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity.
A reduced level of the complement component Factor I in circulation.

Reduced functionality of the process in which a precursor cell type acquires the specialized features of a B cell. A B cell is a lymphocyte of B lineage with the phenotype CD19-positive and capable of B cell mediated immunity.
Absence of the thymus. This feature may be appreciated by the lack of a thymic shadow upon radiographic examination.
Increased susceptibility to chicken pox, as manifested by recurrent episodes of chicken pox.
A general term referring to a defect in immunity resulting from impaired antibody production.
A severe form of B lymphocytopenia in which the count of B cells is very low or absent.

chinese_term: 复发性链球菌感染肺炎
english_description: Increased susceptibility to streptococcus pneumoniae infections as manifested by a history of recurrent infections by streptococcus pneumoniae.
An abnormality of the humoral immune system, which comprises antibodies produced by B cells as well as the complement system.
A reduced level of the complement component Factor H in circulation.
An abnormality of the physiological functioning of B cells.
An immunodeficiency characterized by defective cell-mediated immunity or humoral immunity.

chinese_term: 反复流感嗜血杆菌感染
english_description: Increased susceptibility to Haemophilus influenzae infections as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by Haemophilus influenzae.
Recurrent infections by Neisseria meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis), which is also known as meningococcus.
A reduced ability of a B cell to become activated, i.e., the change in morphology and behavior of
Increased susceptibility to protozoan infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of protozoan infection.

A group of phenotypically heterogeneous genetic disorders characterized by profound deficiencies of T- and B-cell function, which predispose the patients to both infectious and noninfectious complications.

english_term: Depletion of components of the alternative complement pathway
chinese_term: 补体旁路途径组分消耗
english_description: An abnormal reduction in the components of the alternative complement pathway, such as the C3 protein or its cleavage products.

Increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by opportunistic agents, i.e., by microorganisms that do not usually cause disease in a healthy host, but are able to infect a host with a compromised immune system.

chinese_term: 中性粒细胞运动性能减低
english_description: An abnormal reduction of the cell motility of neutrophils.
An increased susceptibility to candida infections, as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of candida infections.
An abnormally low count of T cells.
An abnormal increase from the normal count of B cells.

chinese_term: 复发性细菌性皮肤感染
english_description: Increased susceptibility to bacterial infections of the skin, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infectious dermatitis.

english_term: Decreased proportion of CD4-positive helper T cells
chinese_term: CD4+辅助 T 细胞比例减低
english_description: A decreased proportion of circulating CD4-positive helper T cells relative to total T cell count.

An abnormally increased level of circulationg alpha-globulin. Alpha globulins are a group of serum proteins defined by their mobility on serum electrophoresis. The alpha1-protein fraction is comprised of alpha1-antitrypsin, thyroid-binding globulin, and transcortin. Ceruloplasmin, alpha2-macroglobulin, and haptoglobin contribute to the alpha2-protein band. The alpha2 component is increased as an acute-phase reactant.

english_term: Decreased proportion of CD8-positive T cells
english_description: A decreased proportion of circulating CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells relative to total number of T cells.
A reduced level of the complement component factor B in circulation.
Decreased or impaired activation of T cells in response to a mitogen, cytokine, chemokine, cellular ligand, or an antigen for which it is specific.

chinese_term: 反复革兰氏阴性菌感染
english_description: Increased susceptibility to infection by gram-negative bacteria, as manifested by a medical history of repeated or frequent infections by these agents.
A reduced level of the complement component C3 in circulation.
Lack of detectible CD8-positive T cells

chinese_term: 补体旁路途径功能失调
english_description: An abnormality of the functioning of any aspect of the alternative complement pathway.
Absence of specific immunoglobulins directed against a specific antigen or microorganism.
An increased susceptibility to infections involving both the paranasal sinuses and the lungs, as manifested by a history of recurrent sinopulmonary infections.
Increased susceptibility to systemic pyogenic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of systemic pyogenic infections.
Recurrent infections by bacteria of the genus Neisseria, including N. meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis).
Abnormally reduced ability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity.

english_term: Recurrent infections in infancy and early childhood
chinese_term: 婴儿和幼儿期反复感染
english_description: Recurrent infections at an early age with improvement in later childhood.
Hypoplasia of the maxillozygomatic complex.
An increased density in the cranial sutures following obliteration.
The presence of a coronal suture (the cranial suture that separates the frontal and parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
Abnormal increased size of the posterior cranial fossa.

Abnormally flat (obtuse) angle of the mandible. The angle of the mandibular, located at the junction between the body and the ramus of the mandible, is normally close to being a right angle. This terms describes an abnormal increase of this angle such that the mandible appears flatter than normal.
An increase in bone density affecting the calvaria (roof of the skull).
Aplasia or hypoplasia of the paranasal sinuses.

Normally, the posterior and lateral fontanelles are obliterated by about six months after birth, the anterior fontanelle closes by about the middle of the second year. This term refers to the situation in which the fontanelles close at an inappropriately early time point.
The presence of calcium deposition in the falx cerebri.
Abnormally increased density of craniofacial bone tissue.
Excessive growth (overgrowth) of the facial bones, that is of the facial skeleton.
Underdevelopment of the frontal bone.
Reduced convexity of the occiput (posterior part of skull).
Bony fusion of malleus, incus, and stapes.
Abnormal reduction in ossification of the calvaria (roof of the skull consisting of the frontal bone, parietal bones, temporal bones, and occipital bone).
The presence of a sagittal suture (the cranial suture that separates the left and right parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
Progressively increasing bone density of the skull base without significant changes in bony contour.
An abnormally decreased level of immunoglobulin E (IgE) in blood.
An abnormality of the epiglottis.
Head circumference which falls below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender because of insufficient head growth after birth.
Vertical bony ridge positioned in the midline of the forehead.
The postnatal development of an abnormally large skull (macrocephaly).

english_term: Metopic suture patent to nasal root
english_description: The frontal suture divides the two halves of the frontal bone in infants and usually fuses by the age of six years. The suture runs from the bregma (the point on the skull at which the coronal suture is intersected perpendicularly by the sagittal suture) to the nasion or nasal root. This term applies if the suture is widely patent from bregma to nasal root.

english_term: Midline skin dimples over anterior/posterior fontanelles
chinese_term: 前/后囟门中线皮肤凹陷

english_description: A myeloproliferative disorder characterized by increased proliferation of the granulocytic cell line without the loss of their capacity to differentiate.
Presence of a monoclonal immunoglobulin M protein in the serum.
Anemia characterized by abnormal intracellular inclusions, composed of denatured hemoglobin, found on the membrane of red blood cells.
Increased megakaryocyte number, i.e., of platelet precursor cells, present in the bone marrow.
Larger than normal size of erythrocytes.

Disseminated intravascular coagulation is characterized by the widespread activation of coagulation, which results in the intravascular formation of fibrin and ultimately thrombotic occlusion of small and midsize vessels.

chinese_term: 吡哆醇反应性铁粒幼细胞性贫血
english_description: A type of sideroblastic anemia that is alleviated by pyridoxine (vitamin B-6) treatment.
A reduced number of hematopoietic cells present in the bone marrow relative to marrow fat.

chinese_term: 大细胞性红细胞生成异常性贫血

english_description: A form of hemolytic anemia that can be triggered by exertion.
Average platelet volume below the lower limit of the normal reference interval.
Congenital onset of a marked decrease in the number of granulocytes.
An abnormal prolongation (delay) in the time required by whole blood to produce a visible clot.

An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein C. Protein C is activated to protein Ca by thrombin bound to thrombomodulin. Activated protein C degrades factors VIIIa and Va.
Proliferation (excess production) of hemopoietically active tissue or of tissue which has embryonic hemopoietic potential.
A reduced count of megakaryocytes.

A chronic lymphocytic/lymphatic/lymphoblastic leukemia (CLL) is a neoplastic disease characterized by proliferation and accumulation (blood, marrow and lymphoid organs) of morphologically mature but immunologically dysfunctional lymphocytes. A CLL is always a B-cell lymphocytic leukemia as there are no reports of cases of T-cell lymphocytic leukemias.

A slowly progressing leukemia characterized by a clonal (malignant) proliferation of maturing and mature myeloid cells or mature lymphocytes. When the clonal cellular population is composed of myeloid cells, the process is called chronic myelogenous leukemia. When the clonal cellular population is composed of lymphocytes, it is classified as chronic lymphocytic leukemia, hairy cell leukemia, or T-cell large granular lymphocyte leukemia.

english_term: Abnormality of bone marrow cell morphology
english_description: An anomaly of the form or number of cells in the bone marrow.
The presence of many cysts in the kidney.
A reduction in the count of nephrons per kidney.
A lack of differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging.
Reduced differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging.
High urine magnesium in the presence of hypomagnesemia.

chinese_term: 非酸中毒性近端肾小管病
english_description: A type of proximal renal tubulopathy characterized by resorption defects leading to glycosuria, aminoaciduria, tubular proteinuria, renal hypophosphatemia, and urate tubular hyporeabsorption without bicarbonate loss.

A thrombotic microangiopathy with presence of non-immune, intravascular hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and acute kidney injury. A vicious cycle of complement activation, endothelial cell damage, platelet activation, and thrombosis is the hallmark of the disease.

A progressive detrimental connective tissue deposition (fibrosis) on the kidney parenchyma involving the tubules and interstitial tissue of the kidney. Tubulointerstitial injury in the kidney is complex, involving a number of independent and overlapping cellular and molecular pathways, with renal interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy (IF/TA) as the final common pathway. However, IF and TA are separable, as shown by the profound TA in renal artery stenosis, which characteristically has little or no fibrosis (or inflammation). For new annotations it is preferable to annotate to the specific HPO terms for Renal interstitial lfibrosis and/or Renal tubular atrophy.
Any impairment of reabsorption of chloride by the kidney in order to not lose too much chloride in the urine.
A duplication of the renal pelvis.
DIsruption and breaking up of the basement membrane of the tubules of the kidney.
A type of carcinoma of the kidney with origin in the epithelium of the proximal convoluted renal tubule.
A focal type of palmoplantar keratoderma in which only certain areas of the palms and soles are affected.

chinese_term: 黑素细胞中巨大黑素小体
english_description: The presence of large spherical melanosomes (1 to 6 micrometer in diameter) in the cytoplasm of melanocytes.
Loss of all scalp hair with congenital onset.

english_term: Facial telangiectasia in butterfly midface distribution
chinese_term: 面部毛细血管蝶状扩张
english_description: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin in a butterfly midface distribution.
The giant congenital nevus is greater than 8 cm in size, pigmented and often hairy. A giant congenital nevus is smaller in infants and children, but it usually continues to grow with the child.

english_term: Large cafe-au-lait macules with irregular margins
chinese_term: 边缘不规则的较大咖啡牛奶斑
english_description: Large hypermelanotic macules with jagged borders.

chinese_term: 气管支气管系统形态异常

english_description: The presence of a bilobed gallbladder, related to a duplication of the gallbladder primordium.

chinese_term: 股骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the femur.

An abnormally increased rate of skeletal maturation. Accelerated skeletal maturation can be diagnosed on the basis of an estimation of the bone age from radiographs of specific bones in the human body.
Hyperconvexity of the thoracolumbar spine producing a rounded or humped appearance.
The ability of the interphalangeal joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
Increased cross-section (diameter) of the long bones. Note that widening may primarily affect specific regions of long bones (e.g., diaphysis or metaphysis), but this should be coded separately.
Absent ossification of the calvaria (vault of the skull).
Osteoporosis affecting predominantly the vertebrae.
This type of brachydactyly is characterized by short and broad terminal phalanges of the thumbs and big toes.
The ability of the joints of the hand to move beyond their normal range of motion.
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the third toe.
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition of the intervertebral disk.

chinese_term: 第二-五指之间的皮性并指畸形
english_description: A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the second to the fifth fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints.
Sclerosis (abnormal hardening) of cortical bone, characterized by increased radiodensity.
Multiple exostoses originating in the fingers and toes.
A foot deformity resulting due to an abnormality affecting the muscle and soft tissue. In contrast if the bones of the foot are affected the term structural foot deformity applies.
Osteomyelitis caused by infection with the bacteria, salmonella.

chinese_term: 游离齿状突(齿状突小骨)
english_description: Separation of the odontoid process from the body of the axis.
Deposition of calcium salts on both sides of the brain.
An abnormality of the hand resulting from contracture of the palmar fascia with a fixed flexion deformity of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.

An inherited primary limb malformation disorder characterized by congenital contractures of two or more different body areas and without primary neurologic and/or muscle disease that affects limb function.
Patchy (irregular) increase in bone density. This can take on many forms depending on severity and distribution as can be seen on x-rays.

english_term: Dysplastic distal thumb phalanges with a central hole
chinese_term: 伴有中心孔的远端拇指指骨发育不良

english_description: Increased mobility and flexibility in the joint due to the tension in tissues such as ligaments and muscles.
Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand with a complete extra finger and extra metacarpal.

english_term: Increased bone density with cystic changes

english_description: A bilateral form of triphalangeal thumb.

chinese_term: 第二、三脚趾皮肤性并趾

english_description: Abnormal reduction in length of all metacarpal bones.
The ability of the thumb joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
An abnormal irregularity of cortical bone.

english_term: Spinal stenosis with reduced interpedicular distance
chinese_term: 椎管狭窄伴椎弓根间距缩短
english_description: An abnormal narrowing of the spinal canal related to a reduction in the interpedicular distance (i.e., the distance measured between the pedicles on frontal [coronal] imaging).
Underdevelopment (reduced size) of the tibia.

english_term: Avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis
chinese_term: 股骨头骨骺缺血性坏死
english_description: Avascular necrosis of the proximal epiphysis of the femur occurring in growing children and caused by an interruption of the blood supply to the head of the femur close to the hip joint. The necrosis is characteristically associated with flattening of the femoral head, for which reason the term coxa plana has been used to refer to this feature in the medical literature.

english_term: Osteosclerosis of the base of the skull
english_description: An increase in bone density affecting the basicranium (base of the skull).

english_term: Contractures of the joints of the lower limbs

english_description: The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more epiphyses during the neonatal period.
Abnormal elevation of the floor of the posterior fossa including occipital condyles and foramen magnum.
A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the toes 2, 3, and 4.
Bending or curvature of the distal phalanx of little finger in the radial direction (i.e., towards the 4th finger).

chinese_term: 胫骨发育不全或发育低下
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the tibia.

english_term: Absent fourth finger distal interphalangeal crease
chinese_term: 第四指远端指节间褶痕缺失
english_description: Absence of the distal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fourth finger.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance beween the vertebral endplates affecting the lumbar spine.
An abnormal increase of bone mineral density with generalized involvement of the skeleton.

english_term: Cortical thickening of long bone diaphyses
english_description: Abnormal thickening of the cortex of the diaphyseal region of long bones.
Underdevelopment of the humerus.

english_term: Shortening of all distal phalanges of the toes
chinese_term: 全部脚趾远节趾骨缩短
english_description: Abnormally short distal phalanx of toe of all toes.
Aplasia (absence) of the distal phalanges.
The presence of more than 12 rib pairs.
Combined syndactyly and polydactyly of the foot on the lateral side (i.e., on the side of the little toe).
Short (hypoplastic) middle phalanx of finger, affecting one or more fingers.
Bending or curvature of a second toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).
One or more bent (flexed) toe joints that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
A type of dysharmonic skeletal maturation in which there is a delay in skeletal maturation whose degree differs markedly in different bones.

english_term: Calcific stippling of infantile cartilaginous skeleton
chinese_term: 婴儿软骨骨骼点状钙化

english_description: The presence of bone fractures in the prenatal period that are diagnosed at birth or before.
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an ulnar direction.
In type E brachydactyly, shortening of the fingers is mainly in the metacarpals and metatarsals.

A pathologic entity characterized by a developmental defect in a long bone leading to bending and pathologic fracture, with inability to form a normal bony callus with subsequent fibrous nonunion, leading to the pseudarthrosis (or "false joint").
A form of triphalangeal thumb that can be placed opposite the fingers of the same hand.

An enchondroma is a benign growth of cartilage that develops within the medullary cavity of bone. Enchondromatosis refers to the presence of multiple enchondromas, and this term refers to the presence of multiple enchondromas within the medulla of metaphyseal bone. Radiographically an enchondroma presents a an oval, linear, or pyramidal osteolytic (radiolucent) lesion with well defined margins.
An abnormality of skeletal development characterized by a disturbance of the metaphysis and its histological structure with relatively normal epiphyses and vertebrae.
Disproportionately short middle and distal phalanges compared to the hand/foot.
Combined syndactyly and polydactyly of the great toe.
Progressively worsening joint contractures.
Multiple bent (flexed) finger joints that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
Fusion of a metacarpal bone with the proximal phalanx of the finger distal to it across the corresponding metacarpophalangeal joint.
Absence of a digit or of one or more phalanges of a finger.
Bony overgrowth of the internal (endosteal) surface of the calvaria and the base of skull.

english_term: Radial deviation of thumb terminal phalanx
chinese_term: 拇指末节指骨径向偏移
严重全身性骨质疏松症
english_description: Severe degree of osteoporosis.
Presence of an angular or V -shaped indentation on the ulnar side of the fifth metacarpal bone (i.e., on the sides towards the fifth finger).
The presence of an abnormal curvature of the cervical vertebral column.

english_term: Delayed pneumatization of the mastoid process
english_description: An abnormally reduced degree of pneumatization (i.e., formation of air cells) in the mastoid process with respect to age-dependent norms.
Atresia of the biliary tree.

chinese_term: 掌骨发育不全或发育低下
english_description: Aplasia or Hypoplasia affecting the metacarpal bones.
Irregularly shaped metacarpal bones of varying degree.
The presence of more than the normal number of metacarpal bones.

english_term: Abnormal epiphysis morphology of the phalanges of the hand
english_description: Abnormality of one or all of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand. Note that this includes the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal. In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits).
Any structural anomaly of the hand.

english_term: Abnormalities of the metaphyses of the hand

english_description: An anomaly of epiphysis, which is the expanded articular end of a long bone that developes from a secondary ossification center, and which during the period of growth is either entirely cartilaginous or is separated from the shaft by a cartilaginous disk.

An abnormality of corticomedullary differentiation (CMD) on diagnostic imaging such as magnetic resonance imaging, computer tomography, or sonography. CMD is a difference in the visualization of cortex and medulla.

chinese_term: 运动纤毛细胞形态异常
english_description: Abnormal arrangement of the structures of the motile cilium.

Diffuse filling of the distal airsspaces of the lungs, the alveoli, with macrophages. Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis (DIP) is characterized additionally by thickend alveolar septa and by a sparse inflammatory infiltrate that often includes plasma cells and occasional eosinophils. The alveoli are lined by plump cuboidal pneumocytes. Lymphoid aggregates may be present.
Bilateral lack of development of the lungs.

english_term: Ventilator dependence with inability to wean

english_description: Reduced tendency to respond to a reduced concentration of oxygen in the blood by increasing respiration.
The presence of multiple lung cysts.
Recurrent episodes of apnea occurring during infancy.
A membrane-like structure that extends across the laryngeal lumen close to the level of the vocal cords.
An impairment of gluconeogenesis.
A decreased concentration of arginine in the blood.
Episodes of reduced body termperature.

chinese_term: 混合性呼吸和代谢性酸中毒

english_description: Disordered thermoregulation characterized by an impaired ability to maintain a balance between heat production and heat loss, with resulting instability of body temperature.
Acidosis because of respiratory retention of carbon dioxide.

Reduced intestinal absorption of fructose. Breath testing after ingestion of fructose has been widely adopted as a standard method of identifying fructose malabsorption and intolerance. A dose of 25 g of fructose dissolved in a 10% solution is generally accepted as the appropriate dose of fructose for clinical use of H2 and CH4 breath testing. High levels of hydrogen in exhaled breath subsequent hours indicate fructose intolerance. Presence of malabsorption and reproduction of symptoms during a breath test provides the best objective evidence and symptom correlation for fructose intolerance.
Intermittent episodes of ketoacidosis.
A type of diabetes mellitus initially characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia and subsequently by glucose interolerance and hyperglycemia.
A metabolic acidosis due to accumulation of ketone bodies generally observed in the setting of poor nutritional intake.

chinese_term: 孕妇血清α-甲胎蛋白水平升高
english_description: An elevation of alpha-feto protein in the maternal serum.
Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to multiple nodules in the thyroid gland.
A congenital form of torticollis resulting from shortening of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and leading to a limited range of motion in both rotation and lateral bending.
Excess skin around the neck, often lying in horizontal folds.
Developmental hypoplasia of the thyroid gland.
Reduced abilty to lower the chin towards the chest by bending the neck.
Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to one or more nodules in the thyroid gland.
Reduced amount of adipose tissue in the region of the neck.

english_term: Restricted neck movement due to contractures
chinese_term: 因挛缩致颈部活动受限

english_description: A developmental defect defined by the failure of the formation of the lumen (tube) of the ureter.
Obstruction of the flow of urine through the ureter.

english_term: Hypotrophy of the small hand muscles

english_description: Increased side-to-side width of one or more phalanges of the fingers or toes.
Severely shortened metacarpal with a cuboidal appearance.
Delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more phalanx.

chinese_term: 近端指间关节间隙减小

english_description: Metaphyseal cupping affecting the metacarpal bones.

chinese_term: 第二-第五指指骨锥形骨骺

english_description: Y-shaped metacarpals are the result of a partial fusion of two metacarpal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen in combination with polydactyly.
Abnormal increase in width of the distal region of the metacarpal bones.

chinese_term: 向尺骨偏离的曲棍球棒样手

english_description: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphyses of the metacarpal bones, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphyses are located at the distal ends of the metacarpal bones.
A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more long bones.
A chronic loss of joint motion in metacarpophalangeal joints due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.

chinese_term: 手指近端屈曲褶痕缺如
english_description: Absence of the proximal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fingers.

chinese_term: 五个手指完全皮肤性并指

english_description: Malalignement of carpal bone angles either with respect to each other, to the corresponding metacarpals or with respect to the wrist (radius and ulna).
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three and four.
Increased mobility of one ore more metacarpophalangeal joint.

Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as "bony" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a proximo-distal axis are referred to as "Symphalangism".
Telangiectasia (small dilated blood vessels) located in the fingerpads at the tips of the fingers.
Absence of one or more interphalangeal creases (i.e., of the transverse lines in the skin between the phalanges of the fingers).

english_term: Shortening of all middle phalanges of the fingers
english_description: Short, hypoplastic middle phalanx of finger, affecting all fingers.

english_term: Expanded phalanges with widened medullary cavities
chinese_term: 髓腔加宽型指（趾）骨膨大

english_description: The presence of multiple creases on the palm of the hand (more than the normal three major creases (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, and thenar crease).

english_term: Shortening of all distal phalanges of the fingers
chinese_term: 手指的所有远端指骨缩短
english_description: Hypoplasia of all of the distal phalanx of finger.
Some or all of the metacarpal bones (i.e., metacarpal II to V) have a pointed proximal appearance.
A type of digital ulcer that manifests as an open sore on the surface of the skin at the tip of a finger or toe.
Increased length of the proximal phalanx of finger.
Rounding and broadening of the tufts of the distal phalanges.
Fusion of the epiphysis and metaphysis of one or more phalanges prior to the normal age or stage of growth.

english_term: Shortening of all proximal phalanges of the fingers
english_description: Congenital hypoplasia of proximal phalanx of finger or all fingers.

A central Y-shaped metacarpal is the result of a partial fusion of two central metacarpals (i.e., metacarpals 2-4) of the hand, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Central Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen as a result of a central polydactyly with partial fusion of the duplicated metacarpal.
Increased side-to-side width of the metacarpal epiphyses.

chinese_term: 进行性第二-五指间关节融合

english_term: Swan neck-like deformities of the fingers
english_description: A swan neck deformity describes a finger with a hyperextended PIP joint and a flexed DIP joint. The most common cause for a swan neck-like deformity is a disruption of the end of the extensor tendon. Conditions that loosen the PIP joint and allow it to hyperextend, for example conditions that weaken the volar plate, can produce a swan neck deformity of the finger. One example is rheumatoid arthritis. Another cause are conditions that tighten up the small (intrinsic) muscles of the hand and fingers, for example hand trauma or nerve disorders, such as cerebral palsy, Parkinson's disease, or stroke.

The term proximal symphalangism refers to a bony fusion of the middle and proximal phalanges of the digits of the hand, in other words the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIJ) is missing which can be seen either on x-rays or as an absence of the proximal interphalangeal finger creases.
Increased length of multiple or a single phalanx of finger.
The presence of a supernumerary finger (not a thumb) involving the third or fourth metacarpal with associated osseous syndactyly.
Irregular morphology of one or more metacarpal bones.

english_term: Short metacarpals with rounded proximal ends
Soft tissue swelling of interphalangeal joints
Flattened, squared-off epiphyses of tubular bones
chinese_term: 扁平、方形的管状骨骨骺

english_description: Increase in bone density in the diaphyseal (shaft) region of a metacarpal bone.

english_term: Two carpal ossification centers present at birth
chinese_term: 先天性腕骨双骨化中心

english_description: Poorly defined or shallow palmar creases.
Excessively deep creases of the palm.
The middle phalanx of finger resembles a thimble, a small metal cap to protect the finger while sewing that has a broad (proximal) base and narrower top, whereby both base and top are flat.

chinese_term: 远端指(趾)间关节活动过度

english_term: Decreased movement range in interphalangeal joints
chinese_term: 指间关节活动范围减小

english_term: Hypersegmentation of proximal phalanx of second finger
chinese_term: 第二指近节指骨分节过多
english_description: Presence of an additional phalanx-like bone, producing an extra, wedge-shaped bone at the base of the proximal phalanx of the second finger.
Metaphyseal cupping affecting the proximal phalanges.

english_term: Thin proximal phalanges with broad epiphyses of the hand
chinese_term: 近端指骨变薄而骨骺增宽

english_term: Single interphalangeal crease of fifth finger
english_description: Presence of only one (instead of two, as normal) interphalangeal crease of the fifth finger.

english_term: Limited mobility of proximal interphalangeal joint
chinese_term: 近端指（趾）间关节活动受限

english_term: Tapering pointed ends of distal finger phalanges
chinese_term: 手指远端指骨末端尖细
english_description: A reduction in diameter of the distal phalanx of finger towards the distal end such that the tip of the phalanx comes to a point (this feature can be observed on radiograms).

english_term: Osteoarthritis of the first carpometacarpal joint
chinese_term: 第一腕掌关节骨性关节炎

english_term: Expanded metacarpals with widened medullary cavities
chinese_term: 髓质腔加宽型掌骨膨大

english_term: Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joint
chinese_term: 远端指（趾）间关节骨性关节炎

english_description: An increased resorption of bone matrix by osteoclasts leading to bony defects involving the tarsal bones.
Decreased width of the metacarpal bones (that is, reduced diameter).

english_term: Shortening of all middle phalanges of the toes
english_description: Abnormal shortening of all middle phalanges of toes.
An abnormal limitation of the mobility of the wrist.
An increased concentration of alpha-fetoprotein.

english_term: Abnormal phalangeal joint morphology of the hand

chinese_term: 第五指发育不良/发育不全
english_description: A small/hypoplastic or absent/aplastic 5th finger.

chinese_term: 手指发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Small/hypoplastic or absent/aplastic fingers.
Reduced size of the placenta.
Increased size of the placenta.
Intermittently increased size of the spleen.
Underdevelopment of the spleen.
Reduced number of beta cells in the pancreatic islets of Langerhans.
Hyperplasia of the pancreas.
A chronic form of pancreatitis.
The presence of multiple embedded tooth germs which have failed to erupt.
A decreased amount of enamel mineralization. Hypomineralized enamel has a brown discoloration and brittle aspect.
Premature tooth eruption, which can be defined as tooth eruption more than 2 SD earlier than the mean eruption age.
Agenesis of one or more central incisors, i.e., of lower secondary incisor, lower primary incisor, upper secondary incisor, or of upper central primary incisor.
An abnormality of tooth eruption.
Developmental hypoplasia of the dental enamel.
Prolonged bleeding post dental extraction sufficient to require medical intervention.
Dagger-shaped calcifications in the dental pulp.
A generalized form of microdontia.
Increased space between the primary teeth. Note this phenotype should be distinguished from increased space due purely to microdontia.
A single maxillary central incisor positioned in the midline with morphological symmetry of the crown and bordered by lateral incisors.
Irregular distribution of the teeth along the dental arch, i.e., and irregular spatial pattern of teeth.
Loss of the primary (also known as deciduous) teeth before the usual age.
The presence of a supernumerary, i.e., extra, maxillary incisor, either the primary maxillary incisor or the permanent maxillary incisor.
Developmental hypoplasia of the primary teeth.
Persistence of the primary teeth beyond the age by which they normally are shed and replaced by the permanent teeth.
Tooth root length more than 2 SD below mean, or subjectively apparently decreased tooth root length.
A tooth crown with its mesial and distal sides converging or tapering toward the incisal edge causing severe reduction of mesiodistal diameter
An abnormality of morphology of primary molar.
An abnormality of morphology of the incisor tooth in which the tooth is shaped like a screwdriver blade, i.e., having a rhomboid shape.
Decreased size of the primary teeth.
A congenital defect characterized by the absence of one or more permanent teeth, including oligodontia, hypodontia, and adontia of the of permanent teeth.
Mineralized substance filling the entire dental pulp space.

english_term: Failure of eruption of permanent teeth
english_description: Lack of tooth eruption of the secondary dentition.
Developmental hypoplasia of the tooth germ, i.e., of the structure that forms in odontogenesis that will develop into a tooth.
Agenesis of lower secondary incisor or lower primary incisor.
Premature loss of the permanent teeth.

An crumpled radiographic appearance of the long bones, as if the long bone had been crushed together producing irregularities. This feature is the result of multiple fractures and repeated rounds of ineffective healing, as can be seen for instance in severe forms of osteogenesis imperfecta.
Increased width of the diaphysis of long bones.
The femur is shortened and displays flaring (widening) of the metaphyses.
A bent (flexed) knee joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
Absent or nearly absent fibula. (Does not include aplastic)
Progressive bending or abnormal curvature of a long bone.
An abnormal conformation of the femur that becomes gradually enlarged towards the distal end. This feature affects the distal femoral metaphysis and epiphysis.
Shortening of the legs related to developmental hypoplasia of the bones of the leg.

chinese_term: 桡骨远端骨骺发育不良
english_description: Underdevelopment of the distal epiphysis of the radius.
Increased width of the distal part of the shaft (metaphysis) of the femur.
Reduced ability to flex (bend) the knee joint.
An abnormal anterior bending or curvature of the tibia.
Overconstriction, or narrowness of the diaphysis and metaphysis of long bones.
An abnormal increase in the bone density of the long bones.

A limitation of the ability to place the forearm in a position such that the palm faces anteriorly (supination) and to place the forearm in a position such that the palm faces posteriorly (pronation).
An abnormal flattening of the distal epiphysis of femur.
An abnormal conformation of the femur that becomes gradually enlarged towards the proximal end. This feature affects the proximal femoral metaphysis and epiphysis.
Anomaly of the contour of the Distal epiphysis of femur such that its normally smooth appearance is irregular.
Progressive bending or abnormal curvature of the leg.
A bending or abnormal curvature of the distal portion of the tibia.
Increased density of the compact bone of long bone.

english_term: Peg-like central prominence of distal tibial metaphyses
chinese_term: 胫骨远端干骺端钉状中央突出

english_description: An abnormally wide femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
An anomaly of the metaphysis of the proximal femur (close to the hip).
Proximal radial shortening owing to a congenital defect of development.

english_term: Disproportionate prominence of the femoral medial condyle
chinese_term: 股骨内侧髁不成比例的突出

english_term: Enlargement of the distal femoral epiphysis
english_description: An abnormal enlargement of the distal epiphysis of the femur.

english_term: Increased density of long bone diaphyses

english_description: Underdevelopment or shortening of the end of the fibula (calf bone) nearest the knee.
Absence of the patella.

english_term: Multicentric ossification of proximal femoral epiphyses
chinese_term: 股骨近端骨骺多中心骨化

english_term: Lateral displacement of the femoral head
english_description: A developmental anomaly with lateral displacement of the femoral head.
Formation of bone in the patella later than normal.
Anomaly of the contour of the proximal epiphysis of the tibia such that its normally smooth appearance is irregular.
Partial dislocation of the ulna in the dorsal direction.

chinese_term: 股骨近端骨骺生理溶解
english_description: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is defined as a posterior and inferior slippage of the proximal epiphysis of the femur onto the metaphysis (femoral neck), occurring through the physeal plate during the early adolescent growth spurt.

chinese_term: 广泛性骨矿质密度降低
english_description: A generalized decrease in bone mineral density.

english_term: Periosteal thickening of long tubular bones
english_description: Thickening of the periosteum of long bone.
A chronic loss of ankle joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the ankle.
A limitation of the range of movement of the shoulder joint.
Decreased width of the diaphysis of long bones.
An abnormal anterior curvature of a long bone.

english_term: Abnormality of the pancreatic islet cells
english_description: An abnormality of the islet of Langerhans, i.e., of the regions of the pancreas that contain its endocrine cells. These are the alpha cells, which produce glucagon, the beta cells, which produce insulin and amylin, the delta cells, which produce somatostatin, the PP cells, which produce pancreatic polypeptide, and the epsilon cells, which produce ghrelin.
Any abnormality of the alveolar ridges (on the upper or lower jaws). The alveolar ridges contain the sockets (alveoli) of the teeth.
An abnormality of the dental pulp.
Exfoliation of a tooth more than 2 SD earlier than the normal age for the deciduous teeth and not related to traume or neglect. Exfoliation of a permanent tooth is per se abnormal.
Any abnormality of the primary tooth.
An abnormality of the morphology of the tooth.
The presence of an altered number of of teeth.
Agenesis of incisor.
A bending or abnormal curvature of a long bone.
A bending or abnormal curvature affecting a long bone of the arm.
An anomaly of the femoral metaphysis.

chinese_term: 腓骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the fibula.

chinese_term: 尺骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the ulna.

chinese_term: 髌骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the patella.
An anomaly of a growth plate of a femur.

chinese_term: 桡骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: A small/hypoplastic or absent/aplastic radius.

chinese_term: 腕骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the carpal bones.

chinese_term: 肱骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence (due to failure to form) or underdevelopment of the humerus.
An anomaly that is characterized progressive airflow obstruction that is only partly reversible, inflammation in the airways, and systemic effects or comorbities.
An abnormal high-pitched noisy sound, occurring during inhalation or exhalation caused by the incomplete obstruction in the throat.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis involves inhalation of an antigen. This leads to an exaggerated immune response and a following inflammation of the alveoli within the lungs. The main feature of chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis on lung biopsies is expansion of the interstitium by lymphocytes accompanied by an occasional multinucleated giant cell or loose granuloma. After exposure to the provoking antigen, following symptoms can be seen: fever, chills, malaise, cough, hemoptysis, chest tightness, dyspnea, rash, swelling and headache and can be completely reversible, based on the duration of the illness, categorized as acute (HP:0011009), subacute (HP:0011011), and chronic (HP:0011010).
Accumulation of amorphous PAS-positive material in the space betweem alveolar macrophages, sometimes as condensed form (oval bodies) are typically found in alveolar proteinosis.
Substantial narrowing or blockage of small pulmonary veins as a result of disorganized smooth muscle hypertrophy and collagen matrix deposition.
Adenocarcinoma of the Bronchus.

Abnormal dilatation of the pulmonary lymphatic vessels. Lymphatic fluid in the lung is derived from normal leakage of fluid out of the blood capillaries in the lung. In pulmonary lymphangiectasia, the pulmonary lymphatics are not properly connected and become dilated with fluid.

chinese_term: 气管，支气管平滑肌瘤病
淋巴细胞性间质性肺炎
english_description: Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonitis is a benign lymphoproliferative disorder of the lung that is characterized by the presence of a dense, predominantly lymphocytic interstitial infiltrate (lymphocytes, plasma cells, other elements of the lymphoreticular system) that expands the alveolar septa.

According to the definitions of the American and British Thoracic Societies, including pulmonary functional tests, X-rays, and CT scans for items such as fibrosis, bronchiectasis, bullae, emphysema, nodular or lymphomatous abnormalities.
Abnormality of the lung parenchyma extending to the pulmonary interstitium and leading to diffuse pulmonary fibrosis.
An increased susceptibility to pneumonia as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of pneumonia.
A recurrent hemorrhage occurring within the lung.
Obstruction of conducting airways of the lung.
An increased susceptibility to bronchopulmonary infections as manifested by a history of recurrent bronchopulmonary infections.

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation, a condition most commonly associated with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, is an abnormal communication between the pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein without an intervening capillary communication. HRCT images usually show a coarse spidery appearance of the peripheral vascular markings in the lungs. More specific findings are obtained in the pulmonary angiogram where the normally invisible capillary phase is replaced by irregular vascular channels bridging the peripheral branches of pulmonary arteries and veins.

chinese_term: 单侧原发性肺动脉发育不良

english_description: Hepatic failure refers to the inability of the liver to perform its normal synthetic and metabolic functions, which can result in coagulopathy and alteration in the mental status of a previously healthy individual. Hepatic failure is defined as acute if there is onset of encephalopathy within 8 weeks of the onset of symptoms in a patient with a previously healthy liver.
A diffuse form of hepatic steatosis.

english_term: Decreased mitochondrial complex III activity in liver tissue
chinese_term: 肝组织线粒体复合物III活性降低
english_description: Decreased activity of complex III of the mitochondrion in the liver.
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition in the liver.
Hyperplasia of the biliary tree, as manifested by increased size of bile ducts, dilated lumen, and histologically by an increased number of epithelial cells or hyperplasia.
Inflammation of the liver due to infection with a virus.

english_term: Malformation of the hepatic ductal plate

english_description: Intermittently increased size of the liver.
An abnormal increase in the amount of intracellular lipid droplets in hepatocytes.

chinese_term: 新生儿胆汁淤积性肝病

english_description: An increase in the amount of glycogen stored in hepatocytes compared to normal.

english_term: Reduced number of intrahepatic bile ducts
english_description: The presence of reduced numbers of intrahepatic bile duct than normal.

chinese_term: 亚急性进行性病毒性肝炎

english_description: An acute form of hepatic steatosis.

chinese_term: 肝内胆汁淤积伴发作性黄疸

english_description: A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of large regenerative nodules.

Neonatal jaundice refers to a yellowing of the skin and other tissues of a newborn infant as a result of increased concentrations of bilirubin in the blood. Neonatal jaundice affects over half of all newborns to some extent in the first week of life. Prolonged neonatal jaundice is said to be present if the jaundice persists for longer than 14 days in term infants and 21 days in preterm infants.
Fibroblast proliferation and fiber expansion from the portal areas to the lobule.

english_term: Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in liver
english_description: An abnormal reduction in the number of mitochondria in hepatocytes.
Repeated occurrences of acute noninflammatory encephalopathy and fatty degenerative liver failure.

chinese_term: 婴儿期致命性肝功能衰竭
小的异常形成的肩胛骨

english_description: The two portions of the clavicle (corresponding to the two primary ossification centers of the clavicle) are connected by a fibrous bridge that is contiguous with the periosteum, and a synovial membrane develops, resulting in a clavicle with a bipartite appearance radiographically. Congenital pseudarthrosis of the clavicle generally presents as a painless mass or swelling over the clavicle.
An abnormally straight configuration of the clavicle, a tubular bone which normally is doubly curved .
Lack of development of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.
Bony fusion between the humerus and scapula, leading to an impairment in mobility of the affected shoulder joint.
The presence of a paralyzed diaphragm.

english_term: Irregular ossification at anterior rib ends

english_description: Underdevelopment of the middle portion of the clavicle.
A larger than usual distance between the left and right nipple.
Lack of formation and mineralization of the ribs in utero.
Deposition of calcium salts in point-like foci within the anterior portion of one or more ribs.
Lack of formation of mineralized bony tissue of the sternum.
Underdevelopment of the glenoid fossa, which is the cavity in the lateral part of the scapula which articulates with the head of the humerus.
Osteosclerosis of ribs (increased density related to increased bone mass).
Developmental defect resulting in congenital absence of the middle portion of the clavicle.
More than one fracture of the ribs.
Abnormally reduced diameter (cross section) of the clavicles.

Calcification of the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage found at the anterior ends of the ribs which serve to prolong the ribs forward and contribute to the elasticity of the walls of the thorax.

english_term: Thickening of the lateral border of the scapula

english_description: Absence of the clavicles as a developmental defect.
An abnormal morphology of the ribs consisting of shorted, abnormally curved ribs. On posteroanterior chest radiography, the ribs show a curvature resembling that of a coat hanger (clothes hanger).
Increased time for the complex comprised of the Q wave, R wave, and S wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).. In adults, normal values are 0.06 - 0.10 sec.

Premature ventricular contractions (PVC) or ventricular extrasystoles are premature contractions of the heart that arise in response to an impulse in the ventricles rather than the normal impulse from the sinoatrial (SA) node.

english_term: Ventricular preexcitation with multiple accessory pathways
chinese_term: 多旁路心室预激综合征
english_description: A form of ventricular preexcitation due to the presence of multiple accessory pathways for cardiac conduction.
The presence of excessive connective tissue in the endocardium.
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the aorta.
A bacterial infection of the endocardium, the inner layer of the heart, which usually involves the heart valves.
Calcium deposition in the myocardium.

english_term: Short chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve
english_description: Abnormally short chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve.
Steatosis in the myocardium.
A defect of the atrioventricular septum of the heart.

chinese_term: 多态性及多发性室性期前收缩

english_description: A localized outpouching of ventricular cavity that is generally associated with dyskinesia and paradoxical expansion during systole.
A type of cardiac arrhythmia with premature atrial contractions or beats caused by signals originating from ectopic atrial sites.
Acute occurrence of a dissection (tear within the tunica intima and entry of blood into the tunica media) of a coronary artery.
An abnormality of the hepatic vasculature.

chinese_term: 锁骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the clavicles (collar bones).

chinese_term: 肋骨发育不良/发育不全
肩胛骨发育不良/发育不全
胸骨发育不良/发育不全
遗传性非息肉性结直肠癌

english_description: A form of acute leukemia characterized by excess lympoblasts.
The presence of an adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.

chinese_term: T细胞急性淋巴细胞白血病
english_description: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia of T-cell origin. It comprises about 15% of childhood cases and 25% of adult cases. It is more common in males than females.
The presence of an follicular adenocarcinoma of the thyroid gland.
A type of papillary renal cell carcinoma in which the papillae are covered by large eosinophilic cells with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and nuclear pseudostratification.
A rare subtype of acute myeloid leukemia evolving from primitive megakaryoblasts.
The presence of an adenoma in the cortex of the kidney.
Pheochromocytoma not originating from the adrenal medulla but from another source such as from chromaffin cells in or about sympathetic ganglia.

english_term: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
english_description: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is a malignant tumor of squamous epithelium.

english_term: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder
english_description: The presence of a carcinoma of the urinary bladder with origin in a transitional epithelial cell.
A malignant neoplasm of the adrenal cortex that may produce hormones such as cortisol, aldosterone, estrogen, or testosterone.
Pheochromocytoma originating from the adrenal medulla.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the stomach.
The presence of leiomyosarcoma of the skin.
The presence of a malignant neoplasm of the genital system.
A slowly growing malignant neoplasm derived from cartilage cells.
The presence of renal cell carcinoma in the renal papilla.

A type of pituitary adenoma originating in prolactin secreting cells. This kind of adenoma is characterized by overproduction of prolactin, and may cause loss of menstrual periods and breast milk production in women.
A subtype of renal cell carcinoma thought to originate from mature renal tubular cells in the proximal tubule of the nehpron.
A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the duodenum.
A benign renal neoplasm composed of fat, vascular, and smooth muscle elements.
The presence of a papillary adenocarcinoma of the ovary.
A malignant plasma cell tumor growing within soft tissue or within the skeleton.
A non-malignant neoplasm of the genitourinary system.
