Muscular atrophy affecting proximally located muscles of the legs, i.e., of the thigh.
Reduced strength of the distal musculature of the arms.
Underdevelopment of the muscuklature of the calf.
Muscle weakness affecting the tibialis anterior muscle.
Muscular atrophy that does not display a progression in severity with time.
A type of muscle stiffness that occurs following physical exertion.

english_term: Muscle hypertrophy of the lower extremities
english_description: Muscle hypertrophy primarily affecting the legs.

english_term: Decreased activity of mitochondrial respiratory chain
chinese_term: 线粒体呼吸链活性降低
english_description: Decreased activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain.
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the calf muscles.
An abnormal increase in the amount of intramuscular fat tissue.
Congenital lack, i.e., aplasia of the diaphragm.

Muscular atrophy affecting the muscles that attach to the pelvic girdle (the gluteal muscles, the lateral rotators, adductor magnus, adductor brevis, adductor longus, pectineus, and gracilis muscles).
Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles of the leg brought on by physical exertion.
An abnormal increase in the amount of intraabdominal fat tissue.

english_term: Proximal muscle weakness in lower limbs
english_description: A lack of strength of the proximal muscles of the legs.

english_term: Proximal muscle weakness in upper limbs
english_description: A lack of strength of the proximal muscles of the arms.
Underdevelopment of the pectoral muscle.

english_term: Loss of truncal subcutaneous adipose tissue
chinese_term: 躯干部皮下脂肪组织丢失
english_description: Loss (reduction of previously present) of subcutaneous adipose tissue in the region of the trunk.

chinese_term: 躯干部皮下脂肪组织增多
english_description: The presence of an abnormally increased amount of subcutaneous adipose tissue in the trunk of the body.
Underdevelopment of the musculature.

english_term: Weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles

english_description: Underdevelopment of muscles of the arm.

english_term: Loss of gluteal subcutaneous adipose tissue
chinese_term: 臀部皮下脂肪组织丢失
english_description: Loss (reduction of previously present) of subcutaneous adipose tissue in the gluteal region.

english_term: Progressive loss of facial adipose tissue
chinese_term: 进行性面部脂肪组织丢失

english_description: An abnormally increased tendency towards muscle fatigue induced by physical exercise.
Decreased strength of the abdominal musculature.
The presence of an abnormally increased amount of connective tissue.

Weakness of the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot, that is, of the movement of the toes towards the shin. The foot dorsiflexors include the tibialis anterior, the extensor hallucis longus, the extensor digitorum longus, and the peroneus tertius muscles.
Generalized weakness of the muscles of the arms and legs.
Atrophy of the muscles of the ankle.
Severe hypertrophy (increase in size) of muscle cells.

chinese_term: 运动诱发的横纹肌溶解
english_description: Rhabdomyolysis induced by exercise.
Reduced ability to run.
Atrophy of the peroneous muscles, peroneus longus (also known as Fibularis longus), Peroneus brevis (also known as fibularis brevis, and Peroneus tertius (also known as fibularis tertius).
Muscular atrophy involving the quadriceps muscle.
An increased amount of glycogen in muscle tissue.
Reduced strength of the distal musculature of the legs.
Generalized (unlocalized) atrophy affecting muscles of the limbs in both proximal and distal locations.

english_term: Loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue from upper limbs
chinese_term: 上肢皮下脂肪组织丢失

english_description: An abnormal accumulation of lipids in skeletal muscle.

chinese_term: 先天性全身脂肪营养不良

english_description: Atrophy of the muscles that are responsible for moving the scapula, which are the levator scapulae, the infraspinatus muscle, the teres major, the teres minor, and the supraspinatus muscle.
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) affecting the musculature of the trunk and with onset in infancy.
Progressively reduced strength of the distal musculature.
Generalized degenerative changes of the fat tissue.

chinese_term: 致死型婴儿线粒体肌病

english_description: Chronic muscle inflammation accompanied by muscle weakness.
Decreased intensity of the Achilles reflex (also known as the ankle jerk reflex), which can be elicited by tapping the tendon is tapped while the foot is dorsiflexed.
Lack of strength of the proximal muscles that becomes progressively more severe.

english_term: Weakness of long finger extensor muscles
Midline notch of upper alveolar ridge

english_description: Increased width of the alveolar ridges.
Impairment in the physical production of speech sounds.

Chronic accumulation and overgrowth of the fungus Candida albicans on the mucous membranes of the mouth, generally manifested as associated with creamy white lesions on the tongue or inner cheeks, occasionally spreading to the gums, tonsils, palate or oropharynx.
Cleft palate of the midline of the palate.
A cleft of the lip with overlying mucous membrane.

chinese_term: 前牙开咬错位咬合畸形
english_description: Anterior open bite is a malocclusion characterized by a gap between the anterior teeth (incisors), that is, by a deficiency in the normal vertical overlap between antagonist incisal edges when the posterior teeth are in occlusion.

chinese_term: 骨盆骨发育不良/发育不全
耻骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the pubic bone.
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any bone of the bony pelvis.

english_term: Abnormal ossification involving the femoral head and neck
chinese_term: 股骨颈和股骨头骨化异常

english_description: Interruption of the innervation of the diaphragm.
A congenital failure of muscular development of part or all of one or both hemidiaphragms, resulting in superior displacement of abdominal viscera and altered lung development.
Congenital absence of the left half of the diaphragm.
A decrease in the strength of the diaphragm.

chinese_term: 下颌骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the mandible.

chinese_term: 额窦发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of frontal sinus.

english_term: Mixed hypo- and hyperpigmentation of the skin
chinese_term: 皮肤色素减退和色素沉着共存

english_description: An abnormality of adipose tissue, which is loose connective tissue composed of adipocytes.
Degenerative changes of the fat tissue.

An increase in adipose tissue mass by hyperplastic growth (increase in the number of adipocytes) or by hypertrophic growth (increase in the size of adipocytes occurring primarily by lipid accumulation within the cell).

english_term: Abnormality of the musculature of the limbs

english_description: Muscular atrophy involving the muscles of the upper limbs.
Muscular atrophy involving the muscles of the hand.

english_term: Osteolysis involving bones of the feet
Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in muscle tissue
chinese_term: 肌肉组织中线粒体DNA消耗

english_description: Any structural anomaly of a cerebral artery. The cerebral arteries comprise three main pairs of arteries and their branches, which supply the cerebrum of the brain. These are the anterior cerebral artery, the middle cerebral artery, and the posterior cerebral artery.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger
chinese_term: 第五指中节指骨发育不全/发育不良
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the middle phalanx of the little (5th) finger.
Absence of the middle phalanx of the little (5th) finger.

english_term: Abnormal calcification of the carpal bones

chinese_term: 第五指近节/中节关节融合
english_description: Fusion of the proximal and middle phalanges of the 5th finger.
Displacement of the 5th finger from its normal position.

english_term: Triangular shaped middle phalanx of the 5th finger
chinese_term: 第五指三角形中节指骨
english_description: Triangular shaped middle phalanx of the 5th (little) finger. A triangular or so called delta shaped phalanx is a typical result after a bracket epiphysis of the affected phalanx.

Chronic loss of joint motion in the 5th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 5th finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.

english_term: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 5th finger
chinese_term: 第五指近节指间关节挛缩
english_description: Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) flexion deformity of the little finger. That is, the PIP joint of a little finger is bent (flexed) and cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.
Fragmented appearance of the epiphyses of the metacarpals.

A pseudoepiphysis is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis. The normal metacarpal epiphyses are located at the distal ends of the metacarpal bones. Accessory epiphyses (which are also known as pseudoepiphyses) can also occasionally be observed at the proximal ends of the metacarpals, usually involving the 2nd metacarpal bone.

english_term: Short proximal phalanx of the 5th finger
english_description: Hypoplastic/small proximal phalanx of the fifth finger.

chinese_term: 第五指发育不全或不发育
english_description: Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the fifth finger, also known as the little finger.
Absent 5th (little) finger.

chinese_term: 第五指末节/中节指关节融合
english_description: Fusion of the terminal/distal and middle phalanges of the 5th finger.

Chronic loss of joint motion in the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 4th finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.

english_term: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger
chinese_term: 第四指的近端指间关节挛缩
english_description: Chronic loss of joint motion of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. That is, the PIP joint of a fourth finger is bent (flexed) and cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.
Displacement of the 4th finger towards the radial side (i.e., towards the thumb).
Absent 4th finger.

english_term: Short distal phalanx of the 4th finger
english_description: Hypoplastic/small distal phalanx of the fourth finger.

english_term: Short middle phalanx of the 4th finger
english_description: Hypoplastic/small middle phalanx of the 4th finger, also known as the ring finger.

english_term: Enlarged epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
chinese_term: 第三指中节指骨骨骺膨大
english_description: Abnormally large size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger with respect to age-dependent norms.

english_term: Triangular epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
chinese_term: 第三指中节指骨三角形骨骺
english_description: A triangular appearance of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger of the hand. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat.

english_term: Enlarged epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger
chinese_term: 第三指近节指骨骨骺膨大
english_description: Abnormally large size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger with respect to age-dependent norms.

english_term: Triangular epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger
chinese_term: 第三指近节指骨三角形骨骺
english_description: A triangular appearance of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger of the hand. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat.
Increased width of the phalanges of the 5th finger.
Abnormally short finger associated with developmental hypoplasia.
A secondary ossification center in the third finger that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.

english_term: Triangular shaped middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
chinese_term: 第三指三角形中节指骨
english_description: Triangular shaped middle phalanx of the 3rd (middle) finger. A triangular or so called delta shaped phalanx is a typical result after a bracket epiphysis of the affected phalanx.

english_term: Short middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
english_description: Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the middle phalanx of the third finger.

english_term: Triangular shaped proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger
chinese_term: 第三指三角形近节指骨
english_description: Triangular shaped proximal phalanx of the 3rd (middle) finger. A triangular or so called delta shaped phalanx is a typical result after a bracket epiphysis of the affected phalanx.
Absent 3rd finger.
Hypoplastic/small 3rd (middle) finger.
Displacement of the 3rd finger towards the radial side (i.e., towards the thumb).
Displacement of the 3rd finger towards the ulnar side (i.e., towards the ring finger).
Displacement of the 2nd (index) finger towards the ulnar side.
Bending or curvature of a finger toward the ulnar side (i.e., away from the thumb). The deviation is at the metacarpal-phalangeal joint, and this finding is distinct from clinodactyly.
Bending or curvature of a finger toward the radial side (i.e., towards the thumb). The deviation is at the metacarpal-phalangeal joint, and this finding is distinct from clinodactyly.
Displacement of the 2nd finger towards the radial side.
Displacement of the 2nd finger from its normal position.

english_term: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd finger
chinese_term: 第三指近端指间关节挛缩
english_description: Chronic loss of joint motion of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
Contractures of one ore more joints of the hands meaning chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.

chinese_term: 第四手指近、中节指关节融合
english_description: Fusion of the proximal and middle phalanges of the 4th finger.

english_term: Deviation of the hand or of fingers of the hand
english_description: Displacement of the hand or of fingers of the hand from their normal position.
An abnormal position of the hand in which the wrist is bent toward the radius (i.e., toward the thumb).
Divergence of the longitudinal axis of the hand at the wrist in a posterior (ulnar) direction (i.e., towards the little finger).
A secondary ossification center in the second finger that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.

english_term: Enlarged epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 2nd finger
chinese_term: 第二指中节指骨骨骺膨大

english_term: Triangular epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 2nd finger
chinese_term: 第二指中节指骨三角形骨骺

english_term: Enlarged epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger
chinese_term: 第二指近节指骨骨骺膨大

english_term: Triangular epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger
chinese_term: 第二指近节指骨三角形骨骺

english_description: Hypoplasia of the second finger, also known as the index finger.

english_term: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd finger
chinese_term: 第二指的近节指骨间关节挛缩
english_description: Chronic loss of joint motion of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.

The hairline refers to the outline of hair of the head. An abnormality of the hairline can refer to an unusually low or high border between areas of the scalp with and without hair or to abnormal projections of scalp hair.
An tongue-like extension of hair towards the cheeks, in which hair growth extends in front of the ear to the lateral cheekbones.
Underdevelopment of the pharynx.
Absence of the tibia.

english_term: Aplasia of the distal phalanx of the 2nd finger
chinese_term: 第二指末节指骨发育不全

english_term: Short distal phalanx of the 2nd finger
english_description: Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the distal phalanx of the second finger.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the 2nd finger
chinese_term: 第二指中节指骨发育不全或发育不良

english_term: Triangular shaped middle phalanx of the 2nd finger
chinese_term: 第二指三角形中节指骨
english_description: Triangular shaped middle phalanx of the 2nd finger. A triangular or so called delta shaped phalanx is a typical result after a bracket epiphysis of the affected phalanx.
Absence of the middle phalanx of the index (2nd) finger.

english_term: Short middle phalanx of the 2nd finger
english_description: Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the middle phalanx of the second finger, also known as the index finger.

english_term: Triangular shaped proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger
chinese_term: 第二指三角形近节指骨
english_description: Triangular shaped proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger. A triangular or so called delta shaped phalanx is a typical result after a bracket epiphysis of the affected phalanx.

A vestibular Schwannoma (also known as acoustic neuroma, acoustic neurinoma, or acoustic neurilemoma) is a benign, usually slow-growing tumor that develops from the VIIIth cranial nerve supplying the inner ear.
A bilateral vestibular Schwannoma (acoustic neurinoma).
A unilateral vestibular Schwannoma (acoustic neurinoma).
Abnormality of the vestibulocochlear nerve, the eighth cranial nerve, which is involved in transmitting sound and equilibrium information from the inner ear to the brain.
Astrocytoma is a neoplasm of the central nervous system derived from astrocytes. Astrocytes are a type of glial cell, and thus astrocytoma is a subtype of glioma.
The presence of a peripheral schwannoma.
A hamartoma (a benign, focal malformation consisting of a disorganized mixture of cells and tissues) of the retina.
Neurofibromas present in a smaller number than usually seen in neurofibromatosis type 1.

english_term: Short proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger
english_description: Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the proximal phalanx of the second finger.
Chronic loss of joint motion in the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.

chinese_term: 拇指发育不全或发育不良
english_description: Hypoplastic/small or absent thumb.
Displacement of the thumb from its normal position.

english_term: Complete duplication of distal phalanx of the thumb
chinese_term: 拇指末节指骨完全重复
english_description: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. On x-ray two separate bones appear side to side.

english_term: Complete duplication of proximal phalanx of the thumb
chinese_term: 拇指近节指骨完全重复
english_description: Complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. On x-ray two separate bones appear side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

english_term: Bifid distal phalanx of the thumb
chinese_term: 拇指末节指骨部分重复
english_description: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx) to a partially fused appearance of the two bones.

english_term: Abnormality of the distal phalanx of the thumb
english_description: Any anomaly of the distal phalanx of thumb.
Proximal mislocalization of the thumb.

english_term: Contractures of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb
english_description: Chronic loss of joint motion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is also called Articulatio interphalangealis pollicis.

Absence of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

Hypoplastic (short) proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

english_term: Synostosis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb with the 1st metacarpal
chinese_term: 拇指近节指骨与第一掌骨骨性连合
english_description: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the thumb with the 1st metacarpal.

english_term: Broad distal phalanx of the thumb
english_description: Increased width of the distal phalanx of thumb.

english_term: Triangular shaped distal phalanx of the thumb
english_description: Triangular shaped distal phalanx of the thumb. A triangular or so called delta shaped phalanx is a typical result after a bracket epiphysis of the affected phalanx.

english_term: Short distal phalanx of the thumb
english_description: Hypoplastic (short) distal phalanx of the thumb.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the thumb
chinese_term: 拇指指骨发育不全或发育不良

english_description: Hypoplastic (short) thumb phalanx.

english_term: Stippling of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
chinese_term: 拇指末节指骨骨骺点状钙化
english_description: The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb.
A pseudoepiphysis (which is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis) of one or more phalanges of the thumb.

english_term: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the fingers
english_description: Chronic loss of joint motion in one or more distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers.

An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the fingers. The synonymous term "symphalangism of the hand" may be translated as fusions of bones of varying digree, that involve at least one phalangeal bone of the hand. If bony fusions are referred to as "Symphalangism" the fusion occurs in a proximo-distal axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a radio-ulnar axis are referred to as "bony" Syndactyly.

Fusion involving two or more metacarpal bones (A synostosis of the first metacarpal and the proximal phalanx of the thumb can also be observed, note that the first metacarpal bone corresponds to a proximal phalanx).
Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the carpus (scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate, pisiform).

Fusion of the 1st metacarpal with another bone. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2 to 5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

chinese_term: 慢性脑脊液淋巴细胞增多
english_description: Chronic cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) lymphocytosis is defined as the finding, in at least two serial CSF examinations, of more than 5 cells per cubic millimeter.
Increased concentration of interferon alpha in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Chilblains, also called perniosis, are an inflammatory skin condition related to an abnormal vascular response to the cold. We are unaware of a reliable estimate of incidence. It typically presents as tender, pruritic red or bluish lesions located symmetrically on the dorsal aspect of the fingers, toes, ears and nose. Less commonly, reports describe involvement of the thighs and buttocks. The lesions present hours after exposure to cold and usually resolve spontaneously in one to three weeks.
A benign vascular tumor of the retina without any neoplastic characteristics.
A hemangioblastoma of the spinal cord.
An abnormality of the epididymis.
A cystadenoma, an epithelial tumor, that originates within the head of the epididymis.
Small nodular masses which originate in the subependymal region of the lateral ventricles and protrude into the ventricular cavity. They may represent subependymal hamartomas of tuberous sclerosis.

Cortical tubers in the brain are hamartomatous lesions typically located at the gray-white matter interface, commonly in the frontal and parietal lobes. Cortical tubers are composed of abnormal glial and neural cells, and the size, number, and location vary among patients.

chinese_term: 室管膜下巨细胞星形细胞瘤
english_description: A demarcated, largely intraventricular tumor in the region of the foramen of Monro composed of spindle to large plump or ganglion-like cells with eosinophilic to amphophilic cytoplasm and somewhat pleomorphic nuclei with occasional prominent nucleoli. These tumors are almost always associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Hypomelanotic macules ("ash leaf spots") are white or lighter patches of skin that may appear anywhere on the body and are caused by a lack of melanin. White ash leaf-shaped macules are considered to be characteristic of tuberous sclerosis.
The presence of a sebaceous adenoma with origin in the sebum secreting cells of the skin.

A plaque representing a connective-tissue nevus. Connective tissue naevi are uncommon skin lesions that occur when the deeper layers of the skin do not develop correctly or the components of these layers occur in the wrong proportion. Shagreen patches are oval-shaped and nevoid, skin-colored or occasionally pigmented, smooth or crinkled, The word shagreen refers to a type of roughened untanned leather.
The presence of small depressions in the dental enamel.
A lesion located beneath a fingernail or toenail.
The presence of fibromata beneath finger or toenails.
The presence of a neoplasm of the urinary bladder.
The presence of a neoplasm of the kidney.
Areas of the retina lacking pigmentation. Punched out areas of chorioretinal hypopigmentation less than 1 disc diameter in size and tending to be located in the midperiphery of the retina.
A benign tumor of cardiac striated muscle.
A neurofibroma in which Schwann cells proliferate inside the nerve sheath, producing an irregularly thickened, distorted, tortuous structure.
The presence of a glioma, which is a neoplasm of the central nervous system originating from a glial cell (astrocytes or oligodendrocytes).
A glioma originating in the optic nerve or optic chiasm.
Neurofibromas originating in the spine.

Pseudarthrosis, or "false joint" of the tibia is the result of a developmental failure in the tibia progressing to spontaneous fracture and subsequent fibrous nonunion. The fracture is rarely present at birth but commonly develops during the first 18 months of life.
The presence of pigmented, oval and dome-shaped raised hamartomatous nevi of the iris..
An abnormality of the antihelix.
Developmental hypoplasia of the antihelix.
Absence of the parotid gland.
Nephrosclerosis refers to thickening or scarring ("sclerosis") resulting from damage to the renal arterioles, also referred to as arteriosclerosis of the kidney arteries.
Shoulder joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in shoulders when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity.
Double rows of eyelashes.
Presence of arachnoid cysts of the spinal canal extradurally in the epidural space.
Abnormally increased thickness of the nasal septum.
Abnormally increased hair growth in the lumbosacral region.
Increased volume of the earlobe, that is, abnormally prominent ear lobules.

english_term: Aplasia of the pectoralis major muscle
english_description: Absence of the pectoralis major muscle.
A bony defect in the skull base.
Complete or nearly complete soft tissue fusion of the alveolar ridges.
Partial fusion of the upper and lower eyelid margins by single or multiple bands of tissue.
A pterygium (or pterygia) occurring in the popliteal region (the back of the knee).
A pterygium (or pterygia) in the intercrural (groin) region.

english_term: Pyramidal skinfold extending from the base to the top of the nails
chinese_term: 甲近端向远端锥形分布的皮褶
english_description: Pyramidal skinfold extending from the base to the top of the nails is a rare and distinctive anomaly seen in popliteal pterygia syndrome.
Pterygia affecting the neck.
Pterygium affecting the elbow. This is a cutaneous web that can lead to severe flexion contracture of the elbow joint. Antecubital pterygium can be unilateral, bilateral, symmetric, or asysmmetric.
Anterior schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies.
Excessive wrinkling of the skin of the face.
Chronic pain in the limbs with no clear focal etiology.
Columella extending inferior to the level of the nasal base, when viewed from the side.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the hand
chinese_term: 指骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Small or missing phalangeal bones of the fingers of the hand.
Increased width of the phalanges of the hand.
The presence of short and wide phalanges which taper distally ("bullet shaped").

english_term: Osteolytic defects of the phalanges of the hand
english_description: Dissolution or degeneration of bone tissue of the phalanges of the hand.
Uneven (irregular) increase in bone density of one or more of the phalanges of the hand.

english_term: Symphalangism affecting the phalanges of the hand
english_description: Fusion of two or more phalangeal bones of the hand.

english_term: Triangular shaped phalanges of the hand

english_description: Annular constrictions around the digits, limbs, or trunk, occurring congenitally (sometimes causing intrauterine autoamputation) and also associated with a wide variety of disorders. Constrictive amniotic bands are the result of primary amniotic rupture, which can lead to entanglement of fetal tissue (especially limbs) in fibrous amniotic strands.
The absence of all phalanges of all the digits of a limb and the associated soft tissues.
Absent thumb, i.e., the absence of both phalanges of a thumb and the associated soft tissues.
Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the thumb.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes three and four.

Horn-like malformations of the iliac crests with symmetrical bilateral central posterior iliac processes. A characteristic finding in the Nail-Patella syndrome. Iliac horns are visible on X-ray and may be palpable, but are asymptomatic.
A zone of darker pigmentation around the central part of the iris with a roughly cloverleaf or flower shape.
Absence of the biceps muscle.
Absence of the triceps muscle.
Absence of the quadriceps muscle.
The presence of an abscess located around the anus.
A hemisacral defect involving the sacral vertebrae S2 to S5. In hemisacrum, the first sacral vertebra is intact and there is agenesis involving only S2-S5.
Presence of a bifid sacral bone.
The presence of a teratoma.
A type of sacrococcygeal teratoma located anterior to the sacrum and entirely inside the body (Altman type IV).
Congenital developmental defect arising from the primitive branchial apparatus.
A congenital fistula in the neck resulting from incomplete closure of a branchial cleft.

A branchial cyst is a remnant of embryonic development resulting from a failure of obliteration of a branchial cleft and consists of a subcutaneous cystic mass. Cysts are located anterior or posterior to the ear or in the submandibular region.

Cholesteatoma is a benign but potentially destructive growth consisting of keratinizing epithelium located in the middle ear and/or mastoid process. In cholesteatoma, a skin cyst grows into the middle ear and mastoid. The cyst is not cancerous but can erode tissue and cause destruction of the ear.

chinese_term: 甲状腺功能正常的甲状腺肿
english_description: A goiter that is not associated with functional thyroid abnormalities.

Maternal diabetes can either be a gestational, mostly type 2 diabetes, or a type 1 diabetes. Essential is the resulting maternal hyperglycemia as a non-specific teratogen, imposing the same risk of congenital malformations to pregnant women with both type 1 and type2 diabetes.

english_term: Aplasia of the phalanges of the hand
english_description: Absence of one or more of the phalanges of the hand.
Short (hypoplastic) phalanx of finger, affecting one or more phalanges.
The absence of one or more teeth from the normal series by a failureto develop

chinese_term: 低输出型充血性心力衰竭
english_description: A form of heart failure characterized by reduced cardiac output. This may be seen in patients with heart failure owing to ischemic heart disease, hypertension, cardiomyopathy, and other causes.
A form of diabetes insipidus caused by failure of the kidneys to respond to vasopressin (AVP).
An anomaly of the joint that connects the upper and the lower arm.

Missing or malformed long bones of the upper limbs with the distal parts (the hands) connected to the variably shortened or even absent upper extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the whole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia).
Peromelia affecting only the upper limbs. That is, the distal parts of the arm are missing leading to stump formation.

chinese_term: 肢体发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence (due to failure to form) or underdevelopment of the extremities.
Leg shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the lower extremity.
Amelia of one or both legs.
Peromelia affecting only the lower limbs. That is, the distal parts of the leg are missing leading to stump formation.
Forearm shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the forearm.
Arm shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the upper extremity.
Limb shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the extremities.
Congenital absence (aplasia) of one or more limbs.

Missing or malformed long bones of the extremities with the distal parts (such as hands and/or feet) connected to the variably shortened or even absent extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the hole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia).

Peripheral neuropathy is a general term for any disorder of the peripheral nervous system. The main clinical features used to classify peripheral neuropathy are distribution, type (mainly demyelinating versus mainly axonal), duration, and course.
A focal lesion of a single peripheral nerve. Damage to a sensory nerve is accompanied by sensory impairment of all modalities in the affected anatomic distribution.

english_term: Abnormal distal phalanx morphology of finger
english_description: Any anomaly of distal phalanx of finger.

english_term: Abnormal proximal phalanx morphology of the hand
chinese_term: 手指近节指骨形态异常

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the distal phalanges of the hand
chinese_term: 末节指骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the distal phalanges.
Abnormally wide (broad) distal phalanx of finger.

english_term: Curved distal phalanges of the hand
Osteolytic defects of the distal phalanges of the hand
chinese_term: 手末节指骨溶骨性缺陷

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the middle phalanges of the hand
chinese_term: 中节指骨发育不良/发育不全

english_description: Increased width of the middle phalanx of finger.

english_term: Bullet-shaped middle phalanges of the hand
english_description: Any of the middle phalanges with short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.

english_term: Broad proximal phalanges of the hand
english_description: Increased width of the proximal phalanges of the finger.

english_term: Triangular shaped distal phalanges of the hand

english_description: An abnormality of the cerebral cortex with fewer gyri but with normal cortical thickness. This pattern is usually often associated with congenital microcephaly.

english_term: Broad distal phalanges of all fingers
chinese_term: 所有手指末节指骨变宽
english_description: Abnormally wide (broad) distal phalanx of finger of all fingers.

english_term: Aplasia of the distal phalanges of the hand

english_description: Short distance from the end of the finger to the most distal interphalangeal crease or the distal interphalangeal joint flexion point. That is, hypoplasia of one or more of the distal phalanx of finger.

english_term: Duplication of the distal phalanx of hand
english_description: This term applies if one or more of the distal phalanges of the hand are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.
A reduction in diameter of the distal phalanx of finger towards the distal end.

Trichorrhexis nodosa is the formation of nodes along the hair shaft through which breakage readily occurs. It is thus a focal defect in the hair fiber that is characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily. The result is defective, abnormally fragile hair.
An abnormality of hair pigmentation (color).

Abnormality of the growth of secondary sexual hair, which normally ensues during puberty. In males, secondary sexual hair usually comprises body hair, including underarm, abdominal, chest, and pubic hair. In females, secondary sexual hair usually comprises a lesser degree of body hair, most prominently underarm and pubic hair.

Distance between the hairline (trichion) and the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose), in the midline, more than two SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between the hairline and the glabella.
Flatness of the supraorbital portion of the frontal bones.
Complete absence of any auricular structures.
Increased thickness of the external ear.

english_term: Abnormality of the crus of the helix
english_description: An abnormality of the crus of the helix, which is the horizontal piece of cartilage located outside the ear canal that divides the upper and lower parts of the ear.
An abnormality of the antitragus, which is a small tubercle opposite to the tragus of the ear. The antitragus and the tragus are separated by the intertragic notch.

An abnormal horizontal axis orientation of the crus of the helix. That is, the main axis of the crus of the helix is perpendicular to the medial longitudinal axis of the ear, instead of sloping inferoposteriorly.
The presence of an abnormally prominent of the crus of the helix. That is, development of the crus helix to the same degree as an average antihelix stem or helix.
A unilateral absence of sensory perception of sound.
Distortion of the course of the normal folds of the ear and the appearance of supernumerary crura and folds.
A notched form of the helix of the ear. That is, a defect in the continuity of the helix, which may occur at any point along its length.
Abnormally prominent ear helix.
Decreased thickness of the helix of the ear.
Absence or underdevelopment of the ear lobes.
Attachment of the lobe to the side of the face at the lowest point of the lobe without curving upward.
Sharply demarcated, typically linear and approximately horizontal, indentations in the outer surface of the ear lobe.
An abnormal orientation of the earlobes such that they point out- and upward. That is, the lateral surface of ear lobe faces superiorly.
Abnormality of the temporal bone of the skull, which is situated at the sides and base of the skull roughly underlying the region of the face known as the temple.
An abnormality of the tragus.
Cyclopia is a congenital abnormality in which there is only one eye. That eye is centrally placed in the area normally occupied by the root of the nose.
Anisocoria, or unequal pupil size, may represent a benign physiologic variant or a manifestation of disease.
The presence of remnants of a fetal membrane that persist as strands of tissue crossing the pupil.
A malposition of the pupil owing to a developmental defect of the iris.
A tumor of the eye originating from cells of the retina.
A condition associated with a limitation of the horizontal ocular movement with retraction of the globe and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on adduction
Underdevelopment or absence of the nose or parts thereof.
Abnormally increased lacrimation, that is, excessive tearing (watering eye).
Complete absence of all nasal structures.
Increase in bulk of the ala nasi.
Increased aperture of the nostril.
The presence of only a single nostril.
Slender, slit-like aperture of the nostril.
Excess facial hair.
Lack or loss of the soft tissues between the zygomata and mandible.
Absence of the mandible.
The presence of an asymmetric mouth.

Complete or partial duplication of the phalanges of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones (bifid), two separate bones appearing side to side, or completely duplicated phalanges (proximal and distal phalanx of the thumb and/or 1st metacarpal). In contrast to the phalanges of the digits 2-5 (proximal, middle and distal), the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the thumb. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the thumb. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

english_term: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the 2nd finger
chinese_term: 第二指末节指骨部分重复
english_description: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of index finger, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

english_term: Complete duplication of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
chinese_term: 第三指中节指骨完全重复
english_description: Complete duplication of the middle phalanx of middle finger.

english_term: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the 3rd finger
chinese_term: 第三指末节指骨部分重复
english_description: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of middle finger, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

english_term: Partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger
chinese_term: 第三指近节指骨部分重复
english_description: Partial duplication of the third proximal phalanx of hand, seen on x-rays as a broad and/or bifid phalanx.

english_term: Partial duplication of the phalanx of hand
english_description: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

english_term: Complete duplication of the distal phalanges of the hand
english_description: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the distal phalanges of the hand.
Any abnormality of the fifth metacarpal bone.
A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance.
The epiphysis of the first metacarpal is localized at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone although an accessory epiphysis may be located at the distal end of the metacarpal.

chinese_term: 第一掌骨发育不良或发育不全
english_description: Aplasia or Hypoplasia affecting the 1st metacarpal. In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits).

Increased width of the 1st metacarpal. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
A developmental defect characterized by reduced length of the first metacarpal (long bone) of the hand.
Absent first metacarpal (long bone) of the hand.
Absence of the second long bone of the hand.
Short second metacarpal bone because of developmental hypoplasia.
Absence of the third long bone of the hand.
Short third metacarpal bone.
Absence of the fourth long bone of the hand.
Short fourth metacarpal bone.
Absence of the fifth long bone of the hand.
Short fifth metacarpal bone.
Developmental defect associated with absence of one or more metacarpal bones.
Diminished length of one or more metacarpal bones in relation to the others of the same hand or to the contralateral metacarpal.
Displacement of the big toe from its normal position.

english_term: Abnormality of the first metatarsal bone
english_description: An anomaly of the first metatarsal bone.
Visible increase in width of the hallux without an increase in the dorso-ventral dimension.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the hallux
chinese_term: 拇趾骨发育不良或发育不全

english_description: An increase in width in one or more phalanges of the big toe.

english_term: Symphalangism affecting the phalanges of the hallux

english_description: Partial or complete duplication of one or more phalanx of big toe.

chinese_term: 第一跖骨发育不良或发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the first metatarsal bone.
Increased side-to-side width of the first metatarsal bone.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the distal phalanx of the hallux
chinese_term: 拇趾末节趾骨发育不良或发育不全

english_term: Broad distal phalanx of the hallux
english_description: An increase in width of the distal phalanx of the big toe.

english_term: Bullet-shaped distal phalanx of the hallux
english_description: An abnormal morphology of the distal phalanx of the big toe, with a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.

english_term: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the hallux
english_description: Partial or complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of big toe.

english_term: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the hallux
chinese_term: 拇趾末节指骨部分重复

english_description: Complete duplication of one or more phalanx of big toe.

english_term: Aplasia of the distal phalanx of the hallux
chinese_term: 拇趾末节趾骨发育不全

english_description: A developmental defect characterized by the absence of the first metatarsal bone.
Short first metatarsal bone.
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the proximal phalanx of big toe.
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the big toe.
The presence of a supernumerary toe (not a hallux) involving the third or fourth metatarsal with associated osseous syndactyly.
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphyses of phalanges of the toes.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the toes
chinese_term: 趾骨发育不良或发育不全

english_description: Increased width of phalanx of one or more toes.
A deviation from the normal straight form of one or more toe phalanges.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the distal phalanges of the toes
chinese_term: 末节趾骨发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the distal phalanges of the toes.

english_term: Broad distal phalanx of the toes
english_description: Increased width of the distal phalanx of toe of one or more toes.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the middle phalanges of the toes
chinese_term: 中节趾骨发育不全或发育不良

english_description: A foot deformity resulting due to an abnormality affecting the bones of the foot (as well as muscle and soft tissue). In contrast if only the muscle and soft tissue are affected the term positional foot deformity applies.

english_term: Absent epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
english_description: Absence of one or more epiphyses of the phalanges of the fingers.

english_term: Cone-shaped epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
english_description: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphyses of the fingers of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of a phalanx.

english_term: Enlarged epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
english_description: Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the fingers with respect to age-dependent norms.

english_term: Ivory epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
english_description: Sclerosis of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the fingers, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.

english_term: Small epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
english_description: Abnormally small size of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the fingers with respect to age-dependent norms.

english_term: Aplasia of the middle phalanx of the hand
english_description: Absence of one or more middle phalanx of a finger.
Congenital hypoplasia of one or more proximal phalanx of finger.

english_term: Aplasia of the proximal phalanges of the hand
Cone-shaped epiphyses of the distal phalanges of the hand
Ivory epiphyses of the distal phalanges of the hand
english_description: Distal epiphyses of the hand are hard and dense like ivory. Such an epiphysis has a uniformly dense appearance on radiographs.

english_term: Stippling of the epiphyses of the distal phalanges of the hand
chinese_term: 末节指骨骨骺点状钙化

english_term: Cone-shaped epiphyses of the middle phalanges of the hand
Pseudoepiphyses of the middle phalanges of the hand
english_description: A secondary ossification center in the middle phalanges of the hand that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.

english_term: Cone-shaped epiphyses of the proximal phalanges of the hand
Pseudoepiphyses of the proximal phalanges of the hand
english_description: A secondary ossification center in the proximal phalanges of the hand that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.
Stomatitis is an inflammation of the mucous membranes of any of the structures in the mouth.

Height of the vermilion of the medial part of the lower lip more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the frontal view (subjective).
Increased pigmentation, either focal or generalized, of the mucosa of the mouth.
Fibrous band between the mucosal surfaces of the upper and lower alveolar ridges.
Any abnormality of the salivary glands, the exocrine glands that produce saliva.

english_term: Cleft of alveolar ridge of maxilla
english_description: A gap (cleft) affecting one of the alveolar ridges, which are the protuberances in the mouth that contain the sockets (alveoli) of the teeth. An alveolar cleft can affect all structures of the alveolar ridge, including the gingiva, other mucosa, periosteum, alveolar bone, and teeth.

Distance between the labial point of the incisive papilla to the midline junction of the hard and soft palate more than 2 SD below the mean (objective) or apparently decreased length of the hard palate (subjective).
Increased size and/or number of soft tissue folds on the palatal side of the maxillary alveolar ridge.
Lack of the uvula.

chinese_term: 悬雍垂发育不全／未发育
english_description: Underdevelopment or absence of the uvula.
A fistula which connects the oral cavity and the pharyngeal area via the aspects of the soft palate.
Absence or underdevelopment of the tongue.
Short or anteriorly attached lingual frenulum, associated with limited mobility of the tongue.
Tongue with a median apical indentation or fork.
Glossy appearance of the entire tongue surface.
Any abnormality of dentin.
An abnormally low-pitched voice.
A heterogeneous group of congenital spinal anomalies that result from defective closure of the neural tube early in fetal life.
A neoplasm affecting the spinal cord.
Absence (aplasia) of the sacrum.
Reduced inferior to superior extent of the thorax.
Stridor is a high pitched sound resulting from turbulent air flow in the upper airway.
The sternal cleft is a rare congenital anomaly resulting from a fusion failure of the sternum.
Accumulation of excessive amounts of lymphatic fluid (chyle) in the pleural cavity.
Absence or underdevelopment of the breasts.
Premature development of the breasts.

chinese_term: 横膈发育不全/发育不良
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the diaphragm.

english_term: Ebstein anomaly of the tricuspid valve
english_description: Ebstein's anomaly refers to an abnormally placed and deformed tricuspid valve characterized by apical displacement of the septal and posterior tricuspid valve leaflets, leading to atrialization of the right ventricle with a variable degree of malformation and displacement of the anterior leaflet.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
chinese_term: 腹壁肌群发育不良/发育不全
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the abdominal musculature.
An anomaly of the little toe.
One or more bent (flexed) joints of the second toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.

chinese_term: 第三趾趾骨发育不良/发育不全

english_description: One or more bent (flexed) joints of the fourth toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.

english_term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the 2nd toe
chinese_term: 第二趾趾骨发育不良/发育不全

english_term: Absent distal phalanx of the 2nd toe
english_description: Absence of distal phalanx of the second toe as a result of developmental aplasia.

In contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit (this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit) is either located postaxial (on the ulnar side of the hand, next to the little finger), preaxial (on the radial side of the hand, next to the thumb) or mesoaxial (somewhere central, between thumb and little finger), a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically, meaning anywhere else except post-,meso- or preaxial. In the literature this is sometimes referred to as Disorganisation-like Syndrome (OMIM223200).
A congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of supernumerary fingers or toes.
A bifid or bifurcated appearance of the femur as seen on x-rays, possible appearing as a more or less severe bowing of the upper leg. Might be associated with hip dysplasia on the affected side.
The retrograde (backwards) flow of blood through the pulmonary valve into the right ventricle during diastole.

An ostium primum atrial septal defect is located in the most anterior and inferior aspect of the atrial septum. The ostium primum refers to an anterior and inferior opening (ostium) within the septum primum, which divides the rudimentary atrium during fetal development. The ostium primum is normally sealed by fusion of the superior and inferior endocardial cushions around 5 weeks' gestation. Ostium primum defects result from a failure of the fusion of the embryologic endocardial cushion and septum primum.
A narrowing of the orifice of the tricuspid valve of the heart.
An abnormal connection between the epithelialised surface of the anal canal and the perianal skin.
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the colon. That is, there is an abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the colon.
An abnormal narrowing of the lumen of the esophagus.
An abnormal (non-anatomic) location of the spleen.
The presence of osteophytes (bone spurs), i.e., of bony projections originating from the acetabulum.
An exaggeration of the normal arched form of the acetabular roof such that it takes on a steep appearance.

Hermaphroditism refers to a discrepancy between the morphology of the gonads and that of the external genitalia. In female pseudohermaphroditism, the genotype is female (XX) and the gonads are ovaries, but the external genitalia are virilized.
The presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues either in the same or in opposite gonads. Affected persons have ambiguous genitalia and may have 46,XX or 46,XY karyotypes or 46,XX/XY mosaicism.
Abnormality of the male genital system.
Aplasia, that is failure to develop, of the ovary.

A developmental disorder characterized by the progressive loss of primordial germ cells in the developing ovaries of an embryo, leading to hypoplastic ovaries composed of wavy connective tissue with occasional clumps of granulosa cells, and frequently mesonephric or hilar cells.
The onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls.

chinese_term: 睾丸发育不全/发育不良
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the testes.
Testis not palpable in the scrotum or inguinal canal.
Increased urinary excretion of oligosaccharides (low molecular weight carbohydrate chains composed of at least three monosaccharide subunits), derived from a partial degradation of glycoproteins.

chinese_term: 血红素生物合成途径异常
english_description: An abnormality in the synthesis or catabolism of heme. Heme is composed of ferrous iron and protoporphyrin IX and is an essential molecule as the prosthetic group of hemeproteins such as hemoglobin, myoglobin, mitochondrial and microsomal cytochromes.
Abnormally increased excretion of porphyrins in the urine.

chinese_term: 膀胱发育不全/发育不良
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the urinary bladder.
Aplasia (absence) of the urinary bladder.
Persistence of the urachal canal resulting in a canal between the bladder and the umbilicus.
The presence of an abnormal membrane obstructing the urethra.
Abnormal increase in size of the upper limbs (due to an increase of the size of cells).
The ability of the elbow joint to move beyond its normal range of motion.
An abnormality of the hypothenar eminence, i.e., of the muscles on the ulnar side of the palm of the hand (i.e., on the side of the little finger).
Reduced muscle mass on the ulnar side of the palm, that is, reduction in size of the hypothenar eminence.
The absence of the major creases of the palm (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, or thenar crease).
An abnormality of the creases of the skin of palm of hand.
A narrow segment of significantly reduced circumference of a digit.
An abnormally increased length of the metacarpal bones.

chinese_term: 美人鱼综合症（并腿畸形）
english_description: A developmental defect in which the legs are fused together.

The kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it. Patellar subluxation refers to an unstable kneecap that does not slide centrally within its groove, i.e., a partial dislocation of the patella.
The ability of the knee joint to extend beyond its normal range of motion (the lower leg is moved beyond a straight position with respect to the thigh).
An abnormal limitation of knee joint mobility.
A bending or abnormal curvature of the fibula.
Duplication of the fibula. This may occur as a part of diplopodia (accessory tarsal or metatarsal bone). Diplopodia with double fibula is an extremely rare condition.
An abnormal limitation of the mobility of the ankle joint.
A condition in which the anterior part of the foot rotates outward away from the midline of the body and the heel remains straight.
Absence of the tarsal bones.
An ability of the toe joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
Toes that appear disproportionately long compared to the foot.
Calcification within the adrenal glands.
Absence or underdevelopment of the thymus.
Enlargement of the thymus.

The presence of ectopic thymus tissue. Normally, cells of the ventral bud of the third pharyngeal pouch detach and migrate in the eighth gestational week caudally and medially towards the location of the mature thyroid. They migrate further retrosternally into the superior mediastinum. There are two main ways ectopic thymus tissue can develop. Either cells detach along the descensus path and proliferate, thereby forming accessory thymus tissue, or the entire gland fails to descend.
An abnormality of the thyroid gland owing to the presence of a fibrous cyst resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct.
An abnormal increase in quantity or strength of fetal movements.
Gait apraxia affecting the ability to make walking movements with the legs.

A learning disorder characterized primarily by difficulties in learning to read and spell. Dyslectic children also exhibit a tendency to read words from right to left and to confuse letters such as b and d whose orientation is important for their identification. Children with dyslexia appear to be impaired in phonemic skills (the ability to associate visual symbols with the sounds they represent).
An acquired type of sensory aphasia where damage to the brain leads to the loss of the ability to read.

Inability to recognize objects not because of sensory deficit but because of the inability to combine components of sensory impressions into a complete pattern. Thus, agnosia is a neurological condition which results in an inability to know, to name, to identify, and to extract meaning from visual, auditory, or tactile impressions.
An inability or difficulty differentiating among the fingers of either hand as well as the hands of others.

A writing disability in the absence of motor or sensory deficits of the upper extremities, resulting in an impairment in the ability to write regardless of the ability to read and not due to intellectual impairment.

Inability to recognize the form of objects by touch without visual input. That is, an impairment in the recognition of objects based only on the texture, size, weight and three-dimensional form of the object in the absence of any major somatosensory deficit.
The tendency to repeat vocalizations made by another person.
Palatal myoclonus is characterized by myoclonic (rhythmic involuntary jerky) movements of the soft palate.

Spinal myoclonus is generally due to a tumor, infection, injury, or degenerative process of the spinal cord, and is characterized by involuntary rhythmic muscle contractions, usually at a rate of more than one per second. Myoclonus occurs synchronously in several muscles and can be increased in severity and frequency by fatigue or stress, but is usually unaffected by sensory stimuli. Spinal myoclonus ceases during sleep or anesthesia.
Paroxysmal episodes of vertigo.
The combination of pendular nystagmus, head nodding, and torticollis.
A paroxysmal, transient loss of memory function with preservation of immediate recall and remote memory but with a severe impairment of memory for recent events and ability to retain new information.

An intermittent cessation of airflow at the mouth and nose during sleep. Apneas of at least 10 seconds are considered important, but persons with sleep apnea may have apneas of 20 seconds to up to 2 or 3 minutes. Patients may have up to 15 events per hour of sleep.
Sleep apnea resulting from a transient abolition of the central drive to the ventilatory muscles.
An abnormally increased width of the cranial sutures for age-related norms (generally resulting from delayed closure).
An abnormally small sella turcica.
The presence of an abnormally thin calvarium.

The presence of convoluted folds and furrows formed from thickened skin of the scalp, resembling cerebriform pattern. The scalp has convoluted and elevated folds, 1 to 2 cm in thickness. The convolutions generally cannot be flattened by traction.
Nystagmus due to disturbance of the vestibular system; eye movements are rhythmic, with slow and fast components.
Bursts of large-amplitude multidirectional saccades without intersaccadic interval

Vertical nystagmus may present with either up-beating or down-beating eye movements or both. When present in the straight-ahead position of gaze it is referred to as upbeat nystagmus or downbeat nystagmus.
Downbeat nystagmus is a type of fixation nystagmus with the fast phase beating in a downward direction. It generally increases when looking to the side and down and when lying prone.

Fine, rapid twitching of individual muscle fibers with little or no movement of the muscle as a whole. If a motor neuron or its axon is destroyed, the muscle fibers it innervates undergo denervation atrophy. This leads to hypersensitivity of individual muscle fibers to acetyl choline so that they may contract spontaneously. Isolated activity of individual muscle fibers is generally so fine it cannot be seen through the intact skin, although it can be recorded as a short-duration spike in the EMG.

A type of paralysis in which a muscle becomes soft and yields to passive stretching, which results from loss of all or practically all peripheral motor nerves that innervated the muscle. Muscle tone is reduced and the affected muscles undergo extreme atrophy within months of the loss of innervation.
A localized myotonic contraction in a muscle in reaction to percussion (tapping with the examiner's finger, a rubber percussion hammer, or a similar object).
Severe or complete weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities.
Weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities. Paraplegia refers to a severe or complete loss of strength, whereas paraparesis refers to a relatively mild loss of strength.

An acute dystonic reaction with blepharospasm, periorbital twitches, and protracted fixed staring episodes. There may be a maximal upward deviation of the eyes in the sustained fashion. Oculogyric crisis can be triggered by a number of factors including neuroleptic medications.

A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints, or a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that lies significantly distal to the flexion crease that overlies the metacarpophalangeal joint of the adjacent fingers.
A finger resting on the dorsal surface of an adjacent digit when the hand is at rest.
An abnormality of the clivus, which is the inclined bony region of the posterior cranial fossa located between the sella turcica and the foramen magnum.
An abnormal vertical orientation of the clivus (which normally forms a kind of slope from the sella turcica down to the region of the foramen magnum).
An abnormally wavy surface or edge of the clavicles.
An abnormally wavy surface or edge of the ribs.

A midline anterior-posterior cleft of the epiglottis that involves at least two-thirds of the epiglottic leaf. It is a useful feature for clinical diagnosis because it appears to be very rare in syndromes other than Pallister-Hall-Syndrome and is also rare as an isolated malformation.

A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that is native to the site of origin, e.g., exostoses, nevi and soft tissue hamartomas. Although most hamartomas are benign, some histologic subtypes, e.g., neuromuscular hamartoma, may proliferate aggressively such as mesenchymal cystic hamartoma, Sclerosing epithelial hamartoma, Sclerosing metanephric hamartoma.
Elevated 7-dehydrocholesterol levels.
An abnormal elevation of phytanic acid.

english_term: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the femoral head
english_description: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the femur.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the femoral head.
A cystic lesion originating within the brain.

Cone-shaped epiphyses (also known as coned epiphyses) are epiphyses that invaginate into cupped metaphyses. That is, the epiphysis has a cone-shaped distal extension resulting from increased growth of the central portion of the epiphysis relative to its periphery.
Increased size of epiphyses.
An alteration of the normally smooth contour of the epiphysis leading to an irregular appearance.
Sclerosis of the epiphyses, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.
Reduction in the size or volume of epiphyses.
An abnormal predominance of type II muscle fibers (in general, this feature can only be observed on muscle biopsy).

A benign uni- or multicystic, intraosseous tumor of odontogenic origin, with a characteristic lining of parakeratinized stratified squamous epithelium and potential for aggressive, infiltrative behaviour.

Cutaneous skin tags also known as acrochorda or fibroepithelial polyps are small benign tumours that may either form secondarily over time primarily in areas where the skin forms creases, such as the neck, armpit or groin or may also be present at birth, in which case they usually occur in the periauricular region.
The presence of multiple pits (small, pinpoint-large indentations on the surface of the skin) located on the skin of sole of foot.

Benign tumors that are composed of fibrous or connective tissue. They can grow in all organs, arising from mesenchyme tissue. The term "fibroblastic" or "fibromatous" is used to describe tumors of the fibrous connective tissue. When the term fibroma is used without modifier, it is usually considered benign, with the term fibrosarcoma reserved for malignant tumors.
Angiofibroma consist of many often dilated vessels.
A fibroma of the heart.
The presence of a fibroma of the ovary.
A benign biphasic tumor of the breast with epithelial and stromal components.
Prominence of the malar process of the maxilla and infraorbital area appreciated in profile and from in front of the face.

A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between adjacent foot digits that involves at least half of the proximodistal length of one of the two involved digits; or, a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits of the foot that does not meet the prior objective criteria.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the skeleton.
Absence or underdevelopment of the toenail.
Absence of the anterior pituitary gland resulting from a developmental defect.
Underdevelopment of the anterior pituitary gland.

Facial nerve palsy is a dysfunction of cranial nerve VII (the facial nerve) that results in inability to control facial muscles on the affected side with weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure. This can either be present in unilateral or bilateral form.

english_term: Abnormality of the epiphyses of the feet
english_description: Any abnormality of the epiphyses of the feet.
The presence of a cleft in the cerebral cortex unilaterally or bilaterally, usually located in the frontal area.

english_term: Elevated alkaline phosphatase of hepatic origin
chinese_term: 肝源性碱性磷酸酶升高
english_description: An abnormally increased level of liver isoforms of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood.

english_term: Elevated alkaline phosphatase of bone origin
chinese_term: 骨源性碱性磷酸酶升高
english_description: An abnormally increased level of bone isoforms of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood.
Abnormality of the nasal cavity (the cavity includes and starts at the nares and reaches all the way through to the and includes the choanae, the posterior nasal apertures).
Abnormal narrowing (stenosis) of the midnasal cavity, i.e., of the middle nasal meatus, which in neonates can cause respiratory distress.
An abnormal lack of stability of the cervical spine.
Any abnormal increase or reduction in skin elasticity.
An abnormally increased ability of the skin to permit light to pass through (translucency) such that subcutaneous structures such as veins display an increased degree of visibility.

An abnormal degree of flatness of the Ala of nose, which can be defined as a reduced nasal elevation index (lateral depth of the nose from the tip of the nose to the insertion of the nasal ala in the cheek x 100 divided by the side-to-side breadth of the nasal alae).

An abnormality of the premaxilla (the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla) causing it to appear relatively small in size compared to the other parts of the maxilla or other facial structures.
An abnormality of the Dura mater.
A developmental defect characterized by aplasia of the Falx cerebri.
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more epiphyses.
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of an epiphysis.

english_term: Patchy variation in bone mineral density
english_description: Patchy (irregular) changes in bone mineral density with patches of bone showing an increased density side to side with patches that are affected by reduction of mineral density. This is sometimes referred to as a moth-eaten appearance on x-rays.
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any bone of the skeleton of hand.
An abnormality of the Diencephalon, which together with the cerebrum (telencephalon) makes up the forebrain.
An abnormality of the thalamus.

english_term: Fusion of the left and right thalami
english_description: A developmental defect characterized by fusion of the left and right halves of the thalamus.
The presence of bilateral coxa valga.

english_term: Hypoplasia of the anterior nasal spine
english_description: Underdevelopment of the anterior nasal spine of maxilla.
A congenital defect characterized by absence of the Maxilla.
Underdevelopment of the zygomatic bone. That is, a reduction in size of the zygomatic bone, including the zygomatic process of the temporal bone of the skull, which forms part of the zygomatic arch.

english_term: Abnormality of the curvature of the vertebral column
english_description: The presence of an abnormal curvature of the vertebral column.
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any bone of the skeleton of foot.
Enuresis occurring during sleeping hours.

chinese_term: 组织非特异性碱性磷酸酶升高
english_description: An abnormally increased level of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood.

A hand or foot with more than five digits that has a recognizable A/P axis of symmetry. The axis can lie within a normally formed or partially duplicated digit resembling a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe, or hallux. Alternatively, the axis can be in an interdigital space with a flanking pair of digits that resemble a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe or hallux. The most lateral digits on each side of the hand typically resemble fifth fingers/toes.
Mirror image duplication of digits affecting the feet.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two to five.
A kind of congenital cataract that is characterized by a hollow sphere of punctate opacities involving the fetal nucleus and that usually occurs bilaterally.
A type of congenital cataract in which the opacity follows the anterior or posterior Y suture.
A type of Congenital cataract in which the opacities occupy the subcapsular cortex at the anterior or posterior pole of the lens.
A type of nuclear cataract involving congenital dust-like (pulverulent) opacity of the embryonal and fetal nucleus.
An abnormal deviation from normal levels of immunoglobulins in blood.
An increased level of gamma globulin (immunoglobulin) in the blood.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers four and five.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to five (complete syndactyly of all fingers of the hand).
Syndactyly with fusion of the fingers two to four.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one and two.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to five (complete syndactyly of all toes of the foot).
Syndactyly with fusion of toes two to four.
An abnormality of the texture of the hair.
An abnormality of the distribution of hair growth.
An abnormal hair whorl (that is, a patch of hair growing in the opposite direction of the rest of the hair).
An asymmetriy, i.e., difference in size, shape or position between the left and right ear.

english_term: Advanced pneumatization of the mastoid process
english_description: An abnormally advanced degree of pneumatization (i.e., formation of air cells) in the mastoid process with respect to age-dependent norms.
Abnormal prominence of the corneal nerve fibers.

english_term: Cherry red spot of the macula
english_description: Pallor of the perifoveal macula of the retina with appearance of a small circular reddish choroid shape as seen through the fovea centralis due to relative transparancy of the macula.

Nodular changes affecting the eyelids may have many different causes such as cystic lesions (chalaziae, hordeolae), lipogranulomas, melanomas, infectious diseases (Molluscum contagiosum) and many more.
Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the eyelid.

Tumor-like growths that consist of replacement of the medullary bone with fibrous tissue, causing the expansion and weakening of the areas of bone involved. Especially when involving the skull or facial bones, the lesions can cause externally visible deformities. The skull is often, but not necessarily, affected, and any other bone or bones may be involved. Fibrous dysplasia can either effect isolated bones (Monostotic fibrous dysplasia) or also generalized all bones of the body (Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia).

chinese_term: 多骨性骨纤维发育不良
english_description: Fibrous dysplasia of the bones were lesions are localized in many bones throughout of the body. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia is a cardinal feature of McCune-Albright syndrome.

chinese_term: 单骨性骨纤维发育不良
english_description: Fibrous dysplasia of the bones were lesions are localized in only one bone.

Osteopoikilosis is a benign, asymptomatic sclerotic dysplasia of the bones. It affects both male and female and may be seen at any age. Radiographically sclerotic circular or ovoid lesions are usually symmetrically distributed in a periarticular location. Lesions can increase or decrease in size and number in serial radiographs or even disappear and do not have increased bone radiotracer uptake.

A lamellar pattern visible on radiographs and mainly localized at the metaphyses of the long tubular bones. Pathologic-anatomical studies revealed that these benign signs on x-rays are the result of a juvenile metaphyseal bone necrosis. Calcifications in the necrotic marrow lead to this lamellar or lattice-like appearance.
An abnormal accumulation of excess fluid in the lower extremity resulting in swelling of the feet and extending upward to the lower leg.
Diminished length of a metatarsal bone, with resultant proximal displacement of the associated toe.
A developmental abnormality characterized by the absence (aplasia) of a metatarsal bone.

english_term: Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the toes

english_description: An abnormal distribution of eyebrow hair growth in the medial direction.
Positioning of a lacrimal punctum other than at the medial margins of the eyelid.

Blepharochalasis is characterized by recurrent, non-painful, nonerythematous episodes of eyelid edema. It has been divided into hypertrophic and atrophic forms. In the hypertrophic form recurrent edema results in orbital fat herniation through a weakened orbital septum. Most patients who have blepharochalasis present in an atrophic condition with atrophy of redundant eyelid skin and superior nasal fat pads.
