Loss of elasticity of the upper and lower eyelids causing the skin to sag and bulge.
A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the chin.
Midline deficiency of the mandible and some or all overlying tissues.
An anomaly of the temporomandibular joint.
Prominent positioning of the premaxilla in relation to the rest of the maxilla, the facial skeleton, or mandible. Not necessarily caused by an increase in size (hypertrophy of) the premaxilla.
Aplasia of a toe. That is, absence of all phalanges of a non-hallux digit of the foot and the associated soft tissues.
Increased width of the columella.

A chordoma is a tumors that arises from embryonic remnants of the notochord along the length of the neuraxis. Chordomas generally occur in the sacrum, intracranially at the clivus, or along the spinal axis.
Insertion of the posterior columella below the nasal base.
Decreased length of the eyelashes (subjective).
Abnormal thickening of the skin localized to the palm of the hand.
Deposition of calcium salts in a tissue or location in which calcification does not normally occur.
The presence of a cyst, fistula, or abscess in the sacrococcygeal region (gluteal crease) characteristically accompanied by hair and skin folds.
A sinus in the coccygeal region (the region of the intergluteal cleft). A pilonidal sinus often contains hair and skin debris.

A developmental defect characterized by abnormal connection of one or more pulmonary veins to the superior or inferior vena cava, the right atrium, or the coronary sinus, resulting in a left-to-right shunt of oxygenated blood.
A form of anomalous pulmonary venous return in which not all pulmonary veins drain abnormally. Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return frequently involves one or both of the veins from one lung.
The presence of an additional membrane in the left or right cardiac atrium which results in the subdivision of the affected atrium (and thus in total three atria, whence the name).

A developmental defect of the aortic arch system in which the trachea and esophagus are completely encircled by connected segments of the aortic arch and its branches. This occurs if the normal process of regression and persistence of the bilateral embryonic aortic arches fails.
Over-sensitivity to certain frequency ranges of sound.
Skin dimples are cutaneous indentations that are the result of tethering of the skin to underlying structures (bone) causing an indentation.
Redness of the skin, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the uterus.
The presence of a neoplasm of the urinary system.
The presence of a neoplasm of the testis.

chinese_term: 睾丸间质细胞发育不全
english_description: Underdevelopment of the interstitial (Leydig) cells of the testis. These cells produce testosterone.
Hypertrophy or overdevelopment of the interstitial (Leydig) cells of the testis. These cells produce testosterone.

Reduced ability affecting mainly visuospatial cognition which may be tested using pattern construction (for example by Differential Ability Scales, which test a person's strengths and weaknesses across a range of intellectual abilities).
A glioma affecting the cerebellum.
A glioma affecting the brainstem.

A hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular neoplasm that arises almost exclusively in the central nervous system. Hemangioblastomas consist of a tightly packed cluster of small blood vessels forming a mass of up to 1 or 2 cm in diameter.
A neoplasm of the pineal gland.
Lack of paramedian peaks and median notch of the upper lip vermilion.

Reduced bulkiness of the crease or fold of skin running from the lateral margin of the nose, where nasal base meets the skin of the face, to a point just lateral to the corner of the mouth (cheilion or commissure).
Inner aspect of the upper lip vermilion (normally apposing the teeth) visible in a frontal view, i.e., the presence of an everted upper lip.
Triangular appearance of the oral aperture with the apex in the midpoint of the upper vermilion and the lower vermilion forming the base.
Gentle upward curve of the upper lip vermilion such that the center is placed well superior to the commissures.
Visible space between the dental arches in occlusion.
Tongue extending beyond the alveolar ridges or teeth at rest.
Increased width of the uvula (subjective finding).
Increased length of the uvula.
Decreased length of the uvula.
Hair growth from a single point on the scalp in any location other than lateral to the midline and close to the vertex of the skull.

A congenital, hairless plaque consisting of overgrown epidermis, sebaceous glands, hair follicles, apocrine glands and connective tissue. They are a variant of epidermal naevi. Sebaceous naevi most often appear on the scalp, but they may also arise on the face, neck or forehead. At birth, a sevaceous nevus typically appears as a solitary, smooth, yellow-orange hairless patch. Sebaceous naevi become more pronounced around adolescence, often appearing bumpy, warty or scaly.
Epidermal naevi are due to an overgrowth of the epidermis and may be present at birth (50%) or develop during childhood.
A type of nevus sebaceous with a linear form, raised borders and yellowish color.

A generalized tonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by bilateral limb stiffening or elevation, often with neck stiffening without a subsequent clonic phase. The tonic activity can be a sustained abnormal posture, either in extension or flexion, sometimes accompanied by tremor of the extremities.

Atonic seizure is a type of motor seizure characterized by a sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone without apparent preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting about 1 to 2 seconds, involving head, trunk, jaw, or limb musculature.

chinese_term: 伴大笑的局灶情绪性发作
english_description: Focal emotional seizure with laughing (gelastic) is characterized by bursts of laughter or giggling, usually without appropriate related emotion of happiness, and described as 'mirthless'.
An overlap of the bony plates of the skull in an infant, with or without early closure.

english_term: Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve
english_description: Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve.

english_term: Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve
english_description: Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve.

english_term: Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve
english_description: Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve sometimes also referred to as the facial nerve.
Intermittent clonic or tonic contraction of muscles supplied by facial nerve. Muscles are relaxed in between contractions.
A reduced ability to discriminate between different temperatures.
A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation). This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus.
A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position.

Pain is an unpleasant sensation that can range from mild, localized discomfort to agony, whereby the physical part of pain results from nerve stimulation and is often accompanied by an emotional component. This term groups abnormalities in pain sensation presumed to result from abnormalities related to the specific nerve fibers that carry the pain impulses to the brain.
Spontaneous pain is a kind of neuropathic pain which occurs without an identifiable trigger.

chinese_term: 与疼痛相关的营养改变
english_description: Trophic changes is a term used to describe abnormalities in the area of pain that include primarily wasting away of the skin, tissues, or muscle, thinning of the bones, and changes in how the hair or nails grow, including thickening or thinning of hair or brittle nails.
A pattern of sensory loss with selective loss of touch sensation and proprioception without loss of pain and temperature, or vice-versa.
An abnormal concentration of copper.
Decreased concentration of ceruloplasmin in the blood.

chinese_term: 高浓度非铜蓝蛋白结合型血清铜离子
english_description: An increased concentration of non ceruloplasmin bound copper in the blood.
An abnormality in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG) and being identified at multiple locations (foci).
Multifocal slowing of cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
Diffuse slowing of cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).

english_term: EEG with persistent abnormal rhythmic activity
chinese_term: 脑电图，异常的持续性节律活动
脑电图，棘慢复合波（2.5-3.5赫兹）
english_description: The presence of complexes of spikes and waves (2.5-3.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG).

chinese_term: 大于3.5赫兹棘慢复合波脑电图
english_description: The presence of complexes of spikes and waves (>3.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG).

Complexes of spikes (<70 ms) and sharp waves (70-200 ms), which are sharp transient waves that have a strong association with epilepsy, in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).

The burst suppression pattern in electroencephalography refers to a characteristic periodic pattern of low voltage (<10 microvolts) suppressed background and a relatively shorter pattern of higher amplitude slow, sharp, and spiking complexes.
EEG abnormalities (epileptiform discharges) evoked by flashing lights or black and white striped patterns.

english_term: EEG with periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges
chinese_term: 脑电图，周期性一侧癫痫样放电
english_description: Periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs)are periodic, lateralized, and epileptiform. PLEDs show a relatively constant interval between discharges (0.5 to 3 seconds).
A type of motor delay characterized by a delay in acquiring the ability to control the fingers and hands.
A delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.
Severe mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 20-34.

An enduring pattern of uncooperative, defiant, and hostile behavior toward authority figures that does not involve major antisocial violations, is not accounted for by the child's developmental stage, and results in significant functional impairment. A certain level of oppositional behavior is common in children and adolescents.
An incomplete closure of the abdominal wall.

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed. With dyssynergia, a voluntary movement appears broken down into its component parts.

Incoordination of movement caused by a deficit in the sensory nervous system. Sensory ataxia can be distinguished from cerebellar ataxia by asking the patient to close his or her eyes. Persons with cerebellar ataxia show only a minimal worsening of symptoms, whereas persons with sensory ataxia show a marked worsening of symptoms.
An inversion of the T-wave (which is normally positive).
Atrophy of the cervical segment of the spinal cord.
The presence of xanthomas (intra-and extra-cellular accumulations of cholesterol) extensor tendons (typically over knuckles, Achilles tendon, knee, and elbows).

A diagnostic reflex elicited by stimulation of the skin over the surface of the lateral malleolus of the foot. The Chaddock refelx is present if there is extension of one or more or all of the toes with or without fanning of them when the external inframalleolar skin is stimulated. The Chaddock sign, similar to the Babinski sign, is taken to be an indication of disease of the spinocortical (pyramidal) tract.
An abnormal level of a circulating protein in the blood.

The presence during the prenatal period of a cystic mass with multiple septa with multiple, asymmetric, thin-walled cysts near the posterior aspect of the neck. Fetal cystic hygroma can be defined as nuchal translucency with or without septations measuring greater than 3.0 mm.
The presence of an abnormally large hypoechoic space in the posterior fetal neck (usually detected on prenatal ultrasound examination).
An abnormality of the umbilical cord, which is the cord connecting the developing embryo or fetus to the placenta.
A congenital disorder of the pulmonary valve in which the orifice of the valve fails to develop.
A congenital disorder of the aortic valve in which the orifice of the valve fails to develop.
Shortening of the extremities affecting primarily the distal parts of the limbs (hands and feet) in relation to the other segments of the limbs.
A disease where there is cellular death (necrosis) of bone components due to interruption of the blood supply.

chinese_term: 软骨下缺血性骨质吸收碎裂
english_description: A joint disorder caused by blood deprivation in the subchondral bone causing the subchondral bone to die in a process called avascular necrosis. The bone is then reabsorbed by the body, leaving the articular cartilage it supported prone to damage. The result is fragmentation (dissection) of both cartilage and bone, and the free movement of these osteochondral fragments within the joint space, causing pain and further damage.

A developmental growth retardation of the vertebral end plates that may lead to secondary destruction of the vertebral end plates and protrusion of the nucleus pulposus into the vertebral body (so called Schmorl's nodes as seen on x-rays).

english_term: Abnormal circulating branched chain amino acid concentration
chinese_term: 支链族氨基酸代谢异常
english_description: Any deviation from the normal concentration of a branched chain family amino acid in the blood circulation.
Any deviation from the normal concentration of glycine in the blood circulation.
An elevated plasma concentration of sarcosine.
An elevated urinary concentration of sarcosine.
Any deviation from the normal concentration of threonine in the blood circulation.
Any deviation from the normal concentration of glutamine in the blood circulation.

chinese_term: 组氨酸族氨基酸代谢异常
english_description: An abnormality of a histidine metabolic process.
An increased concentration of histidine in the blood.
Any deviation from the normal concentration of arginine in the blood circulation.
An increased concentration of valine in the blood.
An increased concentration of leucine in the blood.
An increased concentration of isoleucine in the blood.

english_term: Abnormal circulating pyruvate family amino acid concentration
chinese_term: 丙酮酸族氨基酸代谢异常
english_description: An abnormality of a pyruvate family amino acid metabolic process.
An abnormality of an alanine metabolic process.
Any deviation from the normal concentration of tyrosine in the blood circulation.
Zonular cataracts are defined to be cataracts that affect specific regions of the lens.
A form of cataract in which the lens substance has shrunk, leaving a collapsed, flattened capsule with little or no cortex or epithelium on the lens.
A type of cataract affecting the anterior pole of lens immediately adjacent to ('beneath') the lens capsule.
A cataract that affects the posterior part of the cortex of the lens.

chinese_term: 二价无机阳离子稳态平衡异常
english_description: An abnormality of divalent inorganic cation homeostasis.
An increased level of xanthine in the blood circulation.
An increased concentration of xanthine in the urine.

english_term: Abnormality of the upper urinary tract
english_description: An abnormality of the upper urinary tract.

english_term: Abnormality of the lower urinary tract
english_description: An abnormality of the lower urinary tract.
An abnormality of the external nose.
An abnormality of the nasal bone, comprising the left nasal bone and the right nasal bone.

chinese_term: 鼻骨发育不全/发育不良
english_description: Absence or underdevelopment of the nasal bone.
Absence of the nasal bone.
Echogenic bowel is defined as fetal bowel with homogenous areas of echogenicity that are equal to or greater than that of surrounding bone.

Mild pyelectasis is defined as a hypoechoic spherical or elliptical space within the renal pelvis that measures at least 5mm and not more than 10 mm. The measurement is taken on a transverse section through the fetal renal pelvis using the maximum anterior-to-posterior measurement.
The presence of dilatation of the renal pelvis.

A kind of ventriculomegaly occurring in the fetal period and usually diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound. Cerebral ventriculomegaly is defined by atrial measurements 10 mm or more. Mild ventriculomegaly (MVM) is defined as measurements between 10 and 15 mm. Measurements are obtained from an axial plane at the level of the thalamic nuclei just below the standard image to measure the BPD (PMID:16100637).
A form of hydrocephalus in which the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the cerebral ventricular system or in the outlets of the CSF to the arachnoid space is obstructed.
Underdevelopment of the right-sided structures of the heart.
The presence of a dilated urinary bladder.
Fetal megacystis is an abnormally enlarged bladder identified at any gestational age.
A developmental defect resulting in an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra.
A bilateral form of agenesis of the kidney.

english_term: Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation of the lung
chinese_term: 先天性肺囊性腺瘤样畸形
english_description: Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM) can be diagnosed prenatally if ultrasound shows a cystic or solid lung tumor. A CCAM does not have systemic arterial blood supply (in contrast to bronchopulmonary sequenstration). It is a cystic area within the lung that originates from abnormal embryogenesis.
Any deviation from the normal concentration of phytanic acid in the blood circulation.
An abnormality of glycolipid metabolism.
An abnormality of an erythrocyte cell surface molecule.

english_term: Absence of Lutheran antigen on erythrocytes
english_description: Absence of the Lutheran antigen (a type I integral membrane glycoprotein) from the surface of red blood cells.

chinese_term: 红细胞 生成不足性贫血
english_description: A kind of anemia characterized by inadequate production of erythrocytes.
A deviation from the normal count of B cells, i.e., the cells that are formed in the bone marrow, migrate to the peripheral lymphatic system, and mature into plasma cells or memory cells.
An abnormal decrease from the normal count of B cells.
A functional abnormality of the immune system.
A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of many (more than three) gene loci.

A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of a few gene loci. It is recommended this term be used for traits governed by three loci, although it is noted that usage of this term in the literature is not uniform.
A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of two gene loci.
An abnormality of the intrinsic pathway (also known as the contact activation pathway) of the coagulation cascade.

english_term: Abnormality of the common coagulation pathway
english_description: An abnormality of blood coagulation, common pathway.
Involuntary urine leakage synchronous with exertion, or actions such as sneezing, or coughing.
Abnormality of the striatum, which is the largest nucleus of the basal ganglia, comprising the caudate, putamen and ventral striatum, including the nucleus accumbens.

english_term: Chromosomal breakage induced by ionizing radiation
chinese_term: 电离辐射诱发的染色体断裂
english_description: Increased amount of chromosomal breaks in cultured blood lymphocytes or other cells induced by treatment with ionizing radiation.

An abnormal increase of bone mineral density, that is, of the amount of matter per cubic centimeter of bones which is often referred to as osteosclerosis. Osteosclerosis can be detected on radiological examination as an increased whiteness (density) of affected bones.
Abnormally increased formation of dense trabecular bone tissue. Despite the increased density of bone tissue, osteopetrotic bones tend to be more fracture-prone than normal.
A severe form of myopia with greater than -6.00 diopters.
An abnormality of the systemic arterial tree, which consists of the aorta and other systemic arteries.

chinese_term: 碳水化合物代谢/体内稳态平衡异常
english_description: A deviation from the normal concentration of a carbohydrate in the blood circulation.

chinese_term: 葡萄糖内稳态平衡异常
english_description: Abnormality of glucose homeostasis.
An abnormality of the metabolism of mucopolysaccharide.

chinese_term: 循环系统内酶浓度水平异常

english_description: An abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract.
Abnormal functionality of the cardiovascular system.

chinese_term: 阴道发育不全/发育不良
english_description: Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the vagina.
An abnormality of the fallopian tube.
The presence of hemorrhage within the body.
An abnormality of the homeostasis (concentration) of iron cation.
An impairment of a fructose metabolic process.
The presence of amyloid deposition in one or more tissues. Amyloidosis may be defined as the extracellular deposition of amyloid in one or more sites of the body.
An abnormality of the cortex of the kidney.
An altered ability of the kidneys to void urine and/or specific substances.
An abnormality of the helix. The helix is the outer rim of the ear that extends from the insertion of the ear on the scalp (root) to the termination of the cartilage at the earlobe.

english_term: Abnormality of the intrahepatic bile duct
english_description: An abnormality of the intrahepatic bile duct.
An abnormal concentration of potassium.

chinese_term: 血促肾上腺皮质激素水平异常
english_description: An abnormal concentration of corticotropin in the blood.
The presence of an altered number of of permanent teeth.
Agenesis of premolar tooth.

chinese_term: 下颌前臼齿（前磨牙）发育不全
english_description: Agenesis of mandibular premolar.
Agenesis of molar tooth.
Agenesis of secondary molar tooth.

english_term: Agenesis of first permanent molar tooth
english_description: Agenesis of either maxillary first permanent molar or mandibular first permanent molar or both.

english_term: Dentinogenesis imperfecta limited to primary teeth
english_description: Developmental dysplasia of dentin affecting only the primary dentition.
An abnormality of the structure or composition of the teeth.
Misaligned incisor.
An abnormal conical morphology of the incisor tooth.
A supernumerary tooth in the midline between the maxillary central incisors.
The presence of an odontoma.
The presence of one or more teeth additional to the normal number.
A developmental defect of tooth color.
An abnormality of canine tooth.
A tooth that has not erupted because of local impediments (overcrowding or fibrous gum overgrowth).
Increased size of the incisor tooth.
A form of hypomineralization of enamel characterized by reduced calcification.
A form of hypomineralization of enamel characterized by a chalky appearance of the enamel with orange, brown, or white color.
Talon cusp is an accessory cusp located near the cingulum (the portion of the lingual or palatal aspect of the tooth that forms a convex protuberance at the cervical third of the anatomic crown).
The union of two separately developing tooth germs typically leading to one less tooth than normal in the affected dental arch.
Mulberry molars are irregular teeth generally affecting the first molars and are characterized by a grossly deformed crown imitating, as the name implies, the surface of a mulberry.
Maxillary teeth cover the mandibular teeth when biting to an increased degree. The feature is defined as a vertical overlap of the maxillary incisors over the mandibular incisors that exceeds 2 mm.
A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.

A sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure. Limited forms may occur: Grimacing, head nodding, or subtle eye movements. Epileptic spasms frequently occur in clusters. Infantile spasms are the best known form, but spasms can occur at all ages

A type of apraxia that is characterized by difficulty or inability to execute speech movements because of problems with coordination and motor problems, leading to incorrect articulation. An increase of errors with increasing word and phrase length may occur.
Unilateral paresis (weakness) with spasticity of the affected muscles and increased tendon reflexes.
An abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the intestine.
An abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the ileum.

english_term: Abnormal left ventricular outflow tract morphology
english_description: An abnormality of the outflow tract of the left ventricle.
An decrease in the amount of intravascular fluid, particularly in the volume of the circulating blood.
Recurrent episodes of ulceration of the oral mucosa, typically presenting as painful, sharply circumscribed fibrin-covered mucosal defects with a hyperemic border.
A recurrent form of sinusitis.
A chronic form of sinusitis.

Inflammation of the tonsils that has occurred repeatedly. The definition of recurrent may vary somewhat, but the criteria used recently as a measure of severity were five or more episodes of true tonsillitis per year, symptoms recurring for at least a year, and episodes that are disabling and that prevent normal functioning. In some cases recurrent tonsillitis may be related to immunosusceptibility. Evidence exists for a genetic predisposition for recurrent tonsillitis.

chinese_term: NFKB1依赖的细胞因子产生缺陷
english_description: An impairment in the production by leukocytes of NFKB1-dependent cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha and interferon-alpha.

english_term: Abnormality of tumor necrosis factor secretion
chinese_term: 肿瘤坏死因子分泌异常
english_description: An abnormality in the production or cellular release of tumor necrosis factor.
Nasal ridge curving posteriorly to an imaginary line that connects the nasal root and tip.
Any morphological abnormality of the skin.
The presence of inflammation of the skin. That is, an abnormality of the skin resulting from the local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes.
An abnormality of the morphology of the epidermis.
A type of eczema that occurs in the lips and perioral area.
The presence of a rash (change of color and texture) of the perianal skin.

A furuncle (boil) is a skin infection involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue. Chronic furunculosis refers to recurrent episodes of furuncles, often caused by recurrent staphylococcus infection.
An abnormally increased sensitivity to the effects of ionizing radiation.
Mild fever that does not exceed 38.5 degrees centigrade.
Absence of the sweat glands.

A typical absence seizure is a type of generalised non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by its sudden onset, interruption of ongoing activities, a blank stare, possibly a brief upward deviation of the eyes. Usually the patient will be unresponsive when spoken to. Duration is a few seconds to half a minute with very rapid recovery. Although not always available, an EEG would usually show 3 Hz generalized epileptiform discharges during the event.

chinese_term: 失神发作伴眼睑肌阵挛
english_description: An absence with eyelid myoclonia seizure is a type of generalized non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by forced upward jerking of the eyelids during an absence seizure.

Myoclonic absence seizure is a type of generalized non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by an interruption of ongoing activities, a blank stare and rhythmic three-per-second myoclonic movements, causing ratcheting abduction of the upper limbs leading to progressive arm elevation, and associated with 3 Hz generalized spike-wave discharges on the electroencephalogram. Duration is typically 10-60 s. Whilst impairment of consciousness may not be obvious the ILAE classified this seizure as a generalized non-motor seizure in 2017.

chinese_term: 非典型失神癫痫持续状态
english_description: Atypical absence status epilepticus is a type of generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma that is semiologically a prolonged atypical absence seizure.
Typical absence seizures starting before the age of 4 years.

chinese_term: 局灶性运动性癫痫发作
english_description: A type of focal-onset seizure characterized by a motor sign as its initial semiological manifestation.

chinese_term: 局灶性自主神经癫痫发作
english_description: An autonomic seizure is a type of focal non-motor seizure characterized by alteration of autonomic nervous system function as the initial semiological feature.
A focal sensory seizure is a type seizure beginning with a subjective sensation.

english_term: Focal sensory seizure with auditory features
chinese_term: 伴有听觉特征的局灶性感觉发作
english_description: A seizure characterized by elementary auditory phenomena including buzzing, ringing, drumming or single tones as its first clinical manifestation.

english_term: Focal autonomic seizure with epigastric sensation/nausea/vomiting/other gastrointestinal phenomena
chinese_term: 局灶性自主神经性癫痫发作伴上腹部感觉/恶心/呕吐/其他胃肠道现象
english_description: A type of focal autonomic seizure characterised by symptoms or signs pertaining to the gastrointestinal system as the initial semiological feature.

english_term: Focal sensory seizure with olfactory features
chinese_term: 有嗅觉特征的局灶性感觉癫痫
english_description: Seizures characterized by olfactory phenomena as its first clinical manifestation.

english_term: Focal sensory seizure with somatosensory features
chinese_term: 伴躯体感觉特征的局灶性感觉性癫痫发作
english_description: A seizure characterized by sensory phenomena including tingling, numbness, electric-shock like sensation, pain, sense of movement, or desire to move as its first clinical manifestation.

english_term: Focal sensory seizure with visual features
chinese_term: 伴有视觉特征的局灶性感觉发作
english_description: A seizure characterized by elementary visual hallucinations such as flashing or flickering lights/colours, or other shapes, simple patterns, scotomata, or amaurosis as its first clinical manifestation.

A type of focal motor seizure characterized by sudden, brief (<100 ms) involuntary single or multiple contraction(s) of muscles(s) or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal). Myoclonus is less regularly repetitive and less sustained than is clonus.
A type of focal motor seizure characterized by sustained increase in muscle contraction, lasting a few seconds to minutes.

chinese_term: 局灶性癫痫伴眼睑肌阵挛
english_description: Focal seizure with eyelid myoclonia, not eyelid myoclonias in the context of absence seizures.

Generalized clonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by sustained bilateral jerking, either symmetric or asymmetric, that is regularly repetitive and involves the same muscle groups.

chinese_term: 全面性肌阵挛-失张力发作
english_description: A generalized myoclonic-atonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterized by a myoclonic jerk followed by an atonic motor component.

A short generalized seizure, of a duration of <15 min, not recurring within 24 h, occurring during a febrile episode not caused by an acute disease of the nervous system intracranial infection or severe metabolic disturbance.

A febrile seizure that has any of the following features: focal semiology (or associated with post-ictal neurologic abnormalities beyond drowsiness, such as a Todd's paresis), prolonged seizure beyond 15 minutes, or recurring (occurring more than once) in a 24 hour period.

A focal seizure characterized at onset by predominantly proximal limb or axial muscles producing irregular sequential ballistic movements, such as pedaling, pelvic thrusting, thrashing, rocking movements.

Epileptiform activity refers to distinctive EEG waves or complexes distinguished from background activity found in in a proportion of human subjects with epilepsy, but which can also be found in subjects without seizures. Interictal epileptiform activity refers to such activity that occurs in the absence of a clinical or subclinical seizure.

chinese_term: 脑电图局灶性癫痫样放电
english_description: EEG discharges recorded in particular areas of a localized (focal) abnormality in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).

english_term: Focal EEG discharges with secondary generalization
chinese_term: 局灶性脑放电继发泛化
english_description: Focal EEG discharges that secondarily spread to both hemispheres and can then be recorded over the entire scalp.

english_term: Uni- and bilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges
chinese_term: 单侧和双侧多灶性痫样放电
english_description: Epileptiform discharges identified at multiple locations temporarily in both hemispheres and temporarily in one hemisphere.
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec.

english_term: EEG with series of focal spikes
english_description: Focal spikes occurring for several seconds.

english_term: EEG with focal sharp slow waves
english_description: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.

chinese_term: 脑电图，伴广泛性癫痫样放电
english_description: EEG discharges recorded on the entire scalp typically seen in persons with epilepsy.

english_term: EEG with generalized sharp slow waves
chinese_term: 脑电图，伴广泛性尖慢波
english_description: EEG with generalized sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
EEG with abnormal amplitude.

chinese_term: 伴异常缓慢频率的脑电图
english_description: EEG with abnormally slow frequencies.
EEG showing diffuse slowing without interruption.
Hypsarrhythmia occurring in one hemisphere.
Facial height (length) is more than two standard deviations below the mean (objective); or an apparent decrease in the height (length) of the face (subjective).
Forward prominence of the entire forehead, due to protrusion of the frontal bone.
Vertical soft tissue creases in the midline of the forehead, often extending from the hairline to the brow, and seen with facial expression or when the face is at rest.
Posterior positioning of the glabella, i.e., of the midline forehead between the supraorbital ridges.
Linear vertical groove in the midline of the forehead, extending from hairline to glabella.
Absent eyelids.
Redundant eyelid skin pressing the eyelashes against the cornea and/or conjunctiva.
An abnormal elevation of the C-reactive protein level in the blood circulation.
An eyebrow that extends straight across the brow, without curve.
Regional increase in the width (height) of the eyebrow.
An eyebrow that extends laterally beyond the orbital rim rather than turning gently downward at that location.
Eyelashes that draw the attention of the viewer due to increased density and/or length and/or curl without meeting the criteria of trichomegaly.
Elevated ridge(s) of skin starting well below the medial aspect of the lower lid that curves gradually upward toward and/or across the nasal bridge.
No discernible ridge between concha and triangular fossa and helix.
Antihelical ridge that forms an acute angle between the antitragus and its bifurcation (stem) instead of a gently curving arc.
Increased protrusion of the inferior crus relative to the prominence of the antihelix stem.

english_term: Abnormality of superior crus of antihelix
english_description: An abnormality of the superior crus of the antihelix is the upper cartilaginous ridge arising at the bifurcation of the antihelix that ends beneath the fold of the ascending helix, and separates the concha from the triangular fossa.
Decreased protrusion of the superior crus relative to the prominence of a normal antihelix stem.
Increased protrusion of the superior crus relative to the prominence of a normal antihelix stem.
Reduction in the anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.
Continuum between the tragus and ascending helix, without any evidence of a posterior extension (crus) towards the concha.
Small expansion of the helical fold at the junction of the superior and descending portions of the helix.
Discontinuity in the convexity of the inferior margin of the lobe.
Presence of all the normal ear components and the median longitudinal length more than two standard deviations below the mean.
Presence of some auricular structures, but none of these structures conform to recognized ear components.
Lack of convexity or prominence of the contour of the ridge between the bottom of the incisura and the confluence of the ascending helix and crus helix.
A complete or partial duplication of the tragus; expected to lie anterior to the normal tragus.
Increase posterolateral protrusion of the tragus.
Decreased posterolateral protrusion of the tragus.
Abnormally increased variability in the size of erythrocytes.
Increased susceptibility to mycobacterial infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of mycobacterial infection.

chinese_term: 反复鸟分枝杆菌复合菌感染
english_description: Increased susceptibility to mycobacterial avium complex infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of mycobacterial infection.
A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment does not extend beyond the upper sigmoid.

chinese_term: 长节段无神经节巨结肠
english_description: A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment extends proximal to the sigmoid.

english_term: EEG with frontal sharp slow waves
english_description: EEG with sharp slow waves in the frontal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
EEG with sharp waves in the parietal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
A morphological abnormality of a digit, i.e., of a finger or toe.
A soft tissue prominence of the ventral aspects of the fingertips or toe tips.
Increased width of the distal segment of a finger.
For children from birth to 16 years of age the length of the palm is more than the 97th centile; or, the length of the palm appears relatively long compared to the finger length or the limb length.
Increased thumb width without increased dorso-ventral dimension.
The absence of a phalangeal segment of a toe or hallux.
Toes that are disproportionately narrow (reduced girth) for the hand/foot size or build of the individual.
The gradual reduction in girth of the toe from proximal to distal.
Extension of the proximal transverse crease (five finger crease) to the ulnar edge of the palm.
Decreased width of nail.
An abnormality of size or shape of the long bones.
Synostosis affecting only one of the coronal sutures.
Synostosis affecting only the left coronal suture.
Unicoronal synostosis affecting only the right coronal suture.
Synostosis affecting the right and the left coronal suture.
Premature synostosis of only one lambdoid suture.
Premature synostosis of only the left lambdoid suture.
Incomplete fusion of the chin, resulting from a developmental defect and manifesting as a midline cleft or fissure of the chin.
Craniosynostosis involving at least 2 cranial sutures, where the exact pattern of sutures fused has not been precisely specified.
Craniosynostosis of all calvarial sutures.
Asymmetry of the anterior part of the skull.
Asymmetry of the posterior part of the skull.
An abnormality of the fontanelle.
Any anomaly of a cranial suture, that is one of the six membrane-covered openings in the incompletely ossified skull of the fetus or newborn infant.
Premature fusion of the metopic suture.
Unilateral underdevelopment of the facial tissues, including muscles and bones.
Asymmetry observed in the face of a neonate or infant whose face appears symmetric at rest and asymmetric during crying as the mouth is pulled downward on one side while not moving on the other side.
Excessive amount of hair growth on forehead.
Bilateral temporal scarlike defects, which are said to resemble forceps marks.
An abnormality of the vermilion border, the sharp demarcation between the lip (red colored) and the adjacent normal skin.
Increased width of the upper lip.
A mild delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.
A moderate delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.

chinese_term: 严重的全面性发育迟缓
english_description: A severe delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.
An abnormality involving the movement of the eye outwards.

chinese_term: 语言理解中度发育延迟
english_description: A moderate delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.

chinese_term: 严重的理解性语言发育延迟
english_description: A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.
Formation of excess fibrous connective tissue in the tunica intima (innermost layer) of arteries.
An abnormality of the skin that is not localized to any one particular region.
A lesion of the skin that is located in a specific region rather than being generalized.
An abnormality of the skin that is restricted to a particular body region.
Reduced pigmentation of hair diffusely.
Hair that lacks the lustre (shine or gleam) of normal hair.
An abnormal amount of hair.
Hypopigmented hair that appears white.
Reduced pigmentation of hair in patches.
Yellowish discoloration of the nails.
Congenital deep dermal melanosis in the sacral area.
Increased susceptibility to cutaneous fungal infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of cutaneous fungal infections.
Absence of the inner ear due to a developmental defect.
Absence of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect.

english_term: Dilated vestibule of the inner ear
english_description: Dilatation of the vestibule of the inner ear.

english_term: Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal
english_description: An abnormality of the morphology of the semicircular canal.
Absence of the semicircular canal.
Underdevelopment of the semicircular canal.
Reduction in diameter of the internal auditory canal.
Increased size of the vestibular aqueduct.
Increased size of the cochlear duct, i.e., of a duct that communicates between the perilymphatic space and the subarachnoid space, and transmits a vein from the cochlea to join the internal jugular.

english_term: Abnormality of the dorsal column of the spinal cord
english_description: An abnormality of the dorsal columns, i.e., of the dorsal portion of the gray substance of the spinal cord. The dorsal column consists of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus and itself is part of the dorsal funiculus.
Atrophy of the tibialis muscle.

chinese_term: 中枢神经系统髓鞘异常
english_description: An abnormality of myelination of nerves in the central nervous system.
Delayed myelination in the peripheral nervous system.
Demyelination of peripheral sensory nerves.

chinese_term: 儿童期发病的短肢型矮小
婴儿发病的短躯干矮小症
english_description: A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with onset in infancy.

Structural anomaly of the fetal membranes (also known as the amniochorionic or placental membranes), which comprise a vital intrauterine compartment, where they perform mechanical, immune, and endocrine functions to promote growth of the fetus and protection from environmental adversity. Amniochorionic membranes anatomically consist of a single layer of cuboidal amnion epithelial cells, chorionic trophoblasts, and scattered fibroblasts connected by a layer of type IV collagen-rich extracellular matrix.
Delivery of a fetus through surgical incisions made through the abdominal wall (laparotomy) and the uterine wall (hysterotomy).
Delivery of newborn by means of a ventouse, a vacuum device used to assist the delivery of a baby when the second stage of labour has not progressed adequately.
An abnormality of the placenta in which there are numerous cystic spaces within the placenta as well as placental enlargement.
Separation of the placenta from the uterus wall before delivery.
Death during adolescence, the period between childhood and adulthood (roughly between the ages of 10 and 19 years).
An abnormally increased chloride concentration in the blood.
An increased consentration of zinc in the blood.

chinese_term: 母体血清甲胎蛋白浓度增高
english_description: An abnormally high concentration of serum alpha-fetoprotein as compared to normal values for gestational-age.
A medical history of a fetus or child born to a mother with an autoimmune disease.
A medical history of exposure of the mother of a child or fetus to a teratogenic substance during pregnancy.
An abnormality of the medulla oblongata, the lower half of the brainstem.
An anomaly of the control or production of movement in the central nervous system.
A type of cerebral palsy characterized by slow, involuntary muscle movement and mixed muscle tone.
Cognitive, psychiatric or memory anomaly.
Hyposegmented (hypolobulated) or bilobed neutrophil nuclei.
Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Ankle clonus is tested by rapidly flexing the foot upward.
Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Knee clonus can be tested by rapidly pushing the patella towards the toes.
Head circumference below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender at birth.

english_term: Functional abnormality of the middle ear
english_description: An abnormality of the function of the middle ear.
This term refers to the loss of eyelashes that were previously present.
A subjective manifestation of disease localized to the abdomen.
The presence of a carcinoma of the esophagus.
Onset prior to birth but after 8 weeks of embryonic development (corresponding to a gestational age of 10 weeks).
Onset of disease at the age of between 16 and 40 years.
Onset of disease at the age of between 1 and 5 years.
Absence or underdevelopment of the gallbladder.
A developmental defect in which the gallbladder fails to form.
Sudden, repetitive, nonrhythmic motor movements (spasms), involving the eyes and muscles of the face.
Regurgitation of milk through the nose.
Feeding problem necessitating nasogastric tube feeding.
Feeding problem necessitating gastrostomy tube feeding.
The enteric villi are atrophic or absent.

chinese_term: 极重度感音神经性听力损失
english_description: Complete loss of hearing related to a sensorineural defect.

In primary position, the eyes drift slowly downward and then spontaneously beat upward. Upward gaze accentuates the nystagmus. The associated oscillopsias are often very irritating, but the symptoms are usually transient.
Absence of globe, optic nerve, chiasm and optic tracts. No evidence of ocular tissue on MRI scan or examination.
A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of one eye.
An abnormality of the lacrimal duct, a duct that drain tears from the conjunctiva, via the lacrimal puncta, into the lacrimal sac.

english_term: Anterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
english_description: Adhesions between the iris and the cornea.

english_term: Posterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
english_description: Adhesions between the iris and the lens.
A increased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.
Abnormality of the corneal endothelium, that is, the single layer of cells on the inner surface of the cornea.

chinese_term: 角膜后弹力层形态异常
english_description: Abnormality of Descemet's membrane, which is the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium.

english_term: Reduced number of corneal endothelial cells
chinese_term: 角膜内皮细胞的数目减少
english_description: A reduction in the number of corneal endothelial cells.
An abnormality of the stroma of cornea, also known as the substantia propria of cornea.
Reduced transparency of the central portion of the corneal stroma.
Ingrowth of new blood vessels into the cornea.
Abnormal dilatation of the iris.
Multiple pupils.
A conical projection of the anterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
A conical projection of the posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
Progressive maculopathy characterized by concentric regions of hyper- and hypo-pigmentation.
Cystoid macular edema (CME) is any type of macular edema that involves cyst formation.
Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) is the creation of new blood vessels in the choroid layer of the eye.
Pale often indistinct lesions of the macula.
A macular hole is a small break in the macula, located in the center of the retina.
Increased amount of pigmentation in the macula lutea.
Drusen (singular, 'druse') are tiny yellow or white accumulations of extracellular material (lipofuscin) that build up in Bruch's membrane of the eye.
Increased pigmentation of the fundus

A benign tumor of the retina that appears as a grouping of blood-filled saccules within the inner retinal layers or on the surface of the optic disc. Retinal cavernous angioma are described as having a 'cluster of grapes' appearance.
A condition where the retina contains no functional cone cells, so that in addition to the absence of color discrimination, vision in lights of normal intensity is difficult.

A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with abnormal M photopigment, such that the absorption spectrum is shifted toward L wavelengths. Affected individuals have difficulties distinguishing between red and green.
An iris cyst is composed of a single cell layer of epithelium and is filled with fluid.
Malignant tumor of melanocytes affecting the iris.
Exaggerated curvature of the lens of the eye, producing an anterior or posterior spherical bulging.
A small break in the retina.
Inflammation of the vitreous body, characterized by the presence of inflammatory cells and protein exudate in the vitreous cavity.
A type of retinal exudate located in the subretinal space between the sensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.

chinese_term: 雪花型玻璃体视网膜变性
english_description: The appearance of yellow/white crystalline-like (hence the name) spots in the retina and thickening of the peripheral part of the vitreous.
Right atrial isomerism is characterized by bilateral triangular, morphologically right atrial, appendages, both joining the atrial chamber along a broad front with internal terminal crest.
In left atrial isomerism there is a bilateral small finger-shaped morphologically left atrial appendage joining the atrial chamber along a narrow front without an internal terminal crest.
Common atrium without defining morphologic features.

english_term: Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries
chinese_term: 先天矫正型大动脉转位
english_description: The essence of the lesion is the combination of discordant atrioventricular and ventriculo-arterial connections. Thus, the morphologically right atrium is connected to a morphologically left ventricle across the mitral valve, with the left ventricle then connected to the pulmonary trunk. The morphologically left atrium is connected to the morphologically right ventricle across the tricuspid valve, with the morphologically right ventricle connected to the aorta.
Connection of the right atrium to the left ventricle and of the left atrium to the right ventricle in a biventricular heart.

The condition in which both atria are joined to the left ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually there is a hypoplastic right ventricle, which may be on the opposite side of the heart as usual.
The condition in which both atria are joined to the right ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually, the left ventricle is hypoplastic.
A congenital defect with failure to open of the mitral valve orifice.
Complete absence of the interatrial septum with common atrioventricular valve and two atrioventricular connections.
Abnormality of the mitral valve apparatus, whereby chordae attach to a single papillary muscle or hypoplastic papillary muscles.
Congenital defect characterized by underdevelopment of the tricuspid valve.
A tricuspid valve that has failed to open.

A specific combination of heart defects including a primum atrial septal defect and cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet. There is not an inlet ventricular septal defect present. There are two valve annuluses and two valve orifices.

Anatomic features of unbalanced atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) include varying amounts of ventricular hypoplasia, as well as malalignment of the atrioventricular junction. In complete AVSD, the common AV valve can be situated either equally over the right and left ventricles (balanced) or unequally over the ventricles (unbalanced).

english_term: Short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve
english_description: Abnormally short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve.
A congenital defect of heart development characterized by origin of both pulmonary artery and aorta from the morphological left ventricle.

A conenital abnormality of the aortic arch in which the two embryonic aortc arches form a vascular ring that surrounds the trachea or esophagus and then join to form the descending aorta. Double aortic arch can cause symptoms because of compression of the esophagus (dysphagia, cyanosis while eating) or trachea (stridor).

english_term: Left aortic arch with retroesophageal right subclavian artery
chinese_term: 左位主动脉弓伴食管后右锁骨下动脉
english_description: Aortic arch crosses the left mainstem bronchus. The first branch is the right carotid artery, the second branch is the left carotid artery, the third branch is the subclavian artery, the fourth branch is the right subclavian artery arising from the posteromedial aspect of the distal aortic arch and continuing posterior to the esophagus to the right hand side of the body.
Mesocardia is an abnormal location of the heart in which the heart is in a midline position and the longitudinal axis of the heart lies in the mid-sagittal plane.
Non-continuity of the arch of aorta with an atretic point or absent segment.
An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which the morphology of both left and right lungs is the same.
A ventricular septal defect that involves the inlet of the right ventricular septum immediately inferior to the AV valve apparatus.

The trabecular septum is the largest part of the interventricular septum. It extends from the membranous septum to the apex and superiorly to the infundibular septum. A defect in the trabecular septum is called muscular VSD if the defect is completely rimmed by muscle.

chinese_term: 多发肌部型室间隔缺损
english_description: A type of muscular ventricular septal defect characterized by the presence of multiple small defects in the ventricular septum.
Right pulmonary venous return to the inferior vena cava.
A developmental defect of the pericardium with congenital onset.
No pericardium around the heart, occurring as a congenital defect, not the result of a surgical pericardectomy.

Isolated abnormalities of the coronary artery origins. This may be in associated with other structural heart malformations but not the patterns of complex structural heart malformations which result in abnormal course of the coronary arteries.

english_term: Anomalous origin of left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
chinese_term: 肺动脉源性左冠状动脉起源异常
english_description: Left main coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta, above the left cusp of the aortic valve.
The presence of a single coronary artery ostium from which both coronary arteries arise.

english_term: Dilatation of the sinus of Valsalva
english_description: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation of one of the anatomic dilations of the ascending aorta, which occurs just above the aortic valve.

english_term: Patent ductus arteriosus after birth at term
english_description: Abnormal persistent patency of the ductus arteriosus in postnatal life when birth was at 37 completed weeks of gestation or greater.

english_term: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
chinese_term: 右室双出口伴双交通室间隔缺损及肺动脉狭窄
english_description: A double outlet right ventricle with a subaortic ventritricular septal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that extends anterosuperiorly and are closely related to the pulmonary artery as well, are considered to be doubly committed. There is associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

english_term: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
chinese_term: 右室双出口伴肺动脉下室间隔缺损无肺动脉狭窄
english_description: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the pulmonary origin. There is not associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

english_term: Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
chinese_term: 一侧肺动脉异常起源于升主动脉
english_description: Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from the ascending aorta with the contralateral pulmonary artery arising from the right ventricle.
Failure to develop of the tricuspid valve and thus lack of the normal connection between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
Right ventricular dysfunction (global or regional) with functional and morphological right ventricular abnormalities, with or without left ventricular disease.

chinese_term: 左室致密化不全心肌病
english_description: Left ventricular non-compaction (LVNC) is characterized by prominent left ventricular trabeculae and deep inter-trabecular recesses. The myocardial wall is often thickened with a thin, compacted epicardial layer and a thickened endocardial layer. In some patients, LVNC is associated with left ventricular dilatation and systolic dysfunction, which can be transient in neonates.

Transient left ventricular apical ballooning syndrome or takotsubo cardiomyopathy is characterized by transient regional systolic dysfunction involving the left ventricular apex and/or mid-ventricle in the absence of obstructive coronary disease on coronary angiography. Patients present with an abrupt onset of angina-like chest pain, and have diffuse T-wave inversion, sometimes preceded by ST-segment elevation, and mild cardiac enzyme elevation.

english_term: Left superior vena cava draining directly to the left atrium
english_description: A persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC) that drains into the left atrium instead of the right atrium via the coronary sinus, resulting in a right to left sided shunt.

english_term: Left superior vena cava draining to coronary sinus
english_description: A persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC) that drains into the right atrium via the coronary sinus. This is the case in 80-92% of cases of PLSVC and results in no hemodynamic consequence.

english_term: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation
chinese_term: 下腔静脉中断伴奇静脉延续
english_description: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation is the result of connection failure between the right subcardinal vein and the right vitelline vein. Consequently, venous blood from the caudal part of the body reaches the heart via the azygous vein and superior vena cava.

A myxoma (tumor of primitive connective tissue) of the heart. Cardiac myxomas consist of stellate to plump, cytologically bland mesenchymal cells set in a myxoid stroma. Cardiac myxomas are of endocardial origina and general project from the endocardium into a cardiac chamber.

Any cardiac rhythm other than the normal sinus rhythm. Such a rhythm may be either of sinus or ectopic origin and either regular or irregular. An arrhythmia may be due to a disturbance in impulse formation or conduction or both.
A ventricular septal defect that lies beneath the semilunar valve(s) in the conal or outlet septum.
A ventricular septal defect that is confluent with and involves the membranous septum and is bordered by an atrioventricular valve, not including the type 3 VSDs.
An abnormal path of a coronary artery.

english_term: Supraventricular tachycardia with an accessory connection mediated pathway
chinese_term: 室上性心动过速伴旁路连接
english_description: Supraventricular tachycardia in which an accessory pathway connecting the atria and ventricles, apart from the AV node, participates as a necessary part of a reentrant mechanism.
Hemorrhage into the parenchyma of the cerebellum.
Chronic supraventricular tachycardia predominantly seen in childhood.

english_term: Abnormal electrophysiology of sinoatrial node origin
chinese_term: 窦房结源性电生理异常
english_description: An abnormality of the sinoatrial (SA) node in the right atrium. THe SA node acts as the pacemaker of the heart.
Heart rate of greater than 100 beats per minute.

An abnormality involving the generation of the action potential by the sinus node and is characterized by an atrial rate inappropriate for physiological requirements. Manifestations include severe sinus bradycardia, sinus pauses or arrest, sinus node exit block, chronic atrial tachyarrhythmias, alternating periods of atrial bradyarrhythmias and tachyarrhythmias, and inappropriate responses of heart rate during exercise or stress.
Delay of conduction through the atrioventricular node, which is manifested as prolongation of the PR interval in the electrocardiogram (EKG). All atrial impulses reach the ventricles.

An intermittent atrioventricular block with failure of some atrial impulses to conduct to the ventricles, i.e., some but not all atrial impulses are conducted through the atrioventricular node and trigger ventricular contraction.

chinese_term: 默比茨I型房室传导阻滞
english_description: Progressive PR interval prolongation with the subsequent occurrence of a single nonconducted P wave that results in a pause. The pause that follows the nonconducted impulse is less than fully compensatory (less than the sum of two normal sinus intervals).
Block of conduction of electrical impulses along the Bundle of His or along one of its bundle branches.
Conduction block in the anterior division of the left bundle branch of the bundle of His.

A conduction block of the right branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a prolongation of the QRS complex (greater than 0.12 s) with delayed activation of the right ventricle and terminal delay on the EKG.
A conduction block of the left branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a generalized disturbance of QRS morphology on EKG.
Abnormal conduction in all three divisions of the intraventricular conducting tissue.

Junctional ectopic tachycardia (JET) is a unique type of supraventricular arrhythmia defined by narrow QRS complex and atrioventricular (AV) dissociation or retrograde atrial conduction in a 1:1 pattern.

english_term: Cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
chinese_term: 心型完全性肺静脉连接异常
english_description: Type 2 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.

Systemic desaturation of a liveborn baby resulting from persistent pulmonary hypertension with a patent ductus arteriosus and patent foramen ovale, such that the circulation in postnatal life follows the fetal course.
Weakness of the peroneal muscles.

An abnormality of sensation related to CNS function. Assuming the primary sensory modalities are intact and the patient is alert and cooperative, the presence of an abnormality of sensory function may indicate a lesion of a parietal cortex, the thalamocortical projections to the parietal cortex, or the spinal cord.
An abnormality of the concentration of cortisol in the blood.

chinese_term: 中枢性肾上腺功能不全
english_description: A form of adrenal insufficiency related to a lack of ACTH, which leads to a decrease in the production of cortisol by the adrenal glands. Aldosterone production is not usually affected.

chinese_term: 促肾上腺皮质激素缺陷性肾上腺功能不全
english_description: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in ACTH production.
A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by a defect within the adrenal gland.

chinese_term: 地塞米松可抑制的原发性醛固酮增多症
english_description: A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone can be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone.

chinese_term: 糖皮质激素不敏感的原发性醛固酮增多症
english_description: A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone cannot be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone or similar glucocorticoids.
Absent development of the adrenal gland.

chinese_term: 分泌型肾上腺皮质腺瘤
english_description: An hormonally active adrenocortical adenoma, that is, an adenoma that secretes excessive amounts of adrenal hormones.

chinese_term: 促肾上腺皮质激素不足
english_description: A reduced ability to secrete adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), a hormone that stimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete of glucocorticoids such as cortisol.

chinese_term: 促肾上腺皮质激素过多
english_description: Overproduction of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which generally leads secondarily to overproduction of cortisol by the adrenal cortex.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the adenohypophysis, which is also known as the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland.
The presence of a neoplasm (tumour) in the neurohypophysis, which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis.

An abnormal anatomical location of the posterior lobe of the hypophysis, also known as the neurohypophysis. The posterior pituitary is normally present in the dorsal portion of the sella turcica, but when ectopic is usually near the median eminence. This defect is likely to be due to abnormal migration during embryogenesis.
Absence of the neurohypophysis owing to a developmental defect.
Underdevelopment of the neurohypophysis.
A type of pituitary adenoma that produces gonadotropins.
A type of pituitary adenoma that produces growth hormone.
A type of pituitary adenoma that is of unknown cellular origin and that lacks immunocytochemical or fine structural markers. Null cell adenomas are not associated with hormone excess.
A type of pituitary adenoma that produces thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).
Absence of a lobe of the thyroid gland related to a failure of its embryologic development.
An abnormal growth of parafollicular (C-cells) cells.

chinese_term: 甲状腺毒症伴弥漫性甲状腺肿
毒性多结节性甲状腺肿

english_term: Thyrotoxicosis with toxic single thyroid nodule
chinese_term: 甲状腺毒症伴毒性单个甲状腺结节
中枢性甲状腺功能减退症
english_description: A type of hypothyroidism due to an insufficient stimulation of an otherwise normal thyroid gland. Central hypothyroidism is caused by either pituitary (secondary hypothyroidism) or hypothalamic (tertiary hypothyroidism) defects.
An elevated concentration of free 3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine in the blood circulation.

english_term: Impaired sensitivity to thyroid stimulating hormone
chinese_term: 促甲状腺激素受体敏感性缺陷
english_description: Reduced sensitivity of thyroid follicle cells to stimulation by biologically active thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).

chinese_term: 促甲状腺激素受体激活性缺陷
english_description: Gain-of-function thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) defect.
Posterior positions and/or vertical shortening of the infraorbital and perialar regions, or increased concavity of the face and/or reduced nasolabial angle.
Increased size of the parotid gland.
A benign (noncancerous) tumorlike malformation made up of an abnormal mixture of cells and tissues that originates in the tongue.
Visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal bridge, ridge and tip.
A structural abnormality of a skeletal muscle.
Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 1 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy.
Decreased intensity of the patellar reflex (also known as the knee jerk reflex).
A type of myotonia that worsens with repeated muscle contractions.
Impaired ability to recognize letters or numbers drawn by an examiner's fingertip on the patient's skin (the patients eyes are closed or covered throughout this examination).

Lipofuscin (age pigment) is a brown-yellow, electron-dense, autofluorescent material that accumulates progressively over time in lysosomes of postmitotic cells, such as neurons and cardiac myocytes. This term pertains if there is an increase in the accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient.
An increased level of hypoxanthine in the urine.

Basal encephalocele is an encephalocele that occurs along the cribriform plate or through the sphenoid bone. The mass may appear in the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, epipharynx, sphenoid sinus, posterior orbit, or pterygopalatine fossa. The important distinction from other types is that no external tumor is visible except in those rare instances of herniations so large that they protrude through the mouth or nares.
A cleft of the muscular (soft) portion of the palate that is covered by mucous membrane. Soft-palate submucous clefts are characterized by a midline deficiency or lack of muscle tissue.
An abnormality of one or more of the set of bones that make up the facial skeleton.
Increased width of the midpoint of the mandible (mental protuberance) and overlying soft tissue.
Horizontal crease or fold situated below the vermilion border of the lower lip and above the fatty pad of the chin, with the face at rest.
H-shaped crease in the fat pad of the chin.
Prominence of a triangular soft tissue area of the philtrum with the apex to the columella.

Distance between the philtral ridges, measured just above the vermilion border, more than 2 standard deviations below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between the ridges of the philtrum.
Abnormality of the oral mucosa.
Decrease in width of the nasal tip.
Positioning of the nasal tip inferior to the nasal base.
A noninflammatory, progressive occlusion of the intracranial carotid arteries owing to the formation of netlike collateral arteries arising from the circle of Willis.
Congenital absence of the scaphoid..
Detectable but decreased IgA levels that are more than 2 standard deviations below normal age-adjusted means.
Localized thickening and tightness of the skin of the fingers or toes.
A functional anomaly of T cells.
A bone tumor composed of cellular spindle-cell stroma containing scattered multinucleated giant cells resembling osteoclasts.
A type of abdominal pain that comes and goes in waves, most often starting and ending suddenly and being of severe intensity.
Any anomaly in the formation of bone or of a bony substance, or the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone or a bony substance.
Inflammation of the parotid gland.

Accumulation of chyle (the whitish fluid taken up by the lacteals in the intestine, consisting of an emulsion of lymph and triglyceride fat thatpasses into the veins by the thoracic duct) in the pericardium. Chylopericardium is generally caused by obstruction of or trauma to the thoracic duct.
Accumulation of blood in the peritoneal cavity owing to internal hemorrhage.
Abnormal accumulation of fluid leading to swelling of the pharynx.
An appetite for and the persistent ingestion of non-food substances such as clay. In order to diagnose pica, this behavior must have persisted over a period of at least one month.
Decreased activity of coagulation factor IX. Factor IX, which itself is activated by factor Xa or factor VIIa to form factor IXa, activates factor X into factor Xa.
A type of keratitis characterized by inflammation in pinpoint areas of the corneal epithelium.
The presence of spots or rounded patches of abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.
Both lungs have three lobes. Normally, the left lung has two lobes, whereas the right lung has three lobes.
Any anomaly in the formation of the bony substance of the sternum.
An abnormally increased diphosphate(4-) concentration in the blood. Diphosphate(4-), as ester with two phosphate groups, is also known as pyrophosphate.
An anomaly of the ilium ala. This is the large expanded portion of the ilum which bounds the greater pelvis laterally.
Any anomaly in the function of thrombocytes.

chinese_term: 花生四烯酸诱导的血小板聚集受损
english_description: Abnormal response to arachidonic acid as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of arachidonic acid.

chinese_term: 瑞斯托菌素诱导的血小板聚集受损
english_description: Abnormal response to ristocetin as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of ristocetin.

chinese_term: 凝血酶诱导的血小板聚集障碍
english_description: Abnormal response to thrombin or thrombin mimetics as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of thrombin (or thrombin mimetics).
An anomaly in platelet form, ultrastructure, or intracellular organelles.
Average platelet volume above the upper limit of the normal reference interval.
Decreased cell membrane concentration of the glycoprotein complex Ib-IX-V.
An anomaly of alpha or dense granules or platelet lysosomes.
Abnormal bleeding of the umbilical stump following separation of the cord at approximately 7-10 days after birth.
Bleeding from vessels of the various tissues of the eye.
Bleeding in the anterior chamber of the eye.
Hemorrhage from the vessels of the choroid.
Bleeding sufficiently severe as to require red cell transfusion (WHO Grade 3 or 4).

english_term: Bleeding with minor or no trauma
english_description: Significant bleeding or hemorrhage without significant precipitating factor.
Prolonged or protracted bleeding following an invasive procedure or intervention.
Significant maternal haemorrhage/blood loss following deilvery of a child.
A reduced concentration of vitamin K.

english_term: Impaired thromboxane A2 agonist-induced platelet aggregation
chinese_term: 血栓素A2激动剂诱导的血小板聚集受损
english_description: Abnormal response to thromboxane as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of thromboxane A2 receptor agonists.
Increased number of neutrophils circulating in blood.
Decreased concentration of fibrinogen in the blood.
Anomaly in the level or the function of hemoglobin, the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes.
Hemoglobin H (HbH) contains four beta-globin chains. It is normally not present at all in blood, but may make up about 1-40 percent of all hemoglobin in HbH disease, a subform of alpha thalassemia.

chinese_term: 胎儿血红蛋白F持续存在
english_description: Hemoglobin F (HbF) contains two globin alpha chains and two globin gamma chains. It is the main form of hemoglobin in the fetus during the last seven months of intrauterine development and in the half year of postnatal life. In adults it normally makes up less than one percent of all hemoglobin. This term refers to an increase in HbF above this limit. In beta thalassemia major, it may represent over 90 percent of all hemoglobin, and in beta thalassemia minor it may make up between 0.5 to 4 percent.

Hemoglobin A (HbA) contains two globin alpha chains and two globin beta chains. HbA is normally the main adult hemoglobin, representing about 96-98 percent of all hemoglobin. This term represents a decreased in the proportion of HbA below this limit, and can be seen in various forms of thalassemia.
A reduction in the ratio of production of beta globin to that of alpha globin. This is the major abnormality in the various forms of beta thalassemia.
A reduction in the ratio of production of alpha globin to that of beta globin. This is the major abnormality in the various forms of alpha thalassemia.
Missing radius bone on one side only associated with congenital failure of development.
Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metacarpal bones.

english_term: Shortening of all phalanges of fingers
english_description: Abnormal reduction in length affecting all phalanges.
An anomaly of a metacarpophalangeal joint.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the lumbar region.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the thoracic region.
Abnormal calcification in the cardiovascular system.
Atrophy of the extensor digitorum longus muscles, which mediate extension of the toes.
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the fifth toe.
Bending or curvature of a fourth toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).

english_term: Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex I
chinese_term: 线粒体复合物I活性降低
english_description: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex I, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria.

english_term: Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex III
chinese_term: 线粒体复合物III活性降低
english_description: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex III, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria.

english_term: Decreased activity of mitochondrial ATP synthase complex
chinese_term: 线粒体ATP合成酶复合物活性降低
english_description: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial proton-transporting ATP synthase complex, which makes ATP via oxidative phosphorylation, and is sometimes described as Complex V of the electron transport chain.
One or more digit that appears disproportionately short compared to the hand/foot, whereby either the entire digit or a specific phalanx is shortened.

english_term: Hypersegmentation of proximal phalanx of third finger
chinese_term: 第三指近节指骨基部额外分节
english_description: Presence of an additional phalanx-like bone, producing an extra, wedge-shaped bone at the base of the proximal phalanx of the third finger.

An anomaly of the cerebellar peduncles. The superior, middle, and inferior cerebellar peduncles emerge from the cerebellum. The superior cerebellar penduncles connect the cerebellum to the midbrain, the middle cerebellar peduncles connect the cerebellum to the pons, and the inferior cerebellar peduncle connects the medulla spinalis and medulla oblongata with the cerebellum.
An anomaly of the superior cerebellar peduncle.
Increased length of the superior cerebellar peduncle.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the inferior mesenteric artery or superior mesenteric artery .
Decreased concentration of urate in the urine.
A decreased concentration of total carnitine in the blood.
Underdeveloped nails of the fifth toes.
A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between fingers 3 and 4.
An abnormality of the shape of the thoracic vertebra T12 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front).
An abnormality of the shape of the lumbar vertebra L2 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front).
Increased concentration of SO3(2-), i.e., sulfite, in the urine.
Increased concentration of thiosulfate(2-) in the urine.
A type of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessel walls) that affects blood vessels that are smaller than arteries, i.e., arterioles, venules, and capilllaries.

chinese_term: 闭塞性细支气管炎机化性肺炎
english_description: Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) is and interstitial lung abnormalitiy characterized histopathologically by plugs of granulation tissue lying within small airways, alveolar ducts, and alveoli and by chronic inflammatory cell infiltration in alveolar walls. Patients with BOOP generally present with subacute illness, including shortness of breath, fever, malaise, and weight loss.
