english_description: A region of high intensity (brightness) observed upon magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans of the spinal cord.
A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the small intestine.
A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the large intestine.
A benign tumor (adenoma) of the pituitary gland
Present in 1% to 4% of the cases.
The condition of inability to eat normally treated by placement of a thin tube through the nose into the stomach that is then used to carry food.

chinese_term: 周期性中性粒细胞减少症
english_description: Recurrent episodes of abnormally low levels of neutrophils in the body (neutropenia).

english_term: Decreased circulating free fatty acid level
chinese_term: 循环游离脂肪酸水平降低

english_description: An increased concentration of glycerol in the urine.
Reduced desire for sexual activity on the part of a male.
A problem occurring during any phase of the male sexual response cycle that prevents the individual from experiencing satisfaction from the sexual activity
An inflammatory arthritis characterized by purulent synovial fluid with neutrophil accumulation, but with negative cultures.
A type of arthritis that affects up to four joints in the first six months of disease.
The vagina ends in a blind pouch or sac rather than being connected to the internal genitalia.
An abnormal accumulation of fluid and swelling in the tongue.
An abnormal red color of the urine.
An abnormal dark color of the urine.
An abnormal red-brown color of the urine.
An abnormal purple color of the urine.
Underdevelopment of the olfactory bulb.

english_term: Abnormal morphology of the olfactory bulb
english_description: An abnormal morphology of the olfactory bulb (bulbus olfactorius), which is involved in olfaction, i.e. the sense of smell.

english_term: Focal hyperintensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
english_description: An abnormal area of increased brightness (hyperintensity) that is limited to one particular area.

english_term: Multifocal hyperintensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
chinese_term: 多灶性脑白质高信号的MRI表现
english_description: An abnormal area of increased brightness (hyperintensity) that occurs in several distinct areas.

english_term: Confluent hyperintensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
chinese_term: 脑白质融合性高信号的MRI表现
english_description: Areas of brighter than expected MRI signal in the white matter of the brain whereby individual patches run together.

english_term: Focal hypointensity of cerebral white matter on MRI

english_description: Chronic rhinitis accompanied by pus formation.

chinese_term: 中性粒细胞乳铁蛋白缺乏
english_description: The absence of lactoferrin in neutrophil granules, which could be caused by either an isolated failure of synthesis of this protein (or the production of an antigenically unrecognizable form of lactoferrin) or a complete deficiency of specific granule production.

An abnormality of the nucleus of neutrophils, which presents as either a type I nuclear cleft, where the nuclear cleft may show a transition into a round/oval shape. The second type nuclear cleft, which runs perpendicular to the nuclear surface, and this type of cleft might be related to nuclear lobe formation.

chinese_term: 中性粒细胞碱性磷酸酶低
english_description: An abnormally reduced level of alkaline phosphatase in neutrophils, which could be due to absence of enzyme or the production of defective enzyme.

chinese_term: 中性粒细胞线粒体增加
english_description: An increased number of mitochondria detected in neutrophils.

english_term: Decreased expression of GPI-anchored proteins on the cell surface
chinese_term: 细胞表面GPI锚定蛋白表达降低
english_description: A decrease in the protein expression fo GPI-anchor proteins, such as CD55 and CD59, at the cell surface, which suggests a defect in GPI-anchor biosynthesis.
A lasting absence of immunoglobulin G4 (IgG4) in the blood, whereby at most trace quantities of IgG4 can be measured.
A lasting limited decrease of immunoglobulin G1 (IgG1) in the blood.
A partial or complete breakage of the rib.

A neural tube defect arises when the neural tube, the embryonic precursor of the brain and spinal cord, fails to close during neurulation. The cranial region (anencephaly) or the low spine (open spina bifida; myelomeningocele) are most commonly affected although, in the severe NTD craniorachischisis, almost the entire neural tube remains open, from midbrain to low spine.

A structural anomaly of the substantia nigra, which is a midbrain dopaminergic nucleus which has a critical role in modulating motor movement and reward functions as part of the basal ganglia circuitry.

english_term: Congenital malformation of the left heart
english_description: Defect or defects of the morphogenesis of the left heart identifiable at birth.
Reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids.

Severe microcephaly and lissencephaly with granular surfaces with immature cortical plate, reduced in thickness, with focal polymicrogyria and immature small neurons with rare processes, intermingled with a considerable number of glial elements.
Lymphoma that originates in the stomach itself.
A deviation from the normal serum concentration/activity of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), which catalyzes the reduction of pyruvate to form lactate.
A reduced level of the complement component C4 in the circulation.

chinese_term: 血清补体 C4b 降低
english_description: A reduced level of the complement component C4b in circulation.

chinese_term: 血浆酰基肉碱水平升高
english_description: An abnormally increased concentration in the blood circulation of acylcarnitine, which is produced by reversible esterification of the 3-hydroxyl group of carnitine.

english_term: Reduced insulin like growth factor binding protein acid labile subunit level
chinese_term: 酸性不稳定亚基水平降低
english_description: Blood concentration of insulin like growth factor binding protein acid labile subunit level below normal limits.

Presence of an abnormal type of hemoglobin characterized by the subsitution of a glutamic acid residue at position 7 following the initial methionine residue by a valine (the mutation causative of sickle cell disease). The mutation promotes the polymerization of the HbS under conditions of low oxygen concentration. HbS can be identified by multiple methodologies including hemoglobin electrophoresis and high-performance liquid chromatography.

An elevated concentration in the blood of hemoglobin A2 (HbA2), which is a normal variant of hemoglobin A that consists of two alpha and two delta chains and is normally present at low levels in adults but may be increased in beta thalassemia.
Reduced ability of the lungs to transfer gas from inspired air to the bloodstream as measured by the diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) test.

english_term: Abnormality of the brachial nerve plexus
english_description: Any abnormality of the brachial nerve plexus.
An abnormal appearance of hair under polarizing microscopy (using crossed polarizers), whereby hair shafts show striking alternating bright and dark bands, often referred to as tiger tail banding.
A decrease in the concentration of alpha-fetoprotein in the blood circulation.

A circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid, varying in size from a pinhead to less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point that is composed of localized hyperkeratosis (the latter may be demonstrated histopathologically).

english_term: Aplasia/hypoplasia involving bones of the extremities
chinese_term: 四肢骨发育不良/发育不全

english_description: Inflammation in any serous cavity.
Decreased diameter of eyebrow hairs.
Decreased density/number of eyebrow hairs.

chinese_term: 股骨远端干骺端不规则
english_description: Irregularity of the normally smooth surface of the distal metaphysis of the femur.

english_term: Decreased proportion of CD3-positive T cells
english_description: Any abnormality in the proportion of CD3-positive T cells relative to the total number of T cells.

Abnormally decreased weight-to-height squared ratio, calculated by dividing the individual's weight in kilograms by the square of the individual's height in meters and used as an indicator of underweight compared to averages.
The ability of the knee to move past its normal range of motion, (knee hyperextension is greater than 10 degrees).
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort localized to the hand.
An early onset of puberty, in this case early does not refer to precocious.

Malignant mesothelioma is a form of cancer that originates from the cells of the mesothelium, a thin tissue layer surrounding the body's internal organs. Malignant mesothelioma is almost exclusively caused by asbestos exposure, pleural mesothelioma beeing the most common form, affecting the lining of the lungs called the pleura. Other forms such as perioneal-, percardial- or testicular- mesothelioma are much rarer.

english_term: Neoplasm of the central nervous system
english_description: A neoplasm of the central nervous system.
A benign nerve sheath tumor composed of Schwann cells.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the eye.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the breast.

An epiretinal membrane is a thin sheet of fibrous tissue that can develop on the surface of the macular area of the retina and cause a disturbance in vision. An epiretinal membrane area can develop on the thin macular area of the retin. An epiretinal membrane is also sometimes called a macular pucker, premacular fibrosis, surface wrinkling retinopathy or cellophane maculopathy.
The presence of a supernumerary, i.e. third, crus of the helix in the helix, arising at or above the normal bifurcation of the antihelix.

Folds of membranous tissue (peritoneum, mesothelium) attached to the wall of the abdomen and enclosing viscera. Examples include the mesentery for the small intestine; the transverse mesocolon, which attaches the transverse portion of the colon to the back wall of the abdomen; and the mesosigmoid, which enfolds the sigmoid portion of the colon. Cells of the same embryologic origin also surround the other organs of the body such as the lungs (pleura) or the heart (pericardium).

A nuclear cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the lens nucleus. That is, a nuclear cataract is one that is located in the center of the lens. The nucleus tends to darken changing from clear to yellow and sometimes brown.
A cataract which affects the layer of the lens surrounding the nucleus, i.e., the lens cortex. It is identified by its unique wedge or spoke appearance.
A cataract which is found in the back outer layer of the lens. This type often develops more rapidly.

Cerebral palsy describes a group of permanent disorders of the development of movement and posture, causing activity limitation, that are attributed to nonprogressive disturbances that occurred in the developing fetal or infant brain. The motor disorders of cerebral palsy are often accompanied by disturbances of sensation, perception, cognition, communication, and behaviour, by epilepsy, and by secondary musculoskeletal problems.
An abnormality of movement with a neurological basis characterized by changes in coordination and speed of voluntary movements.
A type of stereotypic behavior in which the affected individual repeatedly waves the hands up and down.
An unusually happy aspect over time which can also may be observed during inappropriate situations that should be causing for example distress, fear or anger.

A form of hypersociability that presents as mostly inappropriate people-orientation and friendliness towards others on an inadequate level which might go as far as being dangerous considering for example young children following strangers without restriction.
An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries.
A recurrent form of pancreatitis.
Mislocalised thyroid gland.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the thyroid gland.

Repeated, individually recognizable, intermittent movements or movement fragments that are almost always briefly suppresable and are usually associated with awareness of an urge to perform the movement.
Movement-based tics affecting discrete muscle groups.
Involuntary sounds produced by moving air through the nose, mouth, or throat. The vocal cords are not involved in all tics that produce sound.

A band of bone material of decreased density forming alongside the surface of the cortical bone with thickening of the periosteum. Callus formation in the affected area is common and gives the appearance of a false fracture.
Scalp hair whose growth is slower than normal.
A broad appearance of the second toe.
Fragmented appearance of the epiphyses.
The abnormal fusion of neighboring bones across a joint.
A connective tissue neoplasm formed by proliferation of mesodermal cells. Bone and soft tissue sarcomas are the main types of sarcoma. Sarcoma is usually highly malignant.
A fibroblastic sarcoma is a malignant tumor derived from fibrous connective tissue and characterized by immature proliferating fibroblasts or undifferentiated anaplastic spindle cells.

Benign, slow-growing tumors without any metastatic potential. Despite their benign nature, they can damage nearby structures causing organ dysfunction. Histologically they resemble low-grade fibrosarcomas, but they are very locally aggressive and tend to recur even after complete resection. There is a tendency for recurrence in the setting of prior surgery and the most common localisation of these tumors is intraabdominal from smooth muscle cells of the instestine.
Osteomas are bony growths found most commonly on the skull and mandible; however, they may occur in any bone of the body. Osteomas do not usually cause clinical problems and do not become malignant.

A contraction of the diaphragm that repeats several times per minute. In humans, the abrupt rush of air into the lungs causes the epiglottis to close, creating a hic sound. Also known as synchronous diaphragmatic flutter (SDF), or singultus, from the Latin singult, the act of catching one's breath while sobbing. The hiccup is an involuntary action involving a reflex arc.

Hemiballismus is a rare movement disorder that is caused primarily by damage to various areas in the basal ganglia. Hemiballismus is usually characterized by involuntary flinging motions of the extremities. The movements are often violent and have wide amplitudes of motion. They are continuous and random and can involve proximal and/or distal muscles on one side of the body, while some cases even include the facial muscles. The more a patient is active, the more the movements increase. With relaxation comes a decrease in movements.
Calcium deposition affecting the Meninges.

chinese_term: 多发中枢神经系统脂肪瘤
english_description: The presence of mulitple lipomas located in the central nervous system.

english_term: Abnormality of the medullary cavity of the long bones
english_description: An abnormality of the medullary cavity (medulla, innermost part), which is the central cavity of bone shafts where red bone marrow and/or yellow bone marrow (adipose tissue) is stored.

english_term: Stenosis of the medullary cavity of the long bones

english_description: The presence of dysplastic regions in metaphyseal regions.
Senile plaques are extracellular deposits of amyloid in the gray matter of the brain.

A condition in which middle parts of the hands and/or feet (digits and meta-carpals and -tarsals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic 3rd toe/fingers over absent 2nd or 3rd toes/fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands and/or feet.
A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the thumb or great toe.
A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the fifth finger or fifth toe.
The presence of a supernumerary finger or toe (not a thumb or hallux) involving the third or fourth metacarpal/tarsal with associated osseous syndactyly.
An abnormality of the structure or form of the tendons, also often called sinews.

chinese_term: 腕骨（跗骨）间的骨性联接
english_description: The carpus consists of the scaphoid, lunate, triquetal, pisiform, captitate, hamate, trapezoid, and trapezium bones. The tarsus consists of the talus, calcaneus, navicular, cuboid, cuneiform, and navicular bones. This term applies if there is any fusion among the bones of the carpus or tarsus.
A depression located on a lip.
Depression located on the vermilion of the upper lip, usually paramedian.
Hyponasal speech is when there is an abnormally reduced nasal airflow during speech often in a setting of nasal obstruction or congestion.

Gustatory lacrimation results from an aberrant innervation of fibres from the seventh cranial nerve to the pterygopalatine ganglion which are destined originally for the submandibular ganglion. This aberrant innervation leads to uncontrollable tearing while eating or in anticipation of a meal.
Diffuse unlocalised atrophy affecting the cerebellum.
Benign congenital lesions of the periauricular soft tissue consisting of a blind-ending narrow tube or pit.

A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that includes characteristic ulcers, or open sores, in the colon. The main symptom of active disease is usually constant diarrhea mixed with blood, of gradual onset and intermittent periods of exacerbated symptoms contrasting with periods that are relatively symptom-free. In contrast to Crohn's disease this special form of colitis begins in the distal parts of the rectum, spreads continually upwards and affects only mucose and submucose tissue of the colon.

A chronic granulomatous inflammatory disease of the intestines that may affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus, causing a wide variety of symptoms. It primarily causes abdominal pain, diarrhea which may be bloody, vomiting, or weight loss, but may also cause complications outside of the gastrointestinal tract such as skin rashes, arthritis, inflammation of the eye, tiredness, and lack of concentration. Crohn's disease is thought to be an autoimmune disease, in which the body's immune system attacks the gastrointestinal tract, causing inflammation.

High frequency discharges in electromyography (EMG) that vary in amplitude and frequency, waxing and waning continuously with firing frequencies ranging from 150/second down to 20/second and producing a sound that has been referred to as a dive bomber sound.

chinese_term: 肌电图:神经肌肉接头传递受损
english_description: An electromyographic finding associated with erratic or absent neuromuscular transmission with erratic, moment-to-moment changes in the shape of the motor unit potential (MUP).
The presence of reduced conduction velocity of motor nerves on electromyography.

chinese_term: 肌电图:肌纤维颤搐放电
english_description: The presence of spontaneous bursts of rapidly firing potentials that recur at regular intervals of 2-10 per second and are unaffected by voluntary effort. This is an electromyographic (EMG) finding.

english_term: Abnormality of peripheral somatosensory evoked potentials
chinese_term: 周围体感诱发电位异常

english_term: Abnormality of central somatosensory evoked potentials
chinese_term: 异常的中枢体感诱发电位
周围神经的淀粉样变性病
english_description: The presence of amyloid deposition in the nerves of the peripheral nervous system.

An increased volume of the endomysium, which is a connective tissue sheath that surrounds each muscule fiber. Together, bundles of muscle fibers form a fasciculus, surrounded by another layer of connective tissue called the perimysium.

Unusual regions of densely packed membranous tubules known as tubular aggregates which present as membranous inclusions, derived from membranes of sarcoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria, containing miscellaneous proteins with a variety of enzymatic activities.
The presence of inclusion bodies within the cytoplasm of muscle cells. Inclusion bodies are aggregates (deposits) or stainable material, usually misfolded proteins.

Atrophy of one side of the brain, characterized by findings including thinning of the cerebral cortex, reduced volume of the cerebral white matter with abnormal myelination, and enlargement of the ispilateral fourth ventricle.
Hemorrhage occurring between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater.
Hemorrhage occurring between the dura mater and the skull.
An intraneuronal inclusion body composed of acid mucopolysaccharides.
An abnormality of the dentate nucleus.
A chronic autoimmune phenomenon characterized by fibrosis (or hardening) and vascular alterations of the skin.
Immunological states where the immune system produces harmful responses upon reexposure to sensitising antigens.
Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against cow milk protein.
A non-midline cleft of the upper lip on one side only.
Clefting of the upper lip affecting the lateral portions of the upper lip rather than the midline/median region.
A non-midline cleft of the upper lip on the left and right sides.
Nonmidline cleft palate on the left and right sides.

english_term: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd toe
chinese_term: 第二趾近端趾间关节挛缩
english_description: The proximal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.

english_term: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd toe
chinese_term: 第三趾近端趾间关节挛缩
english_description: The proximal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.

english_term: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th toe
chinese_term: 第四趾近端趾间关节挛缩
english_description: The proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.

english_term: Contractures of the joints of the upper limbs
Aplasia of the phalanges of the 3rd toe
Aplasia of the distal phalanx of the 5th toe
chinese_term: 第五趾末节趾骨发育不全

english_term: Aplasia of the middle phalanges of the toes
Short distal phalanx of the 5th toe
english_description: Developmental hypoplasia of the distal phalanx of little toe.

english_term: Short middle phalanx of the 5th toe
english_description: Developmental hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the 5th toe.

chinese_term: 第四趾近节/中节趾关节融合
english_description: Bony fusion of the middle and proximal phalanges of the 4th toe.

chinese_term: 第五趾近节/中节趾关节融合
english_description: Bony fusion of the middle and proximal phalanges of the 5th toe.
The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension.

english_term: Joint contractures involving the joints of the feet
english_description: Contractures of one ore more joints of the feet meaning chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
A decreased concentration of ammonia in the blood.

Any structural anomaly of mast cells, which are found in almost all tissues and contain numerous basophilic granules and are capable of releasing large amounts of histamine and heparin upon activation.
An increased susceptibility to bronchiolitis as manifested by a history of recurrent bronchiolitis.
A reduced concentration of vitamin B1.
A reduced concentration of vitamin B2.
A reduced circulating concentration of folic acid, which is also known as vitamin B9.
An anomaly in the metabolism of a vitamin.
A reduced concentration of Vitamin D.
A reduced concentration of vitamin E in the blood circulation. Vitamin E is a lipophilic vitamin that is also known as alpha-tocopherol.
Increased frequency of urination.
The presence of a neoplasm of the urethra.
Painful or difficult urination.
Absence of urine, clinically classified as below 50ml/day.
Low output of urine, clinically classified as an output below 300-500ml/day.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the thymus.
A tumor originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus.
The presence of an abscess of the liver.
Congenital duplication of all or part of a limb.
Tumor of the lung.
A rare cancer originating in the lung or pleural cavity that occurs most often in infants and young children but also has been reported in adults. Pleuropulmonary blastoma is regarded as malignant.

chinese_term: 磷酸盐和钙的调节激素异常
english_description: Any deviation from the normal concentration in the blood circulation of a hormone that is involved in the regulation of phosphate and calcium.
The appearance of abnormal valgus deformity in one knee in association with varus deformity in the other.
Inflammation of the sclera.
Inflammation of the eye, parts of the eye or the periorbital region.
Inflammation of the episclera, a thin layer of tissue covering the white part (sclera) of the eye.
Inflammation of fascia, the tissue under the skin and over the muscle.
Edema affecting the region situated around the orbit of the eye.
Edema in the region of the eyelids.
A hernia which occurs just below the inguinal ligament, where abdominal contents pass through a naturally occurring weakness called the femoral canal.
An abnormal site of the kidney.
Abnormal cognition with deficits in thinking, reasoning, or remembering.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the heart.
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of an artery.
Narrowing of the carotid arteries.
Breakage (tear) of a tendon.
Overgrowth of only one leg.
A growth pattern that displays an abnormal difference between the left and the right side.
Undergrowth of the limbs that affects only one side.
Unilateral atrophy (reduction in size) of an arm.
A difference in length or diameter between the left and right leg.
Difference in length or size between the right and left arm.
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of one or more vertebrae.
A tumor formed from the endocrine (argentaffin) cells of the mucosal lining of a variety of organs including the stomach and intestine. These cells are from neuroectodermal origin.
A cardiac diverticulum is a rare congenital malformation which is either fibrous or muscular.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the biliary system.
The presence of a neoplasm of the gallbladder.
A transient visual disturbance that is typically caused by a circulatory, ocular or neurological underlying condition.
Inflammation of the urinary bladder.
Localized loss of fat tissue.
Telangiectasia of the mucosa, the mucous membranes which are involved in absorption and secretion that line cavities that are exposed to the external environment and internal organs.

An abnormal change (metaplasia) in the cells of the inferior portion of the esophagus. The normal squamous epithelium lining of the esophagus is replaced by metaplastic columnar epithelium. Columnar epithelium refers to a cell type that is typically found in more distal parts of the gastrointestinal system.
An abnormal enlargement of the renal calices, the system of ducts of the kidney that collect urine.

Polypoidal masses arising mainly from the mucous membranes of the nose and paranasal sinuses. They are freely movable and nontender overgrowths of the mucosa that frequently accompany allergic rhinitis.
A rupture of the cornea through which a portion of the iris protrudes.
An inflammation of the endocardium, the inner layer of the heart, which usually involves the heart valves.
Presence of small, permanently dilated blood vessels near the surface of the skin, visible as small focal red lesions.
An abnormality of the retractable fold of skin that covers the tip of the penis.
The presence of a fistula affecting the genitourinary system.
The presence of an abscess of the peritoneum.

An abnormal forward-flexed posture e.g. forward flexion of the spine, which is noticeable when standing or walking but disappears when lying down. It is becoming an increasingly recognized feature of Parkinson's disease and dystonic disorders.
The nostrils (the paired channels of the nose) are not present.
Fluid accumulation in the lungs.

An acute and life-threatening complication of pregnancy, which is characterized by the appearance of tonic-clonic seizures, usually in a patient who had developed pre-eclampsia. Eclampsia includes seizures and coma that happen during pregnancy but are not due to preexisting or organic brain disorders.
Pregnancy-induced hypertension in association with significant amounts of protein in the urine.
Pregnancy-induced toxic reactions of the mother that can be as harmless as slight Maternal hypertension or as life threatening as Eclampsia.
Pain during menstruation that interferes with daily activities.
Bleeding at irregular intervals.
The presence of many cysts in the glomerulus of the kidney related to dilatation of the Bowman's capsule.
Neoplasm involving odontogenic cells, an odontogenic tumor.
Death between the age of 16 and 40 years.
A general term for inflammation of the muscles without respect to the underlying cause.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the ovary.
The presence of a seminoma, an undifferentiated germ cell tumor of the testis.
The presence of a neoplasm of the testis with origin in a Leydig cell.
The presence of a neoplasm of the testis with origin in a Sertoli cell.
The presence of a dysgerminoma, i.e., an undifferentiated germ cell tumor of the ovary.

A displacement of the external urethral orifice from its normal position (in males normally placed at the tip of glans penis, in females normally placed about 2.5 cm behind the glans clitoridis and immediately in front of that of the vagina).
The presence of a diverticulum of the esophagus.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the adrenal gland.

The presence of a piece lung tissue which is not attached to the pulmonary blood supply and does not communicate with the other lung tissue (not connected to the standard bronchial airways and not performing a function in respiration).
Inflammation of the esophagus.
A tumor that originates from a neuroendocrine cell.
A neoplasm originating in the pharynx.
A multidimensional but common male sexual dysfunction that involves an alteration in any of the components of the erectile response, including organic, relational and psychological.
The presence of a neoplasm of the adrenal cortex.
An anomaly of the color of the nail.
Brown or black discoloration of the nails.
Anterior vaginal wall prolapse with bulging of the bladder into the vagina.
Inflammation of the thyroid gland.

An autoimmune disease where the thyroid is overactive, producing an excessive amount of thyroid hormones (a serious metabolic imbalance known as hyperthyroidism and thyrotoxicosis). This is caused by autoantibodies to the TSH-receptor (TSHR-Ab) that activate that TSH-receptor (TSHR), thereby stimulating thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion, and thyroid growth (causing a diffusely enlarged goiter). The resulting state of hyperthyroidism can cause a dramatic constellation of neuropsychological and physical signs and symptoms, which can severely compromise the patients.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the tongue.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the oral cavity.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the vagina.

A chronic condition in which the pancreas produces little or no insulin. Type I diabetes mellitus is manifested by the sudden onset of severe hyperglycemia with rapid progression to diabetic ketoacidosis unless treated with insulin.
Inflammation of the optic nerve.
Optic neuritis that occurs in the section of the optic nerve located behind the eyeball.
A bacterial infection and inflammation of the skin und subcutaneous tissues.
An anomaly of the cerebral blood vessels.
A movement disorder which consists of effects including diminished voluntary movements and the presence of involuntary movements.
A neuropathic disorder characterized by episodes of intense pain in the face, originating from the trigeminal nerve. One, two, or all three branches of the nerve may be affected.
A congenital malformation characterized by the union or approximation of the ears in front of the neck, often accompanied by the absence or defective development of the lower jaw.

Rapid swelling (edema) of the dermis, subcutaneous tissue, mucosa and submucosal tissues of the skin of the face, normally around the mouth, and the mucosa of the mouth and/or throat, as well as the tongue during a period of minutes to several hours. The swelling can also occur elsewhere, typically in the hands. Angioedema is similar to urticaria, but the swelling is subcutaneous rather than on the epidermis.

english_term: Abnormal pigmentation of the oral mucosa
chinese_term: 口腔粘膜色素沉着异常
english_description: An abnormality of the pigmentation of the mucosa of the mouth.

Coarse appearance of the components of the network of osseous tissue that makes up the cancellous structure of a bone, i.e., thickening of the (usually fine) white lines that are produced by trabeculae in radiograms.
Abnormal structure or form of trabecular bone.
The presence of an increased degree of wrinkling (irregular folds and indentations) of the skin as compared with age-related norms.
A congenital absence or considerable underdevelopment of the trachea such that communication between the larynx proximally and the alveoli of the lungs distally is lacking.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of a salivary gland.
A decreased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.
An increase in the degree of curvature of the cornea compared to normal.
Tremulousness of the iris on movement of the eye, occurring in subluxation of the lens.
Tibial torsion is inward twisting (medial rotation) (PATO:0002155) of the tibia.
A form of malignant cancer of the connective tissue surrounding nerves. Given its origin and behavior, it is classified as a sarcoma.
The presence of Neurofibromas in the subcutis.
An extra-parenchymal and intra-arachnoidal collection of fluid with a composition similar to that of cerebrospinal fluid.
A form of loss of vision caused by damage to the visual cortex rather than a defect in the eye.

chinese_term: 星形胶质细胞形态异常
english_description: An abnormality of astrocytes.

Acting on the spur of the moment in response to immediate stimuli; acting on a momentary basis without a plan or consideration of outcomes; difficulty establishing or following plans; a sense of urgency and self-harming behavior under emotional distress.
An abnormality of the thoracic vertebral column.
Any structural abnormality of the lumbar vertebral column.
Aggression towards oneself.
A sectoral indentation of the crystalline lens, usually due to zonular weakness or absence.

Swelling of lymph nodes within the mediastinum, the central compartment of the thoracic cavities that contains the heart and the great vessels, the esophagus, and trachea and other structures including lymph nodes.
An abnormality of coagulation associated with an increased risk of thrombosis.
Thickening and hardening of the epidermis seen with exaggeration of normal skin lines.

A systemic disease which can present with cutaneous lesions with or without internal involvement. Tumors are caused by Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8), also known as Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV).
An excessive number of histiocytes (tissue macrophages).
A rare congenital cystic lesion of the lungs in the mediastinum.
A horizontal cleft of the face, varying from slight widening of the mouth, to a cleft extending to the ear.
An anomaly of one or more epiphyses of one or more vertebrae.
An abnormality of the soft palate.
Abnormal eating habit with excessive or insufficient consumption of food or any other abnormal pattern of food consumption.

A form of anomalous eating behavior characterized by binge eating is followed by self-induced vomiting or other compensatory behavior intended to prevent weight gain (purging, fasting or exercising or a combination of these).
A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in the vascular system.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the chest.
Collapse of part of a lung associated with absence of inflation (air) of that part.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the esophagus.
Formation of abnormal lobules (small masses of tissue) in the liver.

A mental disorder characterized by a disintegration of thought processes and of emotional responsiveness. It most commonly manifests as auditory hallucinations, paranoid or bizarre delusions, or disorganized speech and thinking, and it is accompanied by significant social or occupational dysfunction. The onset of symptoms typically occurs in young adulthood, with a global lifetime prevalence of about 0.3-0.7%.
A state of abnormally elevated or irritable mood, arousal, and or energy levels.
A rare pediatric carcinoma of the pancreas.
A serious and potentially life-threatening condition that arises when a considerable mass of body tissue dies (necrosis).
Terminal broadening of the fingers (distal phalanges of the fingers).
Terminal broadening of the toes (distal phalanges of the toes).

An anomaly of the lymphatic system, a network of lymphatic vessels that carry a clear fluid called lymph unidirectionally towards either the right lymphatic duct or the thoracic duct, which in turn drain into the right and left subclavian veins respectively.

Lymphangiomas are rare congenital malformations consisting of focal proliferations of well-differentiated lymphatic tissue in multi cystic or sponge like structures. Lymphangioma is usually asymptomatic due to its soft consistency but compression of adjacent structures can be seen due to the mass effect of a large tumor.
An abnormality of the tonsils.
A structural anomaly of the vessel that contains or conveys lymph fluid.
An abnormality of the placenta, the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall to enable nutrient uptake, waste elimination, and gas exchange.

A malignant, trophoblastic and aggressive cancer, usually of the placenta. It is characterized by early hematogenous spread to the lungs and belongs to the far end of the spectrum of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), a subset of germ cell tumors.
Excessively active peristalsis (wave of contraction of the tubular organs of the gastrointestinal tract) marked by excessive rapidity of the passage of food through the stomach and intestine.
Reduced or inadequate peristalsis, with resultant slow passage of contents through the digestive tract.
Excessive growth or abnormal thickening of bone tissue.
A widening or ballooning of the dural sac surrounding the spinal cord usually at the lumbosacral level.
An increased susceptibility to pharyngitis as manifested by a history of recurrent pharyngitis.
An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
Increased level of cryoglobulins in the blood. Cryoglobulins are abnormal immunoglobulins, especially IGG or IGM, that precipitate spontaneously when serum is cooled below 37 degrees Celsius.
A rare birth defect in women where the urethra and vagina both open into a common channel.
A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) of the conjunctiva.
An anomaly of the sacroiliac joint, which connects the base of the spine (sacrum) to the ilium (a hip bone).
Failure to develop and congenital absence of the breast.
Persistent difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep.
A bony protrusion present on the midline of the hard palate.
The loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, resulting in loss of cohesion between keratinocytes.
The absence of the normal curvature of the vertebral column.
Testicular inflammation.
An abnormality of the development of the toenails.
An abnormality of the development of the fingernails.

chinese_term: 胰腺发育不良/发育不全
english_description: A congenital underdevelopment (aplasia or hypoplasia) of the pancreas.
Aplasia of the pancreas.
Abnormal anatomical location of the stomach. This feature may be due to intestinal malrotation.
An abnormality of the region around the nails of the fingers or toes.
Flesh-colored papule in or around the nail bed. Ungual fibromas may be periungual (arising under the proximal nail fold) or subungual (originating under the nail plate).
Systemic inflammatory response to infection.

The middle finger is more than 2 SD above the mean for newborns 27 to 41 weeks EGA or above the 97th centile for children from birth to 16 years of age AND the five digits retain their normal length proportions relative to each other (i.e., it is not the case that the middle finger is the only lengthened digit), or, Fingers that appear disproportionately long compared to the palm of the hand.
An outpouching of the gastric wall.
Pain or discomfort of the scalp elicited by palpation.
Noticeably unpleasant odors exhaled in breathing.
Testicular torsion is when the spermatic cord to a testicle twists, cutting off the blood supply. The most common symptom is acute testicular pain.
The presence of hypertension related to stenosis of the renal artery.
Increased inferior to superior extent of the thorax.
An abnormal connection between the gut and another hollow organ, such as the bladder, urethra, vagina, or other regions of the gastrointestinal tract.
Inflammatory or noninflammatory diseases affecting the glomeruli of the nephron.
Inflammation of the lip.
Increase in the number or proportion of lymphocytes in the blood.
An abnormal increase in the total number of T cells detected in the blood.
Spontaneous flow of milk from the breast, unassociated with childbirth or nursing.
Deposits of various size, shape, consistency, refractive index, and motility within the eye's vitreous humour, which is normally transparent.
The presence of a neoplasm of the small intestine.

english_term: Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system
chinese_term: 中枢神经系统的良性肿瘤

english_term: Malignant neoplasm of the central nervous system
chinese_term: 中枢神经系统恶性肿瘤
english_description: A tumor that originates in the pineal gland, has moderate cellularity and tends to form rosette patterns.

Symmetrical vermiform facial atrophy that affects mainly the forehead, the chin, the ear lobes and helices. Atrophodermia vermiculata is characterized by erythema and follicular plugs on the cheeks, developing into painless reticular impressions.
An increased susceptibility to cutaneous abscess formation, as manifested by a medical history of recurrent cutaneous abscesses.
Absence or underdevelopment of the eyebrow.

chinese_term: 透明隔-视神经发育不良
english_description: Underdevelopment of the optic nerve and absence of the septum pellucidum.
An acute hypersensitivity reaction due to exposure to a previously encountered antigen.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the scrotum.
An abnormality of emotional behaviour.

chinese_term: 恐惧/焦虑相关行为异常
english_description: An abnormality of fear/anxiety-related behavior, which may relate to either abnormally reduced fear/anxiety-related response or increased fear/anxiety-related response.
Underdevelopment of the areola, the circular area of pigmented skin surrounding the nipple.
Decreased ossification of the vertebral bodies.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the celiac artery.
Increase in bone density of the vertebral body.
An abnormally short femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
Increased width of the ischium, which forms the lower and back part of the hip bone.
Underdevelopment of the iliac bones.
The narrowing or partial blockage of a portion of the duodenum.
The presence of telangiectases on the skin of palm of hand.
Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located on the skin of sole of foot.

english_term: Abnormality of the plantar skin of foot
english_description: An abnormality of the plantar part of foot, that is of the soles of the feet.
Increased density of hairs, i.e., and elevated number of hairs per unit area.
Skin crease extending from below the inner canthus laterally along the malar process of the maxilla and zygoma.
Abnormally persistent clusters of embryonal cells, representing microscopic malformations (dysplasias) of the developing kidney.
An abnormality in the size of the ocular globe (eyeball).
An abnormality of the Common bile duct, a tube-like anatomic structure in the human gastrointestinal tract, formed by the union of the Common hepatic duct and the Cystic duct from the gall bladder.
The presence of multiple rectal hyperplastic/adenomatous polyps.
Connective tissue nevi are hamartomas in which one or several components of the dermis is altered.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fingers. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An increase in bone density within the clavicle.

chinese_term: 3-羟酰基辅酶A脱氢酶水平降低

english_description: An increase in size of the subarachnoid space associated with the lateral cerebral sulcus (Sylvian fissure).
Underdevelopment of the operculum.
Any structural abnormality of the medulla of the kidney.
Decreased width of the foramen obturatorium. The foramen obturatorium (also known as the obturator foramen) is a hole located between the ischium and pubis bones of the pelvis.

Dense radiopaque bands of bone which are thicker than the adjacent diaphyseal cortex and may form at the metaphysis of growing bones. They appear on radiographs as bone that is more radiopaque that the adjacent diaphyseal cortex.
Increased sensitivity to stimulation, excluding the special senses, which may refer to various modes of cutaneous sensibility including touch and thermal sensation without pain, as well as to pain.
Different levels of maturation of different bones.
Flaring (widening) of the epiphysis.

english_term: Abnormal shape of the palpebral fissure
english_description: The presence of an abnormal shape of the palpebral fissure.

english_term: Abnormal size of the palpebral fissures
english_description: An abnormal size of the palpebral fissures for example unusually long or short palpebral fissures.
The presence of multiple polyps in the intestine.
Overgrowth of the stratum corneum characterized by flesh-coloured or slightly pigmented smooth or warty papules on the upper surface of hands and feet.

A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with defective long-wavelength-sensitive (L) cones, causing the sensitivity spectrum to be shifted toward medium wavelengths. This leads to difficulties especially in distinguishing red and green.
An erosion or abrasion of the cornea's outermost layer of epithelial cells.
Low set, steeply sloping shoulders.
Choroid plexus papilloma is a histologically benign neoplasm located in the ventricular system of the choroid plexus.
A painful and harmful medical condition in which the erect penis doesn't return to its flaccid state, despite the absence of both physical and psychological stimulation, within four hours.

chinese_term: 姐妹染色单体过早分离
english_description: The presence of premature sister chromatid segregation.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the mandible.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the eye.
Grey-green or brownish-pigmented ring in the deep epithelial layers at the outer border of the cornea.
A circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid, varying in size from a pinhead to less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point.
A plaque is a solid, raised, plateau-like (flat-topped) lesion greater than 1 cm in diameter.
Morphologically similar to a papule, but greater than either 10mm in both width and depth, and most frequently centered in the dermis or subcutaneous fat.
A circumscribed, fluid-containing, epidermal elevation generally considered less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point.
A small elevation of the skin containing cloudy or purulent material usually consisting of necrotic inflammatory cells.

Nontender, round and firm, but slightly compressible, intradermal or subcutaneous cyst measuring 0.5-5 cm in diameter. Epidermal cysts are intradermal or subcutaneous tumors, grow slowly and occur on the face, neck, back and scrotum. They usually appear at or around puberty, and as a rule an affected individual has one solitary or a few cysts.
A discontinuity of the skin exhibiting incomplete loss of the epidermis, a lesion that is moist, circumscribed, and usually depressed.
A discontinuity of the skin exhibiting complete loss of the epidermis and often portions of the dermis and even subcutaneous fat.
Warts, benign growths on the skin or mucous membranes that cause cosmetic problems as well as pain and discomfort. Warts most often occur on the hands, feet, and genital areas.
A clonal disorder of keratinization with one or multiple atrophic patches surrounded by a clinically and histologically distinctive hyperkeratotic ridgelike border called the cornoid lamella.
The presence of a characteristic high-pitched cry that sounds similar to the meowing of a kitten.
Inflammation of the cartilage of the external ear.
Shortening of a leg affecting only one side.
Disproportionately small hand.
Scar tissue in the macula.

An aberrant pupillary response characterized by (i) Constriction of pupils of both eyes when the light stimulus is applied to the normal eye, and (ii) Dilatation of pupils of both eyes when the light stimulus is rapidly transferred from the normal eye (after brief light exposure to the normal eye) to the affected eye.
Multiple abnormal growths that arise from the lining of the large intestine (colon or rectum) and protrude into the intestinal lumen.
Repeated episodes of abortion (Expulsion of the product of fertilization before completing the term of gestation) without deliberate interference.

chinese_term: 周边玻璃体视网膜变性
english_description: A type of vitreoretinal degeneration with manifestations that are concentrated at the periphery of the retina.
Intermittent episodes of paralysis of all four limbs.

english_term: Respiratory insufficiency due to defective ciliary clearance
chinese_term: 纤毛清除缺陷所致呼吸功能不全

english_description: Chronic hepatitis characterized by parenchymal inflammation with formation of large multinucleated hepatocytes in response to a variety of insults to the liver.
A facial appearance characterized by a permanently or nearly permanently opened mouth, in which the upper lip is tented in a way that the opened mouth has the appearance of a triangle.
Blisters arising in the mouth.
Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring).
Absence of nail of little finger.

chinese_term: 外动力蛋白臂缺失/缩短

english_description: Metabolic alkalosis is defined as a disease state where the pH is elevated to greater than 7.45 secondary to some metabolic process.

english_term: Recurrent upper and lower respiratory tract infections
english_description: Increased susceptibility to upper and lower respiratory tract infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of upper and lower respiratory tract infections.
Acute hepatic injury resulting from inflammation typically accompanied by increased serum alanine transaminase activity. Etiologies include viral hepatitis, drugs, toxins, and autoimmune disorders.
Chronic hepatitis associated with recurrent clinical exacerbations, extrahepatic manifestations, and progression to cirrhosis.
Hepatitis that lasts for more than six months.

english_term: Chronic hepatitis due to cryptosporidium infection
chinese_term: 隐孢子虫感染引起的慢性肝炎
english_description: Chronic hepatitis associated with infection by cryptosporidia, as demonstrated (for example) by immunohistochemistry of liver tissue.
Any complex of structural, architectural, contractile or electrophysiological changes affecting the atria with the potential to produce clinically relevant manifestations.
Thickening of the heart walls in both ventricles.

A condition in which epileptiform abnormalities are believed to contribute to the progressive disturbance in cerebral function. Epileptic encephalaopathy is characterized by (1) electrographic EEG paroxysmal activity that is often aggressive, (2) seizures that are usually multiform and intractable, (3) cognitive, behavioral and neurological deficits that may be relentless, and (4) sometimes early death.

chinese_term: 粘液样细胞外基质积聚
english_description: An increase of medial mucoid extracellular matrix creating translamellar and/or intralamellar expansions including extracellular pools as noted on an H&E stain and/or a stain to highlight extracellular matrix material (Movat's pentachrome, Alcian blue, etc.).

chinese_term: 基底神经节神经元丢失
english_description: A reduction in the number of nerve cells in the basal ganglia.

english_term: Abnormal liver function tests during pregnancy

chinese_term: 脑脊液淋巴细胞增生症
english_description: An increased lymphocyte count in the cerebrospinal fluid.

english_term: Increased serum bile acid concentration during pregnancy
chinese_term: 孕期血清胆汁酸浓度增高

english_description: Multifocal dense infiltrates of mast cells in cutaneous tissue.
Increased vertical distance from the vermillion border of the lower lip to the inferior-most point of the chin.
Median longitudinal ear length greater than two SD above the mean determined by the maximal distance from the superior aspect to the inferior aspect of the external ear.
Median longitudinal ear length less than two SD above the mean determined by the maximal distance from the superior aspect to the inferior aspect of the external ear.
Prolonged/excessive menses and bleeding at irregular intervals.

Alveolar cleft is a tornado-shaped bone defect in the maxillary arch. Alveolar cleft occurs in response to divergence from normal development during frontonasal prominence growth, contact, and fusion. The most common alveolar portion of the cleft is located between the lateral incisor and the canine.
Any abnormality of the masticatory muscle.
Inflammation or infection of the external auditory canal (EAC), the auricle, or both.
Increased susceptibility to ear infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of ear infections.
Pain that is localized to the region of the upper abdomen immediately below the ribs.
Body odor characterized by an offensive body odor and the smell of rotting fish due to the excessive excretion of trimethylamine (TMA) in the urine, sweat, and breath of affected individuals.
Any abnormality of the periodontium.
A decrease in the amount of alveolar bone around the root of a tooth.
Recurrent episodes of oral herpes, typically characterized by blisters or ulcers on the gums, lips and/or tongue caused by herpes virus.
A gap in the lip or lips.

english_term: Submucous cleft of soft and hard palate
english_description: Soft and hard-palate submucous clefts are characterized by bony defects in the midline of the soft and hard palate that are covered by the lining (ie mucous membrane) of the roof of the mouth.
One sided alveolar cleft of the maxilla.

english_term: Decreased level of 1,5 anhydroglucitol in serum
chinese_term: 血清1,5脱水葡萄糖醇水平降低
english_description: A decrease in the level of 1,5 anhydroglucitol in the serum. 1,5-Anhydrosorbitol is a validated marker of short-term glycemic control. This substance is derived mainly from food, is well absorbed in the intestine, and is distributed to all organs and tissues.

english_term: Increased level of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaric acid in urine
chinese_term: 尿液中3-羟-3-甲基戊二酸水平增高
english_description: An increase in the level of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaric acid in the urine.

english_term: Increased level of GABA in serum
chinese_term: 血清γ-氨基丁酸（GABA）水平增高
english_description: An increase in the level of GABA in the serum.

english_term: Decreased level of GABA in serum
chinese_term: 血清γ-氨基丁酸（GABA）水平降低
english_description: A decrease in the level of GABA in the serum.

english_term: Decreased level of erythritol in urine
chinese_term: 尿液赤藓糖醇水平降低
english_description: A decrease in the level of erythritol in the urine.

english_term: Decreased level of erythritol in CSF
chinese_term: 脑脊液赤藓糖醇水平降低
english_description: A decrease in the level of erythritol in the cerebrospinal fluid.

english_term: Increased level of D-threitol in plasma
english_description: An increase in the level of D-threitol in the plasma.

english_term: Increased level of D-threitol in CSF
chinese_term: 脑脊液D-苏糖醇水平增高
english_description: An increase in the level of D-threitol in the cerebrospinal fluid.

english_term: Increased level of D-threitol in urine
english_description: An increase in the level of D-threitol in the urine.

english_term: Increased level of galactitol in plasma
chinese_term: 血浆半乳糖醇水平增高
english_description: An increase in the level of galactitol in the plasma.

english_term: Increased level of galactitol in urine
chinese_term: 尿液半乳糖醇水平增高
english_description: An increase in the level of galactitol in the urine.

english_term: Increased level of galactonate in red blood cells
chinese_term: 红细胞半乳糖水平增高
english_description: An increase in the level of galactonate in the red blood cells.

english_term: Increased level of galactitol in red blood cells
chinese_term: 红细胞半乳糖醇水平增高
english_description: An increase in the level of galactitol in the red blood cells.

english_term: Increased level of hippuric acid in urine
english_description: An increase in the level of hippuric acid in the urine.

english_term: Increased level of L-fucose in urine
english_description: An increase in the level of L-fucose in the urine.

english_term: Increased level of L-glutamic acid in blood
english_description: An increase in the level of L-glutamic acid in the blood.

english_term: Increased level of propylene glycol in blood
chinese_term: 血液中丙二酸浓度增高
english_description: An increase in the level of propylene glycol in the blood.

english_term: Increased level of ribitol in urine
english_description: An increase in the level of ribitol in the urine. Ribotol is a crystalline pentose alcohol (C5H12O5) and is a metabolic end product formed by the reduction of ribose.

english_term: Increased level of ribitol in CSF
chinese_term: 脑脊液核糖醇水平增高
english_description: An increase in the level of ribitol in the cerebral spinal fluid.

english_term: Increased level of ribose in urine
english_description: An increase in the level of ribose in the urine.

english_term: Increased level of ribose in CSF
english_description: An increase in the level of ribose in the cerebrospinal fluid.

english_term: Increased level of xylitol in urine
english_description: An increase in the level of xylitol in the urine.

english_term: Increased level of xylitol in CSF
chinese_term: 脑脊液木糖醇水平增高
english_description: An increase in the level of xylitol in the cerebrospinal fluid.

english_term: Increased level of L-pyroglutamic acid in urine
chinese_term: 尿液L-焦谷氨酸水平增高
english_description: An increase in the level of L-pyroglutamic acid in the urine.
Urticaria may be caused by cold temperatures.
A decrease in the biotinidase level, an enzyme that releases biotin from biocytin, the product of biotin-dependent carboxylases degradation.

chinese_term: 食道嗜酸性粒细胞浸润
english_description: Infiltration of numerous eosinophils (usually greater than 15 per high power field) into the squamous epithelium of the esophagus, and layering of eosinophils on the surface layer of the esophagus.

english_term: Increased level of methylsuccinic acid in urine
english_description: An increase in the level of methylsuccinic acid in the urine.
Partial or complete wasting (loss) of hippocampus tissue that was once present.

chinese_term: 循环肌钙蛋白I浓度升高
english_description: An increased concentration of tropnin I in the blood, which is a cardiac regulatory protein that controls the calcium mediated interaction between actin and myosin. Raised cardiac troponin concentrations are now accepted as the standard biochemical marker for the diagnosis of myocardial infarction.

chinese_term: 循环肌钙蛋白T浓度升高
english_description: An increased concentration of tropnin T in the blood, which is a cardiac regulatory protein that controls the calcium mediated interaction between actin and myosin. Raised cardiac troponin concentrations are now accepted as the standard biochemical marker for the diagnosis of myocardial infarction.
An increase in the level of ketone bodies (acetoacetic acid, beta-hydroxybutyric acid, and acetone) in the blood.

english_term: Decreased glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase level in blood
chinese_term: 血液6-磷酸葡萄糖脱氢酶降低
english_description: A decrease in the level of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in the blood.
An increase in the length of time required for food to pass through the intestines.

chinese_term: 血液5-甲基四氢叶酸异常
english_description: An abnormal concentration of 5-methyltetrahydrofolate in the blood.

english_term: Hypoplasia of mandible relative to maxilla
chinese_term: 相对于上颌骨下颌骨发育不良
english_description: Abnormally small dimension of the mandible (lower jaw) relative to the maxilla (upper jaw).
An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgA immunoglobulin in blood.
An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgG immunoglobulin in blood.
An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgM immunoglobulin in blood.
An abnormally increased level of immunoglobulin D in blood.

chinese_term: 慢性中性粒细胞减少症
english_description: Neutropenia with an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) less than 1,500,000,000/L lasting for more than 3 months.

chinese_term: 一过性中性粒细胞减少
english_description: A transient reduction in the number of neutrophils in the peripheral blood. Transient neutropenia is most commonly associated with viral infections, but other causes include drugs and autoimmunity.

chinese_term: 感染性中性粒细胞减少
english_description: Transient neutropenia caused by an infection, such as with a virus, bacteria or protozoan.
Fusion of the liver with the lung.
A functional abnormality affecting the lower cranial nerves, which include the paired 9th (glossopharyngeal), 10th (vagal), 11th (accessory) and 12th (hypoglossal) cranial nerves.
An anomaly of metabolism or structure of the brain identified by imaging.

An abnormality of the sternum that presents at birth as a ventral sternal non-union defect, due to an abnormality of the fusion of the layers of the skin. It presents as a scar-like line that extends upward from the umbilicus (belly button).
Partial or complete wasting (loss) of the pituitary gland.
Onset of disease manifestations before adulthood, defined here as before the age of 15 years, but excluding neonatal or congenital onset.

A heterogeneous group of symptoms that are localized in the epigastric region. Typical dyspeptic symptoms include postprandial fullness, early satiation, epigastric pain and epigastric burning, but other upper gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, belching or abdominal bloating often occur.
Increased level of amylase in the blood, an enzyme which helps digest glycogen and starch. It is produced mainly in the pancreas and salivary glands.
Decreased level of amylase in the blood, an enzyme which helps digest glycogen and starch. It is produced mainly in the pancreas and salivary glands.
Opposing or not responding to instructions or external stimuli.

chinese_term: 同种红细胞血凝素水平异常
english_description: An abnormal level of isohemagglutinin in the blood. An isohemagglutinin refers to the naturally occurring antibodies in the ABO blood group system (i.e., anti-A in a group B person, anti-B in a group A person, and anti-A, anti-B, and anti-A,B in a group O person).

chinese_term: 同种红细胞凝集素缺乏
english_description: Absent or undetectable level of isohemagglutinin. An isohemagglutinin refers to the naturally occurring antibodies in the ABO blood group system (i.e., anti-A in a group B person, anti-B in a group A person, and anti-A, anti-B, and anti-A,B in a group O person).

english_term: Complete or near-complete absence of specific antibody response to tetanus vaccine
chinese_term: 对破伤风疫苗完全或几乎全无特异性抗体应答
english_description: The inability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a tetanus antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

english_term: Partial absence of specific antibody response to tetanus vaccine
chinese_term: 对破伤风疫苗的特异性抗体应答部分缺失
english_description: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a tetanus antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

english_term: Decreased specific antibody response to polysaccharide vaccine
chinese_term: 对多糖疫苗特异性抗体应答降低
english_description: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against polysaccharides in vaccines, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

english_term: Complete or near-complete absence of specific antibody response to unconjugated pneumococcus vaccine
chinese_term: 对肺炎球菌疫苗完全或几乎全无特异性抗体应答
english_description: The inability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a pneumococcus antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

english_term: Partial absence of specific antibody response to unconjugated pneumococcus vaccine
chinese_term: 对肺炎球菌疫苗特异性抗体应答降低
english_description: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a pneumococcus antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

english_term: Complete or near-complete absence of specific antibody response to Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine
chinese_term: 对B型流感嗜血杆菌（Hib）疫苗完全或几乎全无特异性抗体应答
english_description: The inability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.

english_term: Partial absence of specific antibody response to Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine
chinese_term: 对B型流感嗜血杆菌（Hib）疫苗特异性抗体应答降低
english_description: A reduced ability to synthesize postvaccination antibodies against a Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) antigen, as measured by antibody titer determination following vaccination.
A increased concentration of alpha-aminoadipic acid in the urine.
Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against drugs.

chinese_term: 尿半乳糖寡糖水平升高
english_description: An abnormal increase in the concentration of galactosylated oligosaccharides in urine.

chinese_term: α-肌营养不良蛋白聚糖上O-甘露糖基聚糖减少
english_description: Hypoglycosylation of alpha-dystroglycan with O-mannosyl glycans. Alpha-dystroglycan is a functional target of O-mannosyl glycosylation and functional glycosylation of alpha-DG is essential in its interaction with the extracellular matrix.

english_term: Abnormal proportion of naive CD4 T cells
chinese_term: 初始CD4 T 细胞比例异常
english_description: Any abnormality in the proportion of naive CD4 T cells relative to the total number of T cells.

english_term: Decreased proportion of naive CD8 T cells
chinese_term: 初始CD8 T 细胞比例减低
english_description: An abnormally reduced proportion of naive CD8 T cells relative to the total number of T cells.

english_term: Decreased proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells
chinese_term: 中央记忆性CD4+，α-β T细胞比例减低
english_description: A reduced proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype of CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
An abnormality of the frontal bone.
A partial or complete adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva of the eyelid to the bulbar conjunctiva of the eyeball.
Developmental hypoplasia of the eyelid.

english_term: Abnormal morphology of musculature of pharynx
chinese_term: 咽部肌肉组织形态异常
english_description: An abnormality of any of the muscles of the pharynx.
An abnormality of the common carotid arteries, which provide the arterial supply to the head and neck and give rise to the internal carotid artery and the external carotid artery.
An abnormality of the sphenoid sinus, one of the mucosa-lined, normally air-filled paranasal sinuses of the bones of the skull. The sphenoid sinus is located within the sphenoid bone.
Two-sided or bilateral weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure.

english_term: Abnormality of the shape of the midface
english_description: An abnormal morphology (form) of the midface or its components, the cheeks, maxilla, zygomatic bone, malar region, and infraorbital rims.

Abnormally increased dimension of the maxilla, especially relative to the mandible, resulting in a malocclusion or malalignment between the upper and lower teeth or in anterior positioning of the nasal base, increased convexity of the face, increased nasolabial angle, or increased width (transverse dimension of the maxilla.
A perceived unpleasant smell given off by the body.
Pain in and around the anus or rectum (perianal region).
Multiple cysts along the pupillary margin that appear as spherical or tear-drop-shaped pigmented lesions or wrinkled masses emerging from the pupillary border of the iris.

chinese_term: 小脑发育不良性神经节细胞瘤
english_description: It is a rare, slowly growing tumor of the cerebellum, a gangliocytoma sometimes considered to be a hamartoma, characterized by diffuse hypertrophy of the granular layer of the cerebellum.
A rounded, puffy face with fat deposits in the temporal fossa and cheeks, a double chin.

chinese_term: 心脏运动负荷试验异常
english_description: Abnormal results of exercise on heart function.

chinese_term: 血液脱氢表雄酮水平异常
english_description: A deviation from the normal concentration of dehydroepiandrosterone in the circulation.
A condition where one or both of the two principal meridians focus in the front of the retina when the eye is at rest.
Inflamation of the eyelid due to overactivity of the sebaceous gland.

A conjuctival lesion composed of adipose tissue and dense connective tissue. Such choristomas of dermal elements are normally found at the outer canthus, and have a gelatinous appearance. Classically, there is an indistinct posterior border (with the lesion frequently extending into the orbit) and a well-demarcated anterior border several millimetres posterior to the limbus.
Thinning in the layers of the retina and retinal pigment epithelium around the optic nerve.
A benign tumour of meningothelial cells of the meninges that usually occurs in middle age. It is typically unilateral and there is an association with neurofibromatosis type 2.

Primary food allergies primarily occur as a result (most likely) of gastrointestinal sensitization to predominantly stable food allergens (glycoproteins). A secondary food allergy develops after primary sensitization to airborne allergens (e. g., pollen allergens) with subsequent reactions (due to cross-reactivity) to structurally related often labile allergens in (plant) foods.
An increased amount of urobilinogen present in the stool.
Decreased amount of glutamine in the blood.
An increased amount of glutamate in the blood.
An increased amount of cystine in the blood.
A decreased amount of cystine in the blood.
An increased amount of arginine levels in the blood.
An abnormal decrease in ornithine in the blood.
An elevated amount of gastrin in the blood.

english_term: Abnormal concentration of acylcarnitine in the urine
english_description: An abnormal amount of acylcarnitine in the urine.

chinese_term: 心脏停搏所致的反射性晕厥
english_description: A loss of consciousness followed by stiffening and brief clonic movements affecting some or all limbs, often misinterpreted as an epileptic seizure.
An increased amount of taurine in the blood.
A decreased amount of taurine in the blood.

chinese_term: 脑脊液谷氨酰胺浓度降低
english_description: Abnormally decreased levels of glutamine in cerebrospinal fluid.

chinese_term: 脑脊液精氨酸浓度降低
english_description: Abnormally decreased levels of arginine in cerebrospinal fluid.

chinese_term: 脑脊液赖氨酸浓度升高
english_description: Abnormally increased levels of lysine in cerebrospinal fluid.

chinese_term: 脑脊液甘氨酸浓度升高
english_description: Abnormally increased levels of glycine in cerebrospinal fluid.

english_term: Abnormal CSF pyruvate family amino acid concentration
chinese_term: 脑脊液丙酮酸家族氨基酸浓度异常
english_description: Any deviation from the normal concentration of pyruvate-family amino acids in the cerebrospinal fluid.

chinese_term: 脑脊液丙氨酸浓度升高
english_description: Abnormally increased levels of alanine in cerebrospinal fluid.

chinese_term: 脑脊液白蛋白浓度升高
脑脊液鸟氨酸浓度异常
english_description: Any deviation from the normal concentration of ornithine in the cerebrospinal fluid.

english_term: Increased level of gamma-aminobutyric acid in urine
chinese_term: 尿液γ-氨基丁酸水平升高
english_description: Elevated concentration of gamma-aminobutyric acid in the urine.
The most dramatic and severe form of hair loss characterized by an absence of hair follicles.

english_term: Increased proportion of gamma-delta T cells
english_description: Increased proportion of gamma-delta T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
Slightly raised wart 2-5 mm in diameter often associated with viral infections, commonly persistent in immunodeficient individuals.
An abnormality of a masseter muscle.
An abnormality of an orbicularis oris muscle.
An abnormality of a buccal mucosa.
An abnormality of a blood vessel of the neck, including branches of the arterial and venous systems of the neck.
Any structural abnormality of a cricoid cartilage, that is, of the ring-shaped cartilage of the larynx.
An abnormality of an odontoid tissue.
An abnormality of a hyoid bone.
An abnormality of an internal carotid artery.

chinese_term: 心肌钆对比剂延迟强化
english_description: Areas of high signal intensity in magnetic resonance imaging of the heart appearing 10 to 15 minutes after injection of the intercellular contrast agent gadolinium.
Tightening of smooth muscle surrounding the bronchi and bronchioles with consequent wheezing and shortness of breath.

english_term: Formation of multiple pronuclei during fertilization
chinese_term: 受精过程中多原核的形成
english_description: Pronuclei formation is a critical process during fertilisation. Normally, there are two pronuclei (2PN), including the paternal pronucleus and the maternal pronucleus, in the zygote after fertilisation. It is generally accepted that multiple pronuclei (MPN) formation is due to the abnormal extrusion of the second polar body or to abnormal fertilisation with multiple sperm. The MPN therefore can cause infertility and recurrent failure of IVF/ICSI.

english_term: Impaired renal tubular reabsorption of bicarbonate
chinese_term: 肾小管重吸收受损（肾小管重吸收碳酸氢盐受损）
english_description: Decreased renal tubular reabsorption of bicarbonate.

english_term: Reduced proportion of mucosal-associated invariant T cells
chinese_term: 减少黏膜相关恒定 T 细胞比例减低
english_description: A decreased proportion of circulating mucosal-associated invariant T (MAIT) cells relative to total T cell count.
Extracellular tissue deposition of fibrils that are composed of fragments of and/or intact serum amyloid A protein, a hepatic acute phase reactant.
A reduced amount of programmed cell death upon stimulation of the FAS receptor, which normally induces caspase-8 dependent apoptosis.
A diffuse and specific increase in the number of alpha-cells.
